When on a hill with limited visibility, it is unlawful to pass another vehicle.

questions.question: When driving in fog, you should use your low beam headlights:
questions.answerA: TRUE
questions.answerB: FALSE
questions.explanation: You should always use your low beam headlights when driving in fog. High beam headlights may cause the light to reflect off of the fog and into your eyes.

questions.question: Which statement about speed is true?
questions.answerA: Driving too slowly on certain highways can be dangerous.
questions.answerB: Speeding can kill.
questions.answerC: Speeding is not dangerous if you are a skilled driver.
questions.answerD: Both "Driving too slowly on certain highways can be dangerous" and "Speeding can kill."
questions.explanation: As speed increases, the chance of a fatality increases. If you are moving faster than 80 miles per hour, you have almost no chance of living through a crash. Driving more slowly than other traffic can also be dangerous because other motorists may become impatient and make dangerous moves to pass you.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true?
questions.answerA: You should maintain at least a three- to four-second following distance under normal conditions.
questions.answerB: As speed increases, following distance should decrease.
questions.answerC: Following distances are only important on snow and ice.
questions.explanation: When following another vehicle on any street under normal driving conditions, maintain a three or four second gap between your vehicle and the vehicle in front of you. If any unusual conditions exist, such as rainy weather or increased traffic, increase your following distance.

questions.question: A steady yellow traffic signal light is a warning that the light is about to change to red. If you are already within the intersection when a green light changes to yellow, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop.
questions.answerB: Continue moving and clear the intersection safely.
questions.answerC: Increase your speed so as not to cause an accident.
questions.explanation: If you are already within an intersection when the traffic light turns yellow, you should clear the intersection as quickly as possible.

questions.question: At intersections, crosswalks, and railroad crossings, you should always:
questions.answerA: Stop, listen, and proceed cautiously.
questions.answerB: Look to the sides of your vehicle to see what is coming.
questions.answerC: Slowly pass vehicles that seem to be stopped for no reason.
questions.explanation: Any time you come to a place where people may cross or enter your path, or where one line of traffic meets another, you should look to the left and right sides of your vehicle to make sure no one is coming.

questions.question: You must show proof of insurance to law enforcement:
questions.answerA: Only if you are involved in a collision.
questions.answerB: If you are involved in a collision or stopped for a citation.
questions.answerC: Only if you are stopped and cited.
questions.explanation: You must have evidence of financial responsibility, such as proof of insurance, with you whenever you drive. You must always show proof of insurance and your license to an officer upon request after a traffic stop or collision.

questions.question: When using roundabouts or traffic circles, you should:
questions.answerA: Slow down as you approach the circle.
questions.answerB: Yield to any traffic, pedestrians, or bicyclists already in the circle.
questions.answerC: Enter to the right, but steer left in a counterclockwise direction.
questions.explanation: You should slow down as you approach a roundabout and yield to any vehicles, bicycles, or pedestrians already in the circle. Enter the circle to your right, but steer to your left so that you move around the circle in a counterclockwise direction.

questions.question: If the driver of an oncoming vehicle fails to dim their headlights:
questions.answerA: Look toward the center of the roadway.
questions.answerB: Look toward the right side of the road.
questions.answerC: Look straight ahead.
questions.explanation: If an oncoming driver fails to dim their headlights, look toward the right side of the road. This will keep you from being blinded by the other vehicle’s headlights and allow you to see enough of the road to stay on course. Do not try to retaliate by keeping your bright lights on.

questions.question: You cannot pass safely on a two-way, two-lane street unless:
questions.answerA: You are able to clearly see the road ahead.
questions.answerB: You can return to your lane before meeting oncoming traffic.
questions.answerC: Your vehicle is capable of the speed necessary to pass.
questions.explanation: You cannot pass safely when driving on a two-way, two-lane street unless you can clearly see the road ahead, you can return to your lane before meeting oncoming traffic, and your vehicle is capable of the speed necessary to pass. Do not pass where it is illegal and unsafe to do so.

questions.question: Which statement about backing on a roadway is true?
questions.answerA: The driver should first give a signal to warn approaching traffic from the rear that they intend to stop.
questions.answerB: Drivers should look straight ahead while backing.
questions.answerC: Traffic checks are not necessary when backing.
questions.explanation: You should always look behind you to check for traffic when backing up. Only back up where it is safe and legal to do so.

questions.question: Lanes of traffic moving in opposite directions are divided by ____ lines.
questions.answerA: White
questions.answerB: Red
questions.answerC: Black
questions.explanation: Yellow lines are used to divide traffic moving in opposite directions.

questions.question: It is unlawful for a car to try to share a lane with a motorcycle.
questions.answerA: TRUE
questions.answerB: FALSE
questions.explanation: Motorcycle operators have the right to use a complete traffic lane. Two motorcyclists may share a lane, but a car should never try to share a lane with a motorcycle.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: A left curve is ahead.
questions.answerB: A series of curves is ahead.
questions.answerC: An S-curve is ahead.
questions.answerD: The road will be slippery when wet.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that especially slippery conditions exist when the road is wet.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Stop.
questions.answerB: No U-turn.
questions.answerC: Yield.
questions.explanation: This sign is placed at the beginning of one-way streets and ramps to indicate that you must not continue driving in your current direction.

questions.question: If a green arrow turns into a solid green light, you:
questions.answerA: May still turn, but you must yield to oncoming traffic.
questions.answerB: May no longer turn and must proceed straight.
questions.answerC: Still have the right-of-way to turn.
questions.answerD: No longer have to turn in the direction that the arrow indicated.
questions.explanation: If a green arrow turns into a solid green light, you may still turn in the direction that the arrow was pointing but you must first yield to pedestrians and oncoming traffic.

questions.question: If you are driving near a large commercial vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Follow the large vehicle closely to reduce wind drag on your vehicle.
questions.answerB: Avoid driving beside it for long stretches of time.
questions.answerC: Drive on its right side when on curves and hills.
questions.explanation: Because large commercial vehicles have large blind spots on each side, you should avoid driving beside them for long periods of time.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Traffic signal ahead.
questions.answerB: Stop.
questions.answerC: Yield the right-of-way.
questions.explanation: This sign warns of of an approaching traffic signal.

questions.question: When steering a vehicle:
questions.answerA: Both hands should be placed on the outside of the steering wheel on opposite sides.
questions.answerB: Use a firm but gentle grip on the steering wheel, using your fingers and not your palms.
questions.answerC: All of the above.
questions.explanation: Your hands should be placed on opposite sides the steering wheel with your thumbs aiming up. Grip the wheel gently but firmly, using your fingers rather than your palms. Turn the steering wheel by gripping the outside of the wheel, not the inside.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Side road.
questions.answerB: Keep to the side indicated by the arrow.
questions.answerC: You may drive in the left lane.
questions.explanation: This is a "Keep right" sign. It indicates that a traffic island, median, or barrier is ahead and that drivers must keep to the right of it.

questions.question: At intersections with a "Yield" sign, you must:
questions.answerA: Yield the right-of-way to cross traffic that is near enough to cause conflict.
questions.answerB: Yield the right-of-way only to vehicles on your right.
questions.answerC: Always slow down and proceed without stopping.
questions.explanation: At a yield sign, you must slow down or stop, if necessary, and give the right-of-way to crossing or merging vehicles. Yield the right-of-way to any cross traffic that is close enough to cause conflict.

questions.question: "No zones" are areas around trucks where cars:
questions.answerA: Disappear into blind spots.
questions.answerB: Have sufficient space for traveling behind and passing trucks.
questions.answerC: Can try to squeeze around the truck when the truck makes a wide turn.
questions.explanation: Large trucks and buses have large blind spots to the sides, the rear, and the front. These areas are referred to as "No zones." Drivers of smaller vehicles should avoid lingering in these areas because they will be invisible to the truck driver and may also restrict the truck driver's ability to stop or maneuver safely.

questions.question: When stopped at a red traffic light with a green arrow, you may proceed in the direction of the arrow if you:
questions.answerA: First come to a complete stop.
questions.answerB: Wait until the light changes.
questions.answerC: Are in the proper lane and the intersection is clear.
questions.explanation: You may proceed in the direction that a green arrow signal is pointing if you are in the proper lane, regardless of any other signals that are displayed. Before turning, you must yield the right-of-way to pedestrians and vehicles already within the intersection.

questions.question: When parallel parking between two cars, you should first:
questions.answerA: Turn your wheels to the left.
questions.answerB: Turn your wheels to the right.
questions.answerC: Pull up even with the car in front of your desired parking space.
questions.explanation: After finding a parking space, checking traffic, and signaling, you should stop parallel to the vehicle directly ahead of your desired parking space before turning your wheel to park.

questions.question: A fully loaded tractor-trailer traveling at 55 mph could take up to ____ to come to a complete stop.
questions.answerA: 50 feet
questions.answerB: 125 feet
questions.answerC: 400 feet
questions.explanation: Tractor-trailers take longer distances to stop than smaller cars traveling at the same speed. A fully loaded tractor-trailer may take almost 400 feet to come to a complete stop when driving at 55 mph.

questions.question: Any amount of alcohol in the blood may affect a driver's:
questions.answerA: Right-of-way privileges.
questions.answerB: Judgment and physical coordination.
questions.answerC: Knowledge.
questions.explanation: A driver’s ability to safely operate a vehicle may be impaired at any BAC level, even a level lower than the legal limit. Any amount of alcohol can affect one’s judgment and physical coordination. Driving under the influence of even a small amount of alcohol can lead to criminal charges.

questions.question: As you are driving on a two-lane highway, you approach a school bus that is stopped with its red lights flashing. You:
questions.answerA: May pass if the way is clear.
questions.answerB: May pass if a pedestrian indicates that the way is clear.
questions.answerC: May not pass until the school bus driver turns off the flashing lights and continues driving.
questions.answerD: Must turn on your emergency flashers.
questions.explanation: Drivers are required to stop for a stopped school bus when driving on a two-lane road, regardless of which direction they are traveling.

questions.question: After passing a vehicle, it is safe to return to your driving lane when:
questions.answerA: The driver you passed signals for you to return to your lane.
questions.answerB: You signal your intention for three seconds.
questions.answerC: You see the headlights of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror.
questions.explanation: Before you return to your driving lane, be sure you are not dangerously close to the vehicle you have just passed. One way to do this is to look for the vehicle in your inside rearview mirror. When you can see both headlights in your rearview mirror, you may have enough room to return to your driving lane.

questions.question: Which lane must you be in before making a left turn from a one-way street?
questions.answerA: The lane nearest the left curb.
questions.answerB: The lane nearest the center of the street.
questions.answerC: The lane nearest the right curb.
questions.explanation: When making any turn, turn from the lane closest to the direction you wish to travel into the first available legal lane. If you are making a left turn from a one-way street, this means that you would make the turn from the lane nearest to the left curb.

questions.question: What color are pavement markings that separate traffic lanes moving in opposite direction?
questions.answerA: Yellow
questions.answerB: White
questions.answerC: Yellow and white
questions.explanation: Yellow lines are used in the center of the road to separate lanes of traffic moving in opposite directions.

questions.question: If an emergency vehicle with flashing lights is traveling in the area where you are driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up to avoid the emergency vehicle.
questions.answerB: Stop your vehicle immediately and prevent them from passing.
questions.answerC: Make every effort to give the emergency vehicle a clear path of travel.
questions.answerD: Signal to the emergency vehicle when it is clear for them to pass you.
questions.explanation: If an emergency vehicle with flashing lights is traveling in the area where you are driving, you must make every effort to give them a clear path of travel. If it is safe to do so, pull your vehicle to the side of the road to give the emergency vehicle an open pathway.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Sharp turn to the right.
questions.answerB: Double curve.
questions.answerC: Winding road.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the road ahead winds with a series of turns or curves.

questions.question: When used on roadways, bicycles are considered:
questions.answerA: Hazards.
questions.answerB: Vehicles.
questions.answerC: Dangerous.
questions.explanation: Bicycles are considered vehicles when used on roadways. Bicyclists and motorists are expected to follow the same rules of the road.

questions.question: When driving under low-visibility conditions due to fog, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn on your high beam headlights.
questions.answerB: Slow down and use your low beam headlights.
questions.answerC: Increase your speed so you do not cause an accident.
questions.explanation: When driving in fog, you should slow down and use your low beam lights. If the fog is so dense that you cannot see, pull off the road and wait for the fog to clear.

questions.question: Alcohol is the single greatest common factor in fatal motor vehicle crashes.
questions.answerA: True
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: Alcohol is the number one killer on American roadways. Alcohol affects a person’s vision and slows their reaction time, so it takes longer to act in an emergency. Alcohol affects a person’s driving even if they are below the level of illegal intoxication.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Lane ends.
questions.answerB: No right turn.
questions.answerC: Slippery when wet.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow and black. This sign tells drivers that a lane is ending and that they should prepare to allow traffic to merge safely.

questions.question: You have allowed the wheels of your vehicle to run off the edge of the pavement. What should you do first?
questions.answerA: Turn the front wheels slightly to the left to edge the car back onto the pavement.
questions.answerB: Hold the steering wheel firmly, release the gas pedal, and gently apply the brakes.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes and turn the front wheels sharply to the left.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle leaves the roadway, hold the steering wheel firmly, release the gas pedal, and gently apply the brakes. Wait until your speed has reduced, check the traffic, and look for a place to safely return to the roadway by merging back into traffic. Overcompensating by jerking the wheel to return to the roadway can cause you to lose control of your vehicle or may cause your car to go into other lanes of traffic.

questions.question: If you become stranded in a snowstorm, the best thing to do is to:
questions.answerA: Get out of the car and go for help.
questions.answerB: Lay down in your car and go to sleep.
questions.answerC: Walk into the road and get the attention of other drivers.
questions.answerD: Stay in the car, as you are most likely to be found when you stay in your vehicle.
questions.explanation: If you become stranded in a snowstorm, the best thing to do is stay in your car and wait for help. You are most likely to be found if you don't leave your vehicle. Additionally, it may be unsafe to walk around outside in a snowstorm.

questions.question: Drinking alcohol and driving is:
questions.answerA: A minor traffic safety problem.
questions.answerB: A serious traffic safety problem.
questions.answerC: Safe if you have only had a few drinks.
questions.answerD: Only dangerous to the driver who drinks.
questions.explanation: Driving while impaired or intoxicated is a serious traffic safety problem. Safe driving is not possible when you drink alcohol or take other drugs. Driving under the influence is dangerous both to you and to others on the road.

questions.question: How fast you drive does not affect the distance your vehicle travels after you brake to come to a stop.
questions.answerA: TRUE
questions.answerB: FALSE
questions.explanation: When driving in high-speed traffic, it is extremely important to stay well behind the vehicle in front of you. As your speed increases, the distance it will take for your vehicle to stop also increases.

questions.question: Backing your vehicle is:
questions.answerA: Always dangerous.
questions.answerB: Dangerous if you have a helper.
questions.answerC: Only dangerous in large vehicles.
questions.explanation: Backing up is always dangerous because it is hard to see behind your vehicle. Use extra caution when backing up.

questions.question: Excessive speed:
questions.answerA: Does not increase the chance of a crash.
questions.answerB: Increases your ability to react to a hazard.
questions.answerC: Often leads to high-risk decision-making.
questions.explanation: Excessive speed is one of the most common contributing factors to vehicle crashes. Excessive speed does not save time and often leads to high-risk decision-making.

questions.question: A driver that operates a vehicle on South Carolina roadways has already agreed to submit to a chemical test when requested by a law enforcement officer.
questions.answerA: True
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: South Carolina has an implied consent law. This means that by driving in the state, you give your consent to take a chemical test for intoxication, if called upon to do so.

questions.question: You are driving on a highway divided by two solid yellow lines. You may:
questions.answerA: Cross these lines only to make a left turn into or from an alley, private road, or driveway.
questions.answerB: Cross these lines to pass other vehicles, but only if there is no oncoming traffic.
questions.answerC: Cross these lines under no circumstances.
questions.answerD: Cross these lines only to make a U-turn.
questions.explanation: Double solid yellow lines are used to mark roadways where passing is prohibited from both directions. You may cross these lines only to make a left turn into or from an alley, private road, or driveway.

questions.question: On a freeway, you should look farther ahead than you would on a city street:
questions.answerA: In order to see potential hazards early.
questions.answerB: Because it takes a quarter of a mile to stop your vehicle completely.
questions.answerC: Because it helps you keep up with traffic.
questions.explanation: On the freeway, be ready for changes in traffic conditions. Watch for signals from other drivers. Expect merging vehicles at on-ramps and interchanges and be prepared for rapid changes in road conditions and traffic flow.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Stop.
questions.answerB: Side road.
questions.answerC: Two-way left turn.
questions.explanation: Eight-sided traffic signs warn drivers that they must stop and yield the appropriate right-of-way at an intersection. Drivers may proceed when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: Which is the most common cause of traffic crashes?
questions.answerA: New drivers
questions.answerB: Human error
questions.answerC: Bad weather
questions.explanation: Crashes often occur when one driver does not see another vehicle or when a driver does something unexpected. Communicate with other drivers on the road to help prevent traffic crashes.

questions.question: When you are backing up, it is usually best to:
questions.answerA: Steer with one hand while looking into the rearview mirror.
questions.answerB: Open the driver side door and look back.
questions.answerC: Steer with both hands while looking into the side view mirror.
questions.answerD: Steer with one hand while looking over your shoulder through the rear window.
questions.explanation: Turn your head to look behind you before and while backing up. Steer with one hand when backing up or when operating vehicle controls. You should keep both hands on the wheel at any other time.

questions.question: Which statement about making a right turn is true?
questions.answerA: You should swing wide to the left when making a right turn so you won't run over the curb.
questions.answerB: You may make a right turn at a red traffic light, unless a sign prohibits the turn.
questions.answerC: When making a right turn onto a four-lane roadway, finish the turn in the far left lane.
questions.explanation: After yielding to traffic and pedestrians, you may turn right when stopped at a steady red traffic signal, unless posted signs prohibit it. When making a right turn, you should stay close to the right edge of the roadway and turn into the lane nearest to your previous lane.

questions.question: It is unlawful to:
questions.answerA: Pass another vehicle in any marked no passing zone.
questions.answerB: Pass another vehicle over a railroad crossing.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: It is illegal to cross the centerline to pass when driving on hills, in curves, and in other locations where you cannot see ahead far enough to pass safely. You may not pass at street crossings, at railroad crossings, where signs indicate no passing zones, or where a solid yellow line is next to your lane. You may not pass when the vehicle in front of you has stopped for a pedestrian or when driving in work zones where passing would be hazardous.

questions.question: Two solid yellow lines on the pavement mean:
questions.answerA: Passing is allowed for drivers from both directions.
questions.answerB: Passing is not allowed.
questions.answerC: Passing is allowed if you are at the top a hill.
questions.answerD: Passing is allowed during daylight only.
questions.explanation: Yellow lines tell you that the traffic on the other side of the lines is moving in the opposite direction. You should never cross two solid yellow lines to pass from either direction.

questions.question: It is important to slow down:
questions.answerA: On narrow or winding roads.
questions.answerB: At intersections or railroad crossings.
questions.answerC: When the road is wet or slippery.
questions.explanation: You should always slow down when driving on narrow or winding roads, near intersections, near railroad crossings, on hills, in sharp or blind curves, where there are pedestrians or driving hazards, and when the roads are wet or slippery.

questions.question: When the driver behind you wants to pass, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up.
questions.answerB: Go the same speed.
questions.answerC: Slow down to allow room in front of your vehicle for the other driver to complete the pass easily.
questions.explanation: When the driver behind you wants to pass, you should slow down so that there is enough room in front of your vehicle for the other driver to complete their pass. This will allow them to complete the passing maneuver in less time and more easily.

questions.question: Crossbuck signs indicate:
questions.answerA: Railroad crossings.
questions.answerB: School zones.
questions.answerC: No passing zones.
questions.explanation: Crossbuck signs tell drivers to yield to trains at a railroad crossing. Drivers should not try to outdrive a train.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Slippery when wet.
questions.answerB: Watch for drunk drivers.
questions.answerC: Dangerous curve ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually diamond-shaped with black markings on a yellow background. They alert drivers to upcoming hazards. This sign warns drivers to be extra careful when the pavement is wet because the road may become slippery, making vehicles more difficult to control.

questions.question: When changing lanes, you can check your blind spot by:
questions.answerA: Using the inside rearview mirror.
questions.answerB: Turning your head and looking over your shoulder.
questions.answerC: Using your side mirror.
questions.explanation: Even if your vehicle is properly equipped with mirrors, there are blind spots that cannot be seen by using the mirrors. Before changing lanes, look over your shoulder to check these areas.

questions.question: When you are parallel parking, it is usually best to:
questions.answerA: Give a right signal on the approach, drive past the space and stop, then back into the space.
questions.answerB: Park your vehicle within 18 inches of the curb or edge of the road.
questions.answerC: Center your vehicle inside the space to give surrounding cars room to maneuver.
questions.explanation: When parallel parking, turn on your right signal and stop, pulling even with the car in front of where you want to park, then back into the space. Park within 18 inches of the curb or edge of the road. Be sure to center your car in the space to allow surrounding vehicles room to maneuver.

questions.question: Nighttime is the safest time for cyclists to ride their bikes.
questions.answerA: TRUE
questions.answerB: FALSE
questions.explanation: A bicycle is difficult to see in the dark, even when the cyclist is wearing a proper headlight and reflector. Both motorists and bicyclists should be especially alert when driving at night in order to prevent dangerous collisions.

questions.question: Large vehicles have blind spots that can extend up to 200 feet directly behind the vehicle.
questions.answerA: TRUE
questions.answerB: FALSE
questions.explanation: Large vehicles have blind spots that can extend up to 200 feet directly behind the vehicle. Do not tailgate a large vehicle as they will have no way of knowing that you are there.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true?
questions.answerA: Driving too slowly is not an unsafe practice.
questions.answerB: Driving too slowly on certain highways can be dangerous.
questions.answerC: The speed at which you drive a vehicle does not affect safety.
questions.explanation: Driving too slowly can be dangerous because it may cause drivers behind you to become frustrated and make dangerous moves to pass you. It is safest to drive with the flow of traffic, within the legal speed limit.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Continue at your current speed.
questions.answerB: You must stop ahead.
questions.answerC: Speeding is not allowed.
questions.answerD: There is a traffic signal ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is a traffic signal ahead.

questions.question: When approaching a traffic signal displaying a steady green arrow, drivers:
questions.answerA: Should merge into a lane in the direction of the arrow.
questions.answerB: Should slow to a stop, if it is safe to do so.
questions.answerC: May turn in the direction of the arrow after yielding to traffic and pedestrians already in the intersection.
questions.answerD: May drive straight through the intersection.
questions.explanation: A green arrow displayed on a traffic signal tells drivers that they may turn in the direction of the arrow. You must be in the proper lane for such a turn. Yield the right-of-way to vehicles and pedestrians already in the intersection.

questions.question: Which of the following about winter driving is not true?
questions.answerA: Winter is the most difficult driving season.
questions.answerB: Checking your vehicle's antifreeze and windshield washer fluid levels is especially important during the winter.
questions.answerC: Using cruise control in winter weather is a safe thing to do.
questions.answerD: It is best to use snow tires on your vehicle.
questions.explanation: You should not use cruise control on snow, in rain, in fog, or under similar hazardous conditions. Winter is the most difficult driving season and requires extra caution from drivers. It is important to consistently check your antifreeze and windshield washer fluid levels. Using snow tires can increase a vehicle's traction on the surface of slippery roads.

questions.question: If you park facing uphill on a street with a curb, set the parking brake and:
questions.answerA: Turn the wheels toward the curb.
questions.answerB: Turn the wheels away from the curb.
questions.answerC: Leave the wheels pointing straight.
questions.explanation: When parking facing uphill on a street with a curb, you should turn the front wheels away from the curb and toward the center of the street. The back of the front tire should rest against the curb.

questions.question: Where is it illegal to pass another vehicle?
questions.answerA: On a hill or curve
questions.answerB: At a street crossing or highway intersection
questions.answerC: At any railroad crossing
questions.explanation: It is illegal to cross the centerline to pass when driving on hills, in curves, and in other locations where you cannot see ahead far enough to pass safely. You may not pass at street crossings, at railroad crossings, where signs indicate no passing zones, or where a solid yellow line is next to your lane. You may not pass when the vehicle in front of you has stopped for a pedestrian or when driving in work zones where passing would be hazardous.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Left turn yield on green.
questions.answerB: One-way.
questions.answerC: Cattle crossing.
questions.explanation: Regulation signs regulate traffic speed and movement, displaying rules which drivers must obey. This regulation sign indicates that drivers turning left at a green light must yield to oncoming traffic and may complete the turn when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: If a crossing guard is directing traffic in a school zone, you must:
questions.answerA: Follow the directions given by the crossing guard.
questions.answerB: Copy what surrounding traffic is doing, despite the crossing guard's instructions.
questions.answerC: Assume the guard is not supposed to be directing traffic.
questions.answerD: Follow rules that would be in place if no children were present.
questions.explanation: Be prepared to reduce your speed and use caution when directed to do so by a sign, crossing guard, or law enforcement officer. Always drive with extra caution in a school zone.

questions.question: When passing another vehicle on a road with two lanes traveling in opposite directions, you should:
questions.answerA: Return to the driving lane when there's enough room between you and the vehicle you passed.
questions.answerB: Remain in the left lane if you intend to turn left.
questions.answerC: Return to the right side of the roadway immediately.
questions.explanation: When passing another vehicle on a two-lane roadway, you must return to the right side of the roadway when there is enough room between you and the vehicle you have passed.

questions.question: If you are driving and a tire suddenly goes flat, you should:
questions.answerA: Rapidly pump the brake pedal several times.
questions.answerB: Slow down gradually and not brake.
questions.answerC: Press down on the brake pedal as hard as you can.
questions.explanation: If a tire blows out or suddenly goes flat while you are driving, grip the steering wheel firmly and keep the vehicle aiming straight. Take your foot off the accelerator and do not brake. Allow the vehicle to slow by itself and use the brakes gently, but only if necessary. Pull off the road when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: You must yield to children playing in the streets.
questions.answerA: True
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: You are responsible for driving with extreme caution where children are present. Slow down near schools and playgrounds and in residential areas.

questions.question: You are driving on a busy street and your vehicle’s accelerator sticks open. You should:
questions.answerA: Blow your horn.
questions.answerB: Slam on your brakes.
questions.answerC: Turn on your four-way flashers.
questions.answerD: Turn off your ignition, taking care not to engage the steering wheel locking mechanism.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle’s accelerator sticks open, your vehicle will continue to maintain its speed or accelerate, even if you remove your foot from the gas pedal. Turn off the ignition, using care to move the ignition switch only far enough to stop the engine and not engage the steering wheel locking mechanism. Apply your brakes and move off the road to a safe area.

questions.question: Before turning left, it is important to:
questions.answerA: Sound your horn.
questions.answerB: Yield to oncoming vehicles.
questions.answerC: Swing to the right side of your lane.
questions.answerD: Wait until oncoming traffic has a red light.
questions.explanation: When turning left at a traffic signal, you must yield the right-of-way to pedestrians and oncoming traffic.

questions.question: The driver ahead of you stops at a crosswalk. What should you do?
questions.answerA: Cautiously pass the vehicle at 10 mph or slower.
questions.answerB: Stop, proceeding only when all the pedestrians have crossed.
questions.answerC: Change lanes, look carefully, and pass the stopped vehicle.
questions.explanation: You must not pass a vehicle that is stopped at a crosswalk. There may be pedestrians crossing the street that you cannot see. Instead, stop, proceeding only after all pedestrians have crossed.

questions.question: If you have a sudden tire blowout:
questions.answerA: Use the brakes lightly.
questions.answerB: Pump the brakes.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes firmly.
questions.explanation: If a tire suddenly goes flat while you are driving, hold the steering wheel tightly and keep the vehicle moving straight. Slow down gradually by taking your foot off the gas pedal and using the brakes lightly.

questions.question: A broken yellow line beside a solid yellow line indicates that:
questions.answerA: Passing is permitted from the lane next to the solid yellow line.
questions.answerB: Passing is not permitted from either direction.
questions.answerC: Passing is permitted from the lane next to the broken yellow line.
questions.explanation: A broken yellow line alongside a solid yellow line means that traffic in the lane next to the broken line may cross the line to pass, while traffic in the lane next to the solid line may not.

questions.question: A broken yellow centerline means that:
questions.answerA: Passing is not permitted.
questions.answerB: Passing on the right is permitted when the way ahead is clear.
questions.answerC: Passing on the left is permitted when the way ahead is clear.
questions.explanation: A broken yellow centerline means that a driver may cross the centerline to pass another vehicle on the left as long as there is no oncoming traffic. Drivers should never cross a solid yellow centerline in order to pass.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Watch for people crossing your path.
questions.answerB: No passing zone.
questions.answerC: Work zone ahead.
questions.explanation: This orange warning sign tells drivers that an area of roadwork is upcoming. When traveling through a work zone, stay alert for temporary traffic control devices.

questions.question: If you want to make a three-point turnabout and there is traffic approaching, you should:
questions.answerA: Begin the turnabout right away.
questions.answerB: Flash your headlights and begin the turnabout.
questions.answerC: Yield to oncoming traffic coming from all directions before performing the maneuver.
questions.explanation: When you make a three-point turn, all approaching traffic has the right-of-way. Only perform a turnabout when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: When sharing the road with a truck, it is important to remember that trucks generally:
questions.answerA: Require longer distances to stop than smaller vehicles do.
questions.answerB: Require less time to pass on a downgrade than smaller vehicles do.
questions.answerC: Require a smaller turning radius than smaller vehicles do.
questions.answerD: Require less time to pass on an incline than smaller vehicles do.
questions.explanation: Because of their size, trucks need longer distances to stop than smaller vehicles do.

questions.question: At a school crossing sign, you should:
questions.answerA: Always stop, whether there’s a stop sign or not.
questions.answerB: Watch for children and be ready to stop.
questions.answerC: Always sound your horn when you see children.
questions.answerD: Be ready to help children crossing the street.
questions.explanation: You must always yield to pedestrians who are in or about to enter a crosswalk. Be alert to pedestrians when driving across intersections or turning.

questions.question: You must yield to a pedestrian using a white cane or guide dog:
questions.answerA: Only when the guide dog is leading the person across the street.
questions.answerB: At all times.
questions.answerC: Only if a crossing guard is present.
questions.explanation: Pedestrians who use guide dogs or white canes (with or without a red tip) must be given the right-of-way at all times.

questions.question: If another driver cuts you off in traffic, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull next to the driver and yell at them.
questions.answerB: Let it go.
questions.answerC: Flash your high beams at the driver.
questions.answerD: Get back at the other driver by cutting them off.
questions.explanation: To avoid the dangers of road rage, you should never take it personally if another driver cuts you off in traffic. Just let it go and continue driving safely.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true?
questions.answerA: A sudden change in weather calls for a change in driving.
questions.answerB: You should slow down when driving in rain and fog.
questions.answerC: Be particularly aware of vehicles coming up behind you in inclement weather.
questions.explanation: If the weather changes suddenly, you will need to adjust your driving to adapt. Always slow down when driving in rainy or foggy conditions. Be especially aware of vehicles behind you that may be going too fast for conditions.

questions.question: Your tire blows out while you are driving. You should:
questions.answerA: Slam on your brakes.
questions.answerB: Hold your steering wheel tightly and slow to a stop.
questions.answerC: Keep driving normally.
questions.answerD: Turn on your emergency flashers and continue driving.
questions.explanation: If you experience a tire blowout, do not immediately apply the brakes. Grip the steering wheel firmly and steer to remain in your traffic lane. Reduce your speed gradually by releasing the accelerator and staying off the brakes. Once you are moving very slowly, apply the brakes lightly and pull off the road into a safe area.

questions.question: What might happen when alcohol is combined with another drug?
questions.answerA: The effects of the alcohol and the drug may both be increased.
questions.answerB: Nothing will happen.
questions.answerC: The effects of the alcohol and the drug may both be reduced.
questions.answerD: The effects of only the alcohol may be reduced.
questions.explanation: Consuming both alcohol and another drug may enhance the effects of both. For example, taking one drink when you are also using a cold remedy could affect you as if you have had several drinks.

questions.question: When passing another vehicle, you should return to your original lane when:
questions.answerA: You can see both headlights of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror.
questions.answerB: You have cleared the front bumper of the passed vehicle.
questions.answerC: You are 50 feet in front of the passed vehicle.
questions.explanation: When passing another vehicle, move back into your original lane only when you can see the passed vehicle’s headlights in your rearview mirror. This ensures that you will have enough room to safely pull back in front of the other vehicle.

questions.question: After you have passed a vehicle moving in the same direction, it is safe to move back into the right lane:
questions.answerA: After about three seconds.
questions.answerB: When you can no longer see the passed vehicle over your right shoulder.
questions.answerC: When you can see the entire front of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror.
questions.explanation: When passing, you should not return to your original lane until you can see both headlights of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror. Always check your blind spots before moving back into your original lane.

questions.question: If a motorist sees pedestrians in an upcoming crosswalk, they should:
questions.answerA: Continue ahead because motorists always have the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: Wait for the pedestrians to cross.
questions.answerC: Pull to the right and move behind the pedestrians.
questions.explanation: At a crosswalk, you should yield to any pedestrian. Continue driving when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: Double solid yellow line markings down the center of a road indicate that passing is:
questions.answerA: Allowed from both directions.
questions.answerB: Allowed only from your direction of travel.
questions.answerC: Not allowed from either direction.
questions.explanation: A double yellow centerline means that it is prohibited for traffic from either direction to cross the centerline to pass.

questions.question: When driving to an unfamiliar area, you:
questions.answerA: Should depend on road signs to find your way.
questions.answerB: Should plan your trip in advance.
questions.answerC: Only have to know generally where your destination is.
questions.answerD: Should always choose the most direct route.
questions.explanation: When driving to an unfamiliar area, plan your trip in advance. Don’t start with only a hazy idea of where you are going. If your destination is in an unfamiliar area, check the location on a map before you start to drive.

questions.question: The first thing that alcohol effects is:
questions.answerA: Vision.
questions.answerB: Judgment.
questions.answerC: Balance.
questions.explanation: Alcohol reduces all of the important abilities you need to drive safely. Alcohol goes from your stomach to your blood, then from your blood to all other parts of your body. Alcohol affects the areas of your brain that control judgment and skill.

questions.question: Drive below the posted speed limit when:
questions.answerA: Anything makes conditions less than perfect.
questions.answerB: You see a police car.
questions.answerC: Entering a highway where there are other cars.
questions.answerD: You are on a four-lane road.
questions.explanation: When the road is wet or slippery, when you cannot see well, or when anything else makes conditions less than perfect, drive below the posted speed limit. Even if you are driving within the posted speed limit, you can still be ticketed for driving too fast for conditions.

questions.question: If you experience a tire blowout:
questions.answerA: Take your foot of the gas.
questions.answerB: Do not immediately use your brakes.
questions.answerC: Gradually slow down and pull off the side of the road.
questions.explanation: If you experience a tire blowout, take your foot off the gas pedal and do not immediately apply the brakes. Gradually slow down before gently applying the brakes and pulling off the side of the road.

questions.question: Anything that requires you to ____ could cause you to crash.
questions.answerA: Take your eyes off the road
questions.answerB: Take your hands off the wheel
questions.answerC: Take your attention away from the task of driving
questions.explanation: Anything that causes you to take your attention away from driving, take your eyes off the road, and/or take your hands off the wheel is a distraction.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about driving on a wet roadway?
questions.answerA: As you drive faster, your tires become less effective.
questions.answerB: Water does not affect cars with good tires.
questions.answerC: Deep water is less dangerous than shallow water.
questions.answerD: As you decrease your speed, the roadway becomes more slippery.
questions.explanation: The faster you drive on a wet roadway, the less effective your tires will be at wiping the water from the road. If your speed becomes excessive enough, your tires will lose their grip on the road entirely and you will begin to hydroplane (that is, to slide down the road on a film of water).

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Pedestrian crossing.
questions.answerB: Side road.
questions.answerC: Railroad ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is a pedestrian crosswalk.

questions.question: The maximum speed limit when driving in a rural area is ____, unless a higher limit is allowed by federal law.
questions.answerA: 40 mph
questions.answerB: 55 mph
questions.answerC: 60 mph
questions.explanation: In rural areas, the maximum speed limit is 55 miles per hour, unless a higher limit is allowed by federal law. In urban districts or residential areas, the maximum speed limit is 30 miles per hour.

questions.question: This sign tells you that:
questions.answerA: No turns are allowed on this road.
questions.answerB: The road narrows ahead.
questions.answerC: There are a series of curves ahead.
questions.answerD: The road may be slippery when wet.
questions.explanation: This sign warns of an upcoming winding road with three or more curves.

questions.question: If you are stopped by a police officer, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull over to the right side of the road.
questions.answerB: Stop your vehicle as far away from traffic as possible.
questions.answerC: Turn off your engine, radio, and any other device that may interfere with hearing the officer.
questions.explanation: If you are stopped by a police officer, pull over to the right side of the road and stop your vehicle as far from traffic as possible. Turn off the engine, the radio, and any other devices that may interfere with your communication with the officer.

questions.question: At a railroad crossing, you must:
questions.answerA: Watch for vehicles that must stop at all railroad crossings (school buses, trucks carrying hazardous materials, etc.).
questions.answerB: Watch for multiple trains.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: You must approach all railroad crossings with extreme caution and cross only when you know that no train is coming from either direction. Be aware of vehicles that must stop at all railroad crossings, such as school buses and trucks carrying hazardous materials.

questions.question: When parking next to a curb, you should use your turn signals:
questions.answerA: Only when pulling away from the curb.
questions.answerB: When pulling next to, but not away from, the curb.
questions.answerC: When pulling next to or away from the curb.
questions.explanation: Drivers should signal when pulling next to a curb or away from a curb.

questions.question: When your wheels run off the pavement, you should:
questions.answerA: Hit the breaks hard.
questions.answerB: Grip the steering wheel firmly, begin to slow down, then move slowly back onto the road surface.
questions.answerC: Hit the brakes firmly and jerk the steering wheel hard to pull the vehicle onto the road surface as quickly as possible.
questions.explanation: If one or more of your wheels run off of the pavement, grip the steering wheel firmly and slow down by taking your foot off the accelerator. Do not attempt to cut back sharply onto the pavement. Instead, look to see that the road is clear, then move slowly back onto the highway.

questions.question: If you approach a flashing red traffic light, you:
questions.answerA: Are traveling in the wrong direction.
questions.answerB: Must treat the intersection as if it is controlled by a stop sign.
questions.answerC: May not proceed until it changes to green.
questions.explanation: Treat a flashing red light the same as a stop sign. Come to a complete stop at the stop line or, if there is no stop line, prior to the crosswalk and before entering the intersection. Yield to all other traffic and pedestrians.

questions.question: Driving more slowly than surrounding traffic is:
questions.answerA: A good idea if the weather is bad.
questions.answerB: Appropriate if you don’t know the speed limit.
questions.answerC: Often a hazard because other drivers may become frustrated and try to pass you.
questions.explanation: Driving more slowly than other traffic can be dangerous. Drivers behind you may become impatient and will be tempted to take dangerous risks to pass you.

questions.question: You are approaching a railroad crossing that has no visible gates or flashing lights, but has a standard crossbuck. You should:
questions.answerA: Approach all tracks with extreme caution and cross only when you know that there is no train coming.
questions.answerB: Turn your radio down to hear if there may be an approaching train.
questions.answerC: Only continue once cleared to do so by a flagger, if applicable.
questions.explanation: You must approach all railroad crossings with extreme caution and cross only when you know that no train is coming from either direction. If there is a flagger at a crossing, you must obey all of their instructions.

questions.question: Tailgating other drivers (driving too closely to their rear bumper):
questions.answerA: Can frustrate other drivers and make them angry.
questions.answerB: Cannot result in a traffic citation.
questions.answerC: Reduces collisions by preventing being "cut off."
questions.explanation: Tailgating is a common behavior that can lead to aggressive driving, and so it should be avoided. Drivers may face legal consequences for driving unsafely.

questions.question: A broken yellow line down the center of a road indicates that:
questions.answerA: A construction zone is ahead.
questions.answerB: Passing is not permitted from either direction.
questions.answerC: Passing is permitted from either direction.
questions.explanation: When broken yellow lines separate the lanes of traffic on a two-lane roadway, any driver may pass when there is no oncoming traffic.

questions.question: If oncoming headlights are blinding you while you are driving at night, you should:
questions.answerA: Look toward the right edge of the road.
questions.answerB: Switch your lights to high beams.
questions.answerC: Turn your lights on and off.
questions.explanation: If the headlights of an oncoming vehicle are blinding, glance toward the right edge of the road instead of looking directly ahead. This should keep your vehicle safely on the road until you pass the oncoming vehicle.

questions.question: You may drive around the gates at a railroad crossing:
questions.answerA: When the train has passed.
questions.answerB: Under no circumstances.
questions.answerC: When the lights have stopped flashing.
questions.answerD: When other drivers drive around the gates.
questions.explanation: You are required to stop at all railroad crossings when signals warn of an approaching train. These signals may include flashing red lights, a lowered crossing gate, a flagger signaling, or a train’s audible signal of warning. Do not attempt to go around a lowered gate.

questions.question: You must yield for emergency vehicles:
questions.answerA: Under no circumstances.
questions.answerB: When you see a flashing red or blue light or hear a siren.
questions.answerC: Only when other vehicles yield.
questions.explanation: You must yield the right-of-way to any emergency vehicle that is using its siren or flashing lights.

questions.question: You are driving when it starts to sleet or snow. You should:
questions.answerA: Keep your windshield and mirrors clear.
questions.answerB: Allow additional distance between your vehicle and the vehicles that you are following.
questions.answerC: Approach all vehicles with caution.
questions.explanation: In snowy weather, keep your windshield and mirrors clear. Increase your following distance when driving in wet and cold weather because a slippery road surface will increase the distance needed for your vehicle to stop.

questions.question: An inattentive driver is a driver who:
questions.answerA: Stares at objects off the roadway or daydreams while driving.
questions.answerB: Maintains eye contact during a conversation with a passenger while driving.
questions.answerC: Only watches the vehicle ahead of their vehicle.
questions.explanation: Do not become distracted by looking at passengers, attempting to find something in your vehicle, looking at reading material, sightseeing, or daydreaming while driving. Continue scanning the road, checking your mirrors, and looking at the instrument panel at regular intervals. Developing these safe habits will keep you attentive as a driver.

questions.question: You must not drive your vehicle at a speed greater than:
questions.answerA: The maximum speed limit.
questions.answerB: A speed that is faster than is reasonable and prudent.
questions.answerC: A speed that is safe for existing conditions.
questions.explanation: You must not drive at a speed that is faster than is reasonable and prudent. You must drive at a speed that is appropriate for the area where you are driving, the type and condition of surrounding traffic, the presence of pedestrians, the weather, the quality of the road, and light conditions. You must drive within legal speed limits.

questions.question: You may legally block an intersection:
questions.answerA: If you entered the intersection on the green light.
questions.answerB: During rush hour traffic.
questions.answerC: Under no circumstances.
questions.explanation: Even if the light is green, you may not enter an intersection unless you can get completely across before the light turns red. If you block the intersection, you can be cited.

questions.question: If your car begins to skid out of control, you should:
questions.answerA: Pump the brakes.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes lightly.
questions.answerC: Stay off the brakes.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle begins to skid, stay off the brakes. Continue to correct your steering until the vehicle is back under your control and moving safely down the road.

questions.question: You must stop at a railroad crossing when:
questions.answerA: Directed to do so by a flagger.
questions.answerB: It is controlled by a stop sign.
questions.answerC: Flashing red signals and gates are present and operating.
questions.explanation: You must stop at a railroad crossing when directed to do so by a flagger or stop sign. Stop when flashing red signals and gates are present and operating.

questions.question: As you near an intersection, the traffic light changes from green to yellow. Your best action is to:
questions.answerA: Speed up to beat the red light.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes sharply to stop.
questions.answerC: Be prepared to stop in the center of the intersection.
questions.answerD: Be prepared to stop before the intersection.
questions.explanation: A steady yellow traffic light indicates that the light will soon change to red. You should be prepared to stop for the red light, if it is safe to do so.

questions.question: Headlights must be used:
questions.answerA: After 6 p.m. and before 7 a.m.
questions.answerB: After 7 p.m. and before 8 a.m.
questions.answerC: After 8 p.m. and before 7 a.m. during daylight savings time.
questions.explanation: You must have your headlights turned on when driving from a half hour after sunset until a half hour before sunrise. Turn on your headlights when driving in lowered-visibility situations.

questions.question: It is illegal for a person 21 years of age or older to drive with a minimum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of:
questions.answerA: 0.05 percent.
questions.answerB: 0.08 percent.
questions.answerC: 0.02 percent.
questions.explanation: For drivers age 21 or older, it is illegal to operate a motor vehicle with a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.08 percent or higher. Driving while under the influence of alcohol is not only illegal, but dangerous.

questions.question: When taking medication before driving, the most important thing for you to do is to:
questions.answerA: Get behind the wheel before the medicine can take effect.
questions.answerB: Make several rest stops on your trip.
questions.answerC: Understand the effects of the medication and adjust your driving accordingly.
questions.answerD: Ask another person to ride with you.
questions.explanation: Many medications can produce side effects that may impair your driving skills. If you are taking any medications, be aware of their side effects and do not drive if they interfere with your ability to drive.

questions.question: Hydroplaning is usually caused by:
questions.answerA: Excessive stops.
questions.answerB: Sudden stops.
questions.answerC: Sudden turns.
questions.explanation: Your tires become less effective at clearing water from the road as you increase your speed. If you drive too fast, they may lose their grip entirely, leaving the vehicle sliding on a film of water. This is known as "hydroplaning."

questions.question: If a tire blows out, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brake and hold it.
questions.answerB: Hold the steering wheel tightly and use the brakes lightly.
questions.answerC: Pull over quickly.
questions.explanation: If a tire suddenly blows out while you are driving, hold the steering wheel tightly and keep the vehicle going straight.You should slow down gradually, taking your foot off the gas pedal and using the brakes lightly. Do not stop on the road if at all possible. Pull off the road in a safe place.

questions.question: If you are involved in an accident, you should:
questions.answerA: Remain near the scene of the accident and move your vehicle to the shoulder of the road, if possible.
questions.answerB: Report the accident to the police within one week.
questions.answerC: Go to the nearest telephone and call for help.
questions.explanation: If you are involved in an accident, you must stop your vehicle and move it from the roadway, provide aid to anyone who is injured, notify law enforcement as soon as possible (no matter who is at fault), exchange information with other drivers involved, and submit required reports to the DMV and to your insurance company.

questions.question: Many crashes are caused by:
questions.answerA: Drivers traveling too fast for conditions.
questions.answerB: Drivers consistently checking their mirrors and blind spots.
questions.answerC: Drivers yielding the right-of-way.
questions.answerD: Drivers maintaining a four-second following distance.
questions.explanation: Many crashes are caused by drivers who are driving too fast for conditions. Always drive within the legal speed limits and decrease your speed any time conditions are less than perfect.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
questions.answerA: Use your left foot to brake.
questions.answerB: Use your right foot for both braking and accelerating your vehicle.
questions.answerC: You should always brake abruptly to ensure stopping.
questions.explanation: Use your right foot for both braking and accelerating. You should apply the brakes gently with increasing pressure so that your vehicle stops gradually and smoothly.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Emergency vehicles ahead.
questions.answerB: Uncontrolled intersection ahead.
questions.answerC: Four-way stop ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that a traffic signal is ahead.

questions.question: Distracted driving is:
questions.answerA: Anything that causes evasive action while driving.
questions.answerB: Anything that takes your attention away from driving.
questions.answerC: Anything that causes you to pay more attention to driving.
questions.explanation: The term “distracted driving” refers to driving while anything takes your eyes, hands, or mind away from the task at hand. Distracted driving is the most common contributing factor to reported traffic collisions. Distractions of any sort cause drivers to miss key visual and audio cues needed to avoid a crash.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Slow-moving vehicle.
questions.answerB: Road construction/maintenance area.
questions.answerC: Traffic signal ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign is displayed on slow-moving vehicles.

questions.question: When approaching a traffic signal displaying a steady yellow arrow, drivers:
questions.answerA: Should merge into a lane in the direction of the arrow.
questions.answerB: Should slow to a stop, if it is safe to do so.
questions.answerC: May turn left after yielding to oncoming traffic and pedestrians.
questions.answerD: Have the right-of-way and may expect oncoming traffic to stop for them.
questions.explanation: A steady yellow arrow indicates that a red arrow is about to appear. Stop unless you are already within the intersection.

questions.question: To ensure that your physical condition does not cause you to drive in an unsafe manner, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep physically fit and have regular physical examinations.
questions.answerB: Know the effect of any medicine on your driving ability.
questions.answerC: Drive within your physical limitations.
questions.explanation: Your physical condition has an important bearing on your ability to drive safely. Drivers should be aware of their physical limitations and only drive if it is safe to do so.

questions.question: If you can see that the roadway up ahead is covered by heavy smoke, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn on your four-way flashers and continue.
questions.answerB: Reduce your speed, move as far to the right as possible, and stop off the roadway.
questions.answerC: Turn on your high beam headlights and continue.
questions.explanation: If you notice that the road ahead is covered by heavy smoke, reduce your speed immediately, drive as far as possible to the right, and stop off the roadway. Only then should you determine if it is safe for you to continue. Remember that certain kinds of smoke can irritate your eyes and lungs or even kill you.

questions.question: When arriving to an uncontrolled intersection at the same time as vehicles to your right and left, you should:
questions.answerA: Yield the right-of-way to the vehicle on your left.
questions.answerB: Yield the right-of-way to the vehicle on your right.
questions.answerC: Wait until there are no vehicles at the intersection before proceeding.
questions.explanation: If multiple vehicles arrive at the same time to an intersection that is not controlled by signs or signals, the driver on the right has the right-of-way. Drivers should then proceed in the order that they arrive to the intersection.

questions.question: In inclement weather, you should:
questions.answerA: Steer off the road.
questions.answerB: Drive in a low gear.
questions.answerC: Steer and brake smoothly.
questions.explanation: When driving during unfavorable weather conditions, avoid slamming on the brakes and making sharp, quick turns. These behaviors will make controlling your vehicle in inclement weather even more difficult.

questions.question: When a bicyclist is making a left turn:
questions.answerA: They may use the left lane.
questions.answerB: They may cut through all lanes.
questions.answerC: They may wait on the side of the road.
questions.explanation: You should expect to see bicyclists driving with traffic on the road. You should not be surprised to see a bicyclist using the left lane when turning.

questions.question: This sign is a warning that you are approaching:
questions.answerA: An intersection.
questions.answerB: A crosswalk.
questions.answerC: A railroad crossing.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that you are approaching a railroad crossing.

questions.question: A U-turn is not permitted:
questions.answerA: In a parking lot.
questions.answerB: On or near any curve or hill.
questions.answerC: On a straight roadway with a clear view for 500 feet in both directions.
questions.explanation: You must never turn around while on or near any curve or hill. You may not be able to see oncoming traffic or pedestrians and may cause a collision.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Flagger ahead.
questions.answerB: Turn left at the intersection.
questions.answerC: Last turn before a toll road.
questions.explanation: Orange is the standard color for work zone activity. If you see orange signs, cones, or barrels while driving, stay alert and be prepared for unexpected driving conditions. This sign alerts drivers to an upcoming flagger whose directions should be obeyed by all drivers.

questions.question: When a stop line is present at a stop sign, drivers must stop:
questions.answerA: At the line.
questions.answerB: On top of the line.
questions.answerC: Only if pedestrians are in the crosswalk.
questions.explanation: At an intersection with a stop line, you must stop before reaching the stop line or crosswalk. Proceed when the way is clear.

questions.question: When approaching a four-way stop, drivers must yield the right-of-way to all motorists who arrived before them.
questions.answerA: TRUE
questions.answerB: FALSE
questions.explanation: At a four-way stop, you must yield the right-of-way to drivers who arrived before you. Wait your turn to enter the intersection.

questions.question: Which of the following are factors commonly contributing to traffic crashes?
questions.answerA: Exceeding the posted speed limit and driving too fast for conditions or circumstances.
questions.answerB: Getting adequate rest and staying alert.
questions.answerC: Scanning the environment and staying focused on the driving task.
questions.explanation: Driving above the speed limit, driving too far below the speed limit, and driving too fast for conditions are all actions that commonly contribute to traffic accidents. Always drive with the general flow of traffic, within legal speed limits.

questions.question: You are approaching a railroad crossing and you do not see or hear a train. You must stop:
questions.answerA: If a stop sign is posted.
questions.answerB: If a crossing gate is lowered.
questions.answerC: If the crossing lights are flashing.
questions.explanation: You must always stop before crossing railroad tracks if flashing red lights are activated, a crossing gate is lowered, a stop sign is posted, a flagger signals you to stop, or a train is visible or so close to the crossing that it would be hazardous to continue driving. If you are unsure if a train is too close for you to safely cross the tracks, stop. Never race a train.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Turn right after making a complete stop.
questions.answerB: Right turns are not permitted.
questions.answerC: Left turns are permitted.
questions.explanation: Regulatory signs display laws that drivers must always obey. Right turns are not permitted where this sign is present.

questions.question: A broken yellow line beside a solid yellow line indicates that passing is:
questions.answerA: Permitted from the side next to the solid yellow line.
questions.answerB: Not permitted from either direction.
questions.answerC: Permitted from the side next to the broken yellow line.
questions.explanation: When the center of the road is marked by a solid yellow line beside a broken yellow line, passing is permitted from the side next to the broken line and prohibited from the side next to the solid line.

questions.question: If you park facing uphill where there is no curb, set the parking brake and:
questions.answerA: Turn your wheels toward the edge of the road.
questions.answerB: Turn your wheels away from the edge of the road.
questions.answerC: Keep your wheels facing straight.
questions.explanation: When parking uphill on a road that does not have a curb, your front wheels should be turned to the right (toward the edge of the road). This will ensure that the vehicle will roll off of the road if the brakes fail.

questions.question: You should never park a vehicle:
questions.answerA: Within 50 feet of a railroad crossing.
questions.answerB: Within 20 feet of a crosswalk.
questions.answerC: Within 30 feet of any flashing signal located on the side of a roadway.
questions.explanation: Locations where it is prohibited to park include within 50 feet of a railroad crossing; within 20 feet of a crosswalk at an intersection; and within 30 feet of a signal light, stop sign, or flashing beacon on the side of the roadway.

questions.question: When you are being tailgated:
questions.answerA: Move over to the right, if there is an open lane to your right.
questions.answerB: If there is not an open lane to your right, wait until the way is clear ahead and reduce your speed slowly to encourage the tailgater to drive around you.
questions.answerC: Never slow down abruptly.
questions.explanation: If you are being tailgated by another driver and there is a right lane, move over to the right. If there is no right lane, wait until the road ahead is clear and then reduce your speed slowly. This will encourage the tailgater to drive around you. Never slow down abruptly as this will only increase the risk of your vehicle being hit from behind.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Two-way traffic.
questions.answerB: Change in direction ahead.
questions.answerC: School zone and crossing.
questions.explanation: This sign informs drivers that they are leaving a divided roadway and approaching a two-way highway.

questions.question: It is unlawful to drive alongside a motorcycle in the same lane.
questions.answerA: True
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: You must never attempt to share a lane with a motorcyclist, even if it looks like there is enough room to do so. Motorcyclists need to have a full lane width to be able to maneuver safely.

questions.question: The amount of alcohol in the blood is referred to as:
questions.answerA: Implied consent (IC).
questions.answerB: Blood alcohol concentration (BAC).
questions.answerC: Rate of alcohol consumption (RAC).
questions.explanation: Blood alcohol concentration (BAC) is a measurement of the percentage of alcohol in the blood. The higher the BAC number, the more impaired a person is.

questions.question: If you find that the roadway ahead of you is flooded, you should:
questions.answerA: Slam on the brakes.
questions.answerB: Not drive through the flooded area. Turn around and find another route.
questions.answerC: Drive only in the center of the roadway.
questions.explanation: Never attempt to drive on a flooded road. Even if the water looks shallow, it may hide many kinds of hazards. If you encounter a flooded area, turn around and seek another route to your destination.

questions.question: If you see a cyclist in your lane ahead and wish to pass, you should:
questions.answerA: Treat the cyclist as any other driver you would pass.
questions.answerB: Lightly tap your horn to warn the cyclist.
questions.answerC: Wait until traffic is clear in the opposite lane and then change lanes to pass the cyclist.
questions.explanation: Bicycles on a roadway are considered to be vehicles and should be treated as such. A loud blast of your horn could startle a cyclist and cause an accident, so your horn should be used lightly only to get a cyclist's attention. Before passing a cyclist in a narrow traffic lane, wait until the traffic is clear in the opposite lane and then change lanes to pass the cyclist; do not attempt to squeeze past them.

questions.question: You are approaching an intersection when the traffic light changes from green to solid yellow. You should:
questions.answerA: Consider it the same as a caution sign and continue through the intersection.
questions.answerB: Stop immediately.
questions.answerC: Stop before entering the intersection, unless you are too close to stop safely.
questions.answerD: Speed up to get through the intersection before the red light appears.
questions.explanation: When approaching an intersection with a solid yellow traffic light, slow to a stop before entering the intersection, if it is safe to do so. If you can't stop safely, drive carefully through the intersection.

questions.question: What is a potential effect of taking a prescription drug while drinking alcohol?
questions.answerA: There will likely be no effect.
questions.answerB: It will make you more alert.
questions.answerC: It can make you unfit to drive.
questions.explanation: Legal medications, both prescription and over-the-counter, can impair your ability to drive. They can be particularly dangerous when used in combination with alcohol.

questions.question: Drivers are not required to stop upon meeting a stopped school bus when traveling in the opposite direction on a four-lane highway.
questions.answerA: True
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: You do not need to stop upon meeting a stopped school bus when you are traveling in the opposite direction on a roadway with at least four lanes. You should always exercise caution when driving near children.

questions.question: When a traffic signal light turns green, you should:
questions.answerA: Yield the right-of-way to pedestrians.
questions.answerB: Accelerate as quickly as possible.
questions.answerC: Back up slowly.
questions.answerD: Not move until another driver waves you on.
questions.explanation: A green light tells you that you can go through the intersection. However, you must first yield the right-of-way to traffic and pedestrians who are still in the intersection.

questions.question: You are approaching an intersection with a steady yellow traffic light. If you have not already entered the intersection, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up to beat the red light.
questions.answerB: Reduce you speed and proceed carefully through the intersection.
questions.answerC: Come to a safe stop.
questions.explanation: When a steady yellow light appears on a traffic signal, you should prepare to stop. If you are already within the intersection, you should clear the intersection as quickly as possible.

questions.question: Which statement about right-of-way laws is true?
questions.answerA: If two vehicles begin to enter an intersection at the same time, the vehicle on the left has the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: When turning left at an intersection, you may turn before oncoming traffic passes.
questions.answerC: You may make a right turn in front of a crossing pedestrian.
questions.answerD: You should never demand the right-of-way.
questions.explanation: You should never demand the right-of-way. Laws do not specify who has the right-of-way, only who does not. At a four-way stop, if multiple drivers arrive at once, the driver on the left should yield the right-of-way to the driver on the right. Drivers should yield to oncoming traffic and pedestrians when turning right or left.

questions.question: Which of the following commonly causes traffic accidents?
questions.answerA: Inattentive driving
questions.answerB: Excessive speed under the driving conditions
questions.answerC: Following other vehicles too closely
questions.explanation: Driving too fast for conditions is a major cause of motor vehicle crashes. Being inattentive to surroundings can cause a driver to collide with other vehicles. Most rear-end collisions are caused by drivers following other vehicles too closely.

questions.question: You may not park:
questions.answerA: On a hill.
questions.answerB: In a parking lot.
questions.answerC: On a crosswalk or in a marked bicycle lane.
questions.answerD: Within 12 inches of the right side of the road.
questions.explanation: There are a number of locations where it is unlawful to park, including on a crosswalk or in a marked bicycle lane. When parking on the street, you must be within 12 inches of the side of the road.

questions.question: Temporary signs used in construction and maintenance work areas:
questions.answerA: Have a red background with green writing.
questions.answerB: Have an orange background with black writing.
questions.answerC: Have a yellow background with blue writing.
questions.explanation: All temporary signs in work zones have orange backgrounds with black writing and/or symbols.

questions.question: If someone has consumed alcoholic drinks, what will help the person overcome the influence of those drinks?
questions.answerA: Tomato juice and lime
questions.answerB: Hot coffee
questions.answerC: Fresh air
questions.explanation: Only the passage of time will allow a person to overcome the influence of alcohol.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Drive with caution and be ready to stop.
questions.answerB: You must come to a complete stop.
questions.answerC: Stop, if necessary.
questions.explanation: The stop sign is the only eight-sided sign you will see on any roadway. When you encounter a stop sign, you must come to a complete stop. You may not proceed until the way is clear for you to completely and safely pass through the intersection.
