questions.question: Drivers may pass on a two-lane roadway marked with a single solid yellow line on their side of the centerline.
questions.answerA: True
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: When there is a solid and a broken yellow line separating two lanes of traffic moving in opposite directions, a driver may pass only when the broken yellow line is nearest to the driver’s lane.

questions.question: Which of the following driving skills are affected by the use of alcohol and/or drugs?
questions.answerA: Alertness and concentration.
questions.answerB: Reaction time and coordination.
questions.answerC: All of the above.
questions.explanation: Any amount of alcohol acts as a depressant, slowing the function of the nervous system. It will reduce a person's alertness and ability to concentrate, increase their reaction time, and drastically reduce their coordination.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about railroad crossings is true?
questions.answerA: It is against the law to go around lowered gates at a crossing.
questions.answerB: You must stop at a railroad crossing when directed to do so by a flagger.
questions.answerC: Not all railroad crossings are equipped with flashing red signals and gates.
questions.explanation: You must stop at a railroad crossing when directed to do so by a flagger, stop sign, or warning devices, such as gates or flashing lights. Not all railroad crossings are equipped with such devices. It is against the law to drive around lowered railroad crossing gates.

questions.question: You are required to stop your vehicle:
questions.answerA: At any intersection where a police officer orders you to stop.
questions.answerB: Where there is a red traffic light.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: You must come to a complete stop at a steady or flashing red traffic light. You must always obey instructions given by officers directing traffic, regardless of any posted signs or traffic signals.

questions.question: Alcohol is:
questions.answerA: A stimulant.
questions.answerB: An antihistamine.
questions.answerC: A depressant.
questions.explanation: Alcohol is a depressant that dulls your judgment and makes your reflexes unreliable.

questions.question: You are driving on a road with two or more lanes traveling in the same direction. You should:
questions.answerA: Drive in any lane.
questions.answerB: Drive in the left lane, except to pass.
questions.answerC: Drive in the right lane, except to pass.
questions.explanation: On a multilane highway, slower traffic should travel in the right lane. Use the left lane to pass slower-moving traffic.

questions.question: When getting ready to change lanes, you should:
questions.answerA: Check your side view mirror.
questions.answerB: Check your rearview mirror.
questions.answerC: Quickly turn your head to check for other vehicles.
questions.explanation: Before changing lanes, check your side and rearview mirrors for traffic approaching you from behind. Just before you begin moving into the other lane, quickly glance over your shoulder and check for any vehicles that may be in your blind spot.

questions.question: Motorists are not required to yield to pedestrians when they walk against a traffic light.
questions.answerA: True
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: Drivers should always be willing to give a pedestrian the right-of-way, regardless of whether or not they are legally entitled to it. Always yield the right-of-way to pedestrians, motor vehicles, bicyclists, or anyone else who has moved into an intersection before you.

questions.question: If moving with a stream of vehicles across a railroad track, it is safe to stop on the track for a short period of time.
questions.answerA: True
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: It is prohibited to stop, stand, or park on a railroad track. You should never cross railroad tracks unless there is room for your entire vehicle on the other side of tracks.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Hospital.
questions.answerB: Upcoming intersection.
questions.answerC: Railroad crossing.
questions.explanation: Warning signs provide notice to road users of a situation that might not be readily apparent and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers of an upcoming intersection so they may prepare for potential traffic or prepare to turn.

questions.question: Distracted driving may be caused by:
questions.answerA: Eating, drinking, or smoking.
questions.answerB: Talking or texting on a cellular phone.
questions.answerC: Changing a radio station or CD.
questions.explanation: It is estimated that drivers make 200 decisions for every mile traveled, making it vital that drivers focus their full attention on the task of driving. Performing any additional task can create a dangerous distraction.

questions.question: Water on the road can cause a vehicle to hydroplane. Your car may hydroplane at speeds as low as:
questions.answerA: 45 miles per hour.
questions.answerB: 35 miles per hour.
questions.answerC: 40 miles per hour.
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning occurs when there is standing water on a roadway. At speeds up to 35 mph, most tires will channel water away from the tire. As your speed increases past 35 mph, tires cannot channel the water as well and your tires may start to lose contact with the road and ride over the water like a set of water skis.

questions.question: A steady green light at an intersection means that you:
questions.answerA: Must slow down and prepare to stop.
questions.answerB: Must stop and check for oncoming traffic before proceeding.
questions.answerC: May drive through the intersection if the road is clear.
questions.explanation: A steady green light means you may drive through the intersection if the road is clear. You may also turn right or left on a steady green light unless a sign prohibits the turn. When turning, you must yield to other vehicles and pedestrians within the intersection.

questions.question: Where is parking prohibited?
questions.answerA: Within 45 feet of a fire hydrant
questions.answerB: On a sidewalk
questions.answerC: Within 100 feet of a driveway
questions.explanation: There are a number of locations where parking is prohibited. These locations include on a sidewalk, within 15 feet of a fire hydrant, and in front of a driveway (or near enough to a driveway to interfere with others' abilities to use it).

questions.question: When changing lanes, you should never:
questions.answerA: Look over your shoulder to check your blind spot.
questions.answerB: Change lanes abruptly or spontaneously.
questions.answerC: Check for other vehicles moving into the same lane.
questions.explanation: When changing lanes, you must be sure that there are no vehicles in the space you want to enter. Check for other vehicles behind and to the side of your vehicle by checking your mirrors and blind spots. Always use the proper turn signal before changing lanes to allow surrounding vehicles time to react to your movements.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Slow down if an emergency vehicle is approaching.
questions.answerB: Look both ways as you cross the intersection.
questions.answerC: Always come to a full stop at the intersection.
questions.answerD: Slow down and be prepared to stop if necessary.
questions.explanation: Decrease your speed as you approach an intersection with a yield sign. Prepare to stop and yield the right-of-way to vehicles and pedestrians in the intersection or crossroad. You must come to a full stop at a yield sign if traffic conditions require it.

questions.question: You may be able to identify an aggressive driver by:
questions.answerA: Their erratic and improper lane changes.
questions.answerB: The number of passengers in their car.
questions.answerC: Their tendency to drive slowly.
questions.explanation: While driving, you should remain aware of the actions of surrounding drivers. If you notice an aggressive driver nearby making erratic or improper lane changes, you should not challenge them. The safest way to handle an aggressive driver is to get out of their way.

questions.question: When parking uphill on a hill or incline with a curb:
questions.answerA: Turn your front wheels sharply toward the curb.
questions.answerB: Turn your front wheels slightly to the right.
questions.answerC: Turn your front wheels sharply away from the curb.
questions.explanation: To keep your vehicle from rolling into traffic when parked facing uphill, turn your front wheels sharply away from the curb. If you are parking uphill on a street that has no curb, turn the wheels sharply toward the edge of the road.

questions.question: If another car is in danger of hitting you, you should:
questions.answerA: Sound your horn.
questions.answerB: Wave your arms.
questions.answerC: Use your emergency lights.
questions.explanation: Your horn should be used to warn other drivers or pedestrians in situations where they may not see you. For example, if you think another driver is about to hit you, you should sound your horn.

questions.question: Drivers must be careful when passing large vehicles and should avoid driving beside large vehicles for long periods of time.
questions.answerA: TRUE
questions.answerB: FALSE
questions.explanation: Because large vehicles have large blind spots on both sides, you should avoid driving beside a large vehicle for a long period of time. It is safest for you to either drop back or move forward when you find yourself directly next to a large vehicle.

questions.question: A yellow light that flashes on and off means:
questions.answerA: Stop and look for other vehicles, then go if there is no traffic.
questions.answerB: Stop and wait for a green light.
questions.answerC: Speed up to clear the intersection quickly.
questions.answerD: Slow down and proceed with caution.
questions.explanation: A flashing yellow traffic light means drivers should slow down and proceed with caution.

questions.question: You should not make sudden stops in front of large trucks and buses because:
questions.answerA: Small vehicle drivers cannot adequately see large trucks and buses in their rearview mirrors.
questions.answerB: Large trucks and buses, due to their size and weight, require longer distances to stop than smaller passenger vehicles.
questions.answerC: Large trucks and buses travel at a higher speeds than small vehicles.
questions.explanation: Large vehicles require longer distances to stop and accelerate than smaller vehicles do. Making a sudden stop in front of a large vehicle is dangerous because the other driver may not be able to stop in time to avoid a collision.

questions.question: When driving on an interstate:
questions.answerA: Stop on the shoulder of the road if you are tired.
questions.answerB: You should always use cruise control.
questions.answerC: Signal, check mirrors, and check blind spots before changing lanes.
questions.explanation: Signal, check your mirrors, and check your blind spot before changing lanes or passing on an interstate. Only stop on the shoulder of the interstate in the case of an emergency and change lanes as infrequently as possible. Cruise control should not be used in heavy traffic or under poor weather conditions.

questions.question: A yellow and black diamond-shaped sign:
questions.answerA: Warns you about conditions on or near the road.
questions.answerB: Helps direct you to cities and towns ahead.
questions.answerC: Tells you about traffic laws and regulations.
questions.answerD: Tells you about road construction ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs, which tell you about conditions on or near the road ahead, are usually diamond-shaped with black symbols or words on a yellow background.

questions.question: A solid white line on the right edge of the highway slants in to the left. That shows that:
questions.answerA: There is an intersection just ahead.
questions.answerB: You are approaching a construction area.
questions.answerC: You will be required to turn left just ahead.
questions.explanation: A solid line along the side of the road indicates where its edge is, marking the boundary between the travel lane and the shoulder. If the edge line angles toward the center of the road, this means that the road is narrower ahead.

questions.question: When faced with an oncoming car to the left and a bicyclist to the right, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull onto the shoulder.
questions.answerB: Split the difference.
questions.answerC: Let the car pass and then pass the bike.
questions.explanation: When there is more than one potential hazard on the road, you should ensure that you only have to deal with one of them at a time. For example, when there is a bicyclist on the right that you want to pass and an oncoming car to the left, you should not try to squeeze between both at the same time. Instead, let the oncoming car pass, and then pass the bicyclist.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Winding road.
questions.answerB: No parking.
questions.answerC: Right lane closed.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers that they are approaching a winding road and that they should adjust their speed accordingly.

questions.question: When completing an emergency roadside stop, it is not necessary to put on your parking brake.
questions.answerA: True
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: Set your parking brake when making an emergency roadside stop. Turn on your emergency flashers to alert other drivers to your presence.

questions.question: If you are continually being passed on the right and the left while driving in the center lane of an expressway, you should:
questions.answerA: Stay in the center lane.
questions.answerB: Move to the lane on your right.
questions.answerC: Move to the lane on your left.
questions.explanation: If a road has four or more lanes with two-way traffic, drive in the right lanes unless you are passing or turning left. If you are on an interstate highway and are driving below the speed of the flow of traffic, use the right lane.

questions.question: When approaching a stop sign that is not marked by a crosswalk, drivers should stop their vehicles before entering the intersection.
questions.answerA: True
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: At a stop sign, you must come to a complete stop at the stop line, if there is one. If there is no stop line, you must make a complete stop before entering the crosswalk. If there is no crosswalk, you must stop before entering the intersection.

questions.question: At an intersection with a yield sign, you:
questions.answerA: Must yield the right-of-way to cross traffic that is close enough to cause conflict.
questions.answerB: Must yield to vehicles only on your right.
questions.answerC: Should slow down but never stop.
questions.explanation: When approaching a yield sign, drivers must give the right-of-way to traffic already in the lanes that they intend to enter or cross. Drivers should be prepared to stop when approaching a yield sign but may continue without stopping if there is no conflicting traffic.

questions.question: What are the colors of warning signs indicating upcoming hazards?
questions.answerA: Black letters or symbols on a white background
questions.answerB: Black letters or symbols on a yellow background
questions.answerC: White letters or symbols on a blue background
questions.answerD: White letters or symbols on a green background
questions.explanation: Warning signs that indicate approaching hazards are usually yellow with black lettering or symbols. Warning signs in work zones are orange with black lettering or symbols.

questions.question: You must obey instructions from school crossing guards:
questions.answerA: At all times.
questions.answerB: Only during school hours.
questions.answerC: Unless you do not see any children present.
questions.explanation: Drivers should be alert to the presence of crossing guards when near a school and must always obey their instructions.

questions.question: The act of turning your head and checking your blind spot before changing lanes, driving away from a curb, or merging your vehicle into traffic is:
questions.answerA: A bad driving habit.
questions.answerB: A good driving habit.
questions.answerC: Unnecessary.
questions.answerD: Not necessary if you use the rearview mirror.
questions.explanation: When changing lanes, it is important to check your blind spots. Do this by looking over your shoulder toward the next lane. Do not rely only on your mirrors.

questions.question: The maximum posted speed limit should be driven only:
questions.answerA: During the night.
questions.answerB: During the day.
questions.answerC: Under ideal conditions.
questions.explanation: The posted maximum speed limit is the fastest legal speed you can travel on a road under ideal conditions. It is safest to drive at the same speed as surrounding traffic, up to the maximum speed limit. Maintaining a safe speed at all times is a responsibility shared by all motorists.

questions.question: You should use your horn when:
questions.answerA: Another vehicle is in your way.
questions.answerB: It may help prevent a collision.
questions.answerC: Another driver makes a mistake.
questions.explanation: Only use your horn when it is necessary to avoid collisions. Do not use your horn if a driver or bicyclist is moving slowly and you want him or her to drive faster or get out of your way.

questions.question: Which of these statements is true about drugs and driving?
questions.answerA: Any prescription drug is safe to use if you don't feel drowsy.
questions.answerB: Even over-the-counter drugs can impair your driving.
questions.answerC: Only illegal drugs can impair your driving.
questions.explanation: Legal prescription and over-the-counter drugs can impair your ability to drive, including drugs taken for colds, hay fever, allergies, or to calm nerves or muscles. It is illegal to drive while under the influence of any drug that impairs your ability to drive safely; this law does not differentiate between illegal, prescription, or over-the-counter drugs.

questions.question: If you are driving so slowly that traffic is backing up behind you, you should:
questions.answerA: Decrease your speed.
questions.answerB: Pull off the right side of the road and let traffic pass.
questions.answerC: Not let the other cars pass your vehicle.
questions.explanation: Driving more slowly than the flow of traffic can be hazardous. If you are on a two-lane, two-way road and driving so slowly that traffic is backing up behind you, you are required to pull off the road and let the other vehicles pass. Only drive significantly under the speed limit when conditions require it.

questions.question: Which statement is true?
questions.answerA: You should put on your cruise control near a railroad crossing to maintain a constant speed.
questions.answerB: You must stop at a railroad crossing when directed to do so by a flagger or stop sign.
questions.answerC: You have the right-of-way at a railroad crossing and do not need to stop.
questions.explanation: You must stop at a railroad crossing when directed to do so by a flagger, stop sign, or warning signal. Use caution when driving near railroad tracks.

questions.question: Motorists are not required to yield to pedestrians when they walk against a traffic light.
questions.answerA: True
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: Drivers should always be willing to give a pedestrian the right-of-way, regardless of whether or not they are legally entitled to it. Always yield the right-of-way to pedestrians, motor vehicles, bicyclists, or anyone else who has moved into an intersection before you.

questions.question: Temporary signs used in construction and maintenance work areas:
questions.answerA: Have a red background with green writing.
questions.answerB: Have an orange background with black writing.
questions.answerC: Have a yellow background with blue writing.
questions.explanation: All temporary signs in work zones have orange backgrounds with black writing and/or symbols.

questions.question: The amount of space you need to cross traffic depends on the:
questions.answerA: Road conditions, weather conditions, and oncoming traffic.
questions.answerB: Presence of a stop sign.
questions.answerC: Use of your turn signals.
questions.explanation: The amount of space you need to cross traffic depends on the road conditions, weather conditions, and oncoming traffic.

questions.question: When you hear the siren or see the flashing lights of an approaching emergency vehicle, you must:
questions.answerA: Slow down until it passes you.
questions.answerB: Drive to the right side of the road and stop.
questions.answerC: Motion for the emergency vehicle to pass you.
questions.answerD: Merge into the right lane and continue driving.
questions.explanation: Yield the right-of-way to any approaching emergency vehicle that is using its flashing lights or siren, regardless of its direction of travel. You must immediately drive to the right side of the road and stop until the emergency vehicle has passed. If you are within an intersection, pass through the intersection before coming to a stop on the right side of the road.

questions.question: An octagonal sign is always a:
questions.answerA: Speed limit sign.
questions.answerB: Stop sign.
questions.answerC: Hospital sign.
questions.explanation: Octagonal signs are always stop signs. Come to a complete stop when approaching a red, eight-sided sign.

questions.question: When you are traveling in a work zone, you should:
questions.answerA: Watch for cones, barrels, signs, large vehicles, and workers.
questions.answerB: Slow down and obey the posted speed limit.
questions.answerC: Follow instructions given by flaggers and signs.
questions.explanation: In a work zone, keep an eye out for traffic control devices (such as cones, barrels, or signs), large construction vehicles, and workers. Slow down and obey the posted limit for the work zone. Obey any instructions given by a flagger and posted on signs.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Keep right.
questions.answerB: Low shoulder.
questions.answerC: No parking at any time.
questions.explanation: Regulation signs regulate traffic speed and movement, displaying rules which drivers must obey. This regulation sign indicates that drivers should keep right to avoid an upcoming potential driving hazard.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Bicycle crossing.
questions.answerB: Stop only if other cars are approaching.
questions.answerC: Bicycle store.
questions.explanation: This sign (with the arrow below) indicates the location of a bicycle crossing/path. Drive with caution around this sign because bicycles likely regularly cross or ride beside traffic in the area.

questions.question: Increase your following distance when:
questions.answerA: Driving behind a large vehicle that blocks your vision.
questions.answerB: Exiting an expressway.
questions.answerC: Following a motorcycle.
questions.explanation: You should increase your following distance when you are behind a large vehicle that blocks your vision, when driving in bad weather or heavy traffic, when exiting an expressway, when behind a motorcycle or bicycle, and if someone is tailgating you.

questions.question: To avoid glare from the headlights of an approaching car:
questions.answerA: Look briefly toward the right side of the road.
questions.answerB: Stay focused on the centerline on the road.
questions.answerC: Flash your high beams.
questions.explanation: You should avoid looking toward the bright lights of an oncoming vehicle by glancing toward the right side of the road. After looking briefly toward the side of the road, continue looking ahead to check on the position of the other vehicle.

questions.question: When sharing the road with cyclists, you should:
questions.answerA: Regard the bicycles as vehicles on the road.
questions.answerB: Be extra careful when driving near the cyclists.
questions.answerC: Leave ample room when turning after passing a cyclist.
questions.explanation: Bicycles on the roadway are considered vehicles with the same rights and responsibilities as motor vehicles. You must be careful when driving near cyclists and should maintain a safe operating distance between the bicycles and your vehicle. Allow ample room when turning after you pass a cyclist so the cyclist is not cut off when you slow for the turn.

questions.question: You are coming to an intersection with a flashing red light. You should:
questions.answerA: Slow down and yield the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: Slow down and drive carefully through the intersection.
questions.answerC: Come to a complete stop, check the traffic, and go when it is safe to do so.
questions.explanation: A flashing red traffic light means the same thing as a stop sign. You must come to a complete stop, yield to other traffic and pedestrians, and then proceed when it safe to do so.

questions.question: A motorist must stop when approaching a stopped school bus unloading children on a two-lane road.
questions.answerA: True
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: You must stop for a school bus loading or unloading passengers if you are driving in either direction on a two-lane, two-way highway. You must also stop when approaching the bus from behind on a four-lane highway.

questions.question: The “No zone” is:
questions.answerA: A term used to describe blind spots around a truck or bus.
questions.answerB: A special speed zone.
questions.answerC: A roadway with restrictions on vehicle stereo volume.
questions.answerD: The television show that replaced The Twilight Zone.
questions.explanation: A truck or bus has blind spots on each side, in the rear, and in the front. An automobile cannot be seen in these blind spots. These blind spots are referred to as the “No zone.”

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: The road ahead turns sharply right, then left.
questions.answerB: The road ahead turns sharply left, then right.
questions.answerC: The road ahead curves to the left.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the road ahead will turn sharply to the right and then to the left.

questions.question: To let others know that you intend to turn, signal at least ____ feet from where you plan to turn.
questions.explanation: South Carolina law requires you to signal for at least 100 feet before beginning any kind of turn.

questions.question: When you see this sign, you must:
questions.answerA: Stop completely and check for pedestrians and cross traffic.
questions.answerB: Slow down without coming to a complete stop.
questions.answerC: Stop completely and wait for a green light.
questions.answerD: Slow down and check for traffic.
questions.explanation: Any eight-sided sign is a stop sign. At an intersection with a stop sign, you must stop completely and check for pedestrians and cross traffic in the intersection. Wait for the intersection to clear before proceeding.

questions.question: A broken yellow line beside a solid yellow line indicates that passing is:
questions.answerA: Permitted from the side next to the solid yellow line.
questions.answerB: Not permitted from either direction.
questions.answerC: Permitted from the side next to the broken yellow line.
questions.explanation: When the center of the road is marked by a solid yellow line beside a broken yellow line, passing is permitted from the side next to the broken line and prohibited from the side next to the solid line.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Yield.
questions.answerB: Crossroad ahead.
questions.answerC: Keep right.
questions.explanation: Traffic signs with three sides of equal length warn drivers to slow down when approaching an intersection and to be prepared to come to a complete stop to yield to other drivers or pedestrians. Drivers may proceed when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: To enter a gap in highway traffic:
questions.answerA: Watch only the vehicles behind the gap.
questions.answerB: Check behind you, then watch the vehicle ahead.
questions.answerC: Speed up and let the other vehicles make way.
questions.explanation: Whenever you want to change lanes or enter traffic, you must be sure that there are no vehicles in your way in the lane you want to enter. Always check for traffic to the side of and behind your vehicle before you change lanes.

questions.question: This red and white sign means you should:
questions.answerA: Stop and check for traffic coming from both directions before proceeding.
questions.answerB: Give the right-of-way to traffic on the road you wish to enter or cross.
questions.answerC: Maintain a steady speed and check for traffic coming from all directions.
questions.explanation: A three-sided yield sign indicates that you must slow down and be ready to stop, if necessary, to let any vehicle, bicyclist, or pedestrian pass before you proceed. In this case, you do not have the right-of-way.

questions.question: At an intersection with a yield sign, you:
questions.answerA: Must yield the right-of-way to cross traffic that is close enough to cause conflict.
questions.answerB: Must yield to vehicles only on your right.
questions.answerC: Should slow down but never stop.
questions.explanation: When approaching a yield sign, drivers must give the right-of-way to traffic already in the lanes that they intend to enter or cross. Drivers should be prepared to stop when approaching a yield sign but may continue without stopping if there is no conflicting traffic.

questions.question: You are preparing to exit the interstate. When should you start reducing your speed?
questions.answerA: About halfway through the deceleration lane.
questions.answerB: As you approach the deceleration lane.
questions.answerC: Immediately upon entering the deceleration lane.
questions.explanation: When leaving an interstate, you should maintain your speed until you enter the deceleration lane, at which point you should reduce your speed to the exit ramp's posted advisory speed.

questions.question: You are driving when it starts to sleet or snow. You should:
questions.answerA: Keep your windshield and mirrors clear.
questions.answerB: Allow additional distance between your vehicle and the vehicles that you are following.
questions.answerC: Approach all vehicles with caution.
questions.explanation: In snowy weather, keep your windshield and mirrors clear. Increase your following distance when driving in wet and cold weather because a slippery road surface will increase the distance needed for your vehicle to stop.

questions.question: Your vehicle's stopping distance increases when stopping:
questions.answerA: On a wet or icy road.
questions.answerB: On paved highways.
questions.answerC: When driving at night.
questions.explanation: Stopping distances increase on wet or icy roads. Stopping distances also increase on road surfaces covered in loose gravel or stones.

questions.question: When approaching a pedestrian using a white cane or guide dog, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop until the person is well away from the roadway.
questions.answerB: Honk your horn as you pass them.
questions.answerC: Carefully drive around them.
questions.explanation: South Carolina law gives special protection to blind pedestrians. If a person carrying a white cane or using a guide dog enters the street, all drivers must stop and yield to them.

questions.question: If your vehicle has a two-part safety belt system, you should:
questions.answerA: Use only the lap belt.
questions.answerB: Use both the lap and shoulder belts.
questions.answerC: Use only the shoulder belt.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle has a two-part seat belt system, be sure to wear both the lap belt and the shoulder belt. Wearing either part alone greatly reduces your protection. If you have an automatic shoulder belt, be sure to buckle your lap belt as well.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about blind spots is true?
questions.answerA: They are eliminated if you have one outside mirror on each side of the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Large trucks have bigger blind spots than most passenger vehicles.
questions.answerC: Blind spots can be checked by looking in your rearview mirrors.
questions.explanation: Blind spots are areas that a driver cannot see if they look in their mirrors. Large trucks have large blind spots that drivers of other vehicles should avoid.

questions.question: You should drive on the shoulder to pass a car:
questions.answerA: If the vehicle ahead of you is turning left.
questions.answerB: Under no circumstances.
questions.answerC: If the shoulder is wide enough.
questions.explanation: Passing on the right is permissible only if it is possible to do so without driving off the roadway. Never pass another vehicle on the shoulder because the other driver will not expect you to be there and may pull off the road.

questions.question: If you park facing uphill on a street with a curb, set the parking brake and:
questions.answerA: Turn the wheels toward the curb.
questions.answerB: Turn the wheels away from the curb.
questions.answerC: Leave the wheels pointing straight.
questions.explanation: When parking facing uphill on a street with a curb, you should turn the front wheels away from the curb and toward the center of the street. The back of the front tire should rest against the curb.

questions.question: It is unlawful to:
questions.answerA: Pass another vehicle in any marked no passing zone.
questions.answerB: Pass another vehicle over a railroad crossing.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: It is illegal to cross the centerline to pass when driving on hills, in curves, and in other locations where you cannot see ahead far enough to pass safely. You may not pass at street crossings, at railroad crossings, where signs indicate no passing zones, or where a solid yellow line is next to your lane. You may not pass when the vehicle in front of you has stopped for a pedestrian or when driving in work zones where passing would be hazardous.

questions.question: It is illegal for a person 21 years of age or older to drive with a minimum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of:
questions.answerA: 0.05 percent.
questions.answerB: 0.08 percent.
questions.answerC: 0.02 percent.
questions.explanation: For drivers age 21 or older, it is illegal to operate a motor vehicle with a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.08 percent or higher. Driving while under the influence of alcohol is not only illegal, but dangerous.

questions.question: Large vehicles have blind spots that can extend up to 200 feet directly behind the vehicle.
questions.answerA: TRUE
questions.answerB: FALSE
questions.explanation: Large vehicles have blind spots that can extend up to 200 feet directly behind the vehicle. Do not tailgate a large vehicle as they will have no way of knowing that you are there.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: School crossing.
questions.answerB: Pedestrian crossing.
questions.answerC: Jogging trail.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates the presence of a pedestrian crossing. You should watch for people entering a crosswalk or crossing your path. Slow down and be prepared to stop.

questions.question: A broken yellow centerline indicates that:
questions.answerA: Passing is not permitted.
questions.answerB: Passing on the right is permitted when the way ahead is clear.
questions.answerC: Passing on the left is permitted when the way ahead is clear.
questions.explanation: A broken yellow centerline next to your side of the road indicates that traffic may cross the centerline to pass from your side of the road.

questions.question: A driver need not stop for a stopped school bus when traveling in the opposite direction on a four-lane roadway.
questions.answerA: True
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: On a highway with four or more lanes, you must stop for a school bus loading or unloading passengers only when you are traveling behind it. You must still drive with special caution when driving near children.

questions.question: A solid yellow line next to a broken yellow line means that vehicles:
questions.answerA: Driving in both directions may pass.
questions.answerB: Next to the broken line may pass.
questions.answerC: Next to the solid line may pass.
questions.explanation: Yellow lines separate lanes of traffic moving in opposite directions. A broken yellow line next to your driving lane means that you may pass.

questions.question: Nighttime is the safest time for cyclists to ride their bikes.
questions.answerA: TRUE
questions.answerB: FALSE
questions.explanation: A bicycle is difficult to see in the dark, even when the cyclist is wearing a proper headlight and reflector. Both motorists and bicyclists should be especially alert when driving at night in order to prevent dangerous collisions.

questions.question: Which drivers are subject to the South Carolina Point System?
questions.answerA: Permit holders
questions.answerB: All drivers
questions.answerC: Intermediate drivers only
questions.explanation: A license to drive confers a privilege, not a right. You may keep this privilege only as long as you drive safely. Your license will be suspended if you accumulate 12 points for violations committed inside or outside of the state.

questions.question: When driving in fog, you should use your low beam headlights:
questions.answerA: TRUE
questions.answerB: FALSE
questions.explanation: You should always use your low beam headlights when driving in fog. High beam headlights may cause the light to reflect off of the fog and into your eyes.

questions.question: You should follow which of the following tips when being passed by another driver?
questions.answerA: Be on guard so that you can protect yourself from any unsafe actions performed by the other driver.
questions.answerB: Maintain your speed and position when being passed.
questions.answerC: If the passing car wants to return to your lane, allow them space.
questions.explanation: When a driver is passing you, be on guard so that you may protect yourself from any of the other driver's potentially unsafe actions. Maintain your speed and position, unless the other driver must return to your lane because of an oncoming car. Then slow down when they speed up, or speed up if they slow down.

questions.question: If you experience a tire blowout:
questions.answerA: Tap or pump the brakes.
questions.answerB: Slow down gradually and use your brakes lightly.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes firmly and quickly.
questions.explanation: If you experience a tire blowout, you should slow down gradually by taking your foot off of the accelerator. Don't apply the brakes until the vehicle has slowed considerably.

questions.question: Where is it illegal to pass another vehicle?
questions.answerA: On a hill or curve
questions.answerB: At a street crossing or highway intersection
questions.answerC: At any railroad crossing
questions.explanation: It is illegal to cross the centerline to pass when driving on hills, in curves, and in other locations where you cannot see ahead far enough to pass safely. You may not pass at street crossings, at railroad crossings, where signs indicate no passing zones, or where a solid yellow line is next to your lane. You may not pass when the vehicle in front of you has stopped for a pedestrian or when driving in work zones where passing would be hazardous.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: When pavement is wet, reduce your speed.
questions.answerB: The road ahead winds a series of turns or curves.
questions.answerC: Traffic increases ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that pavement is slippery when wet. In wet conditions, you should reduce your speed, avoid braking or changing direction suddenly, and increase the distance between your vehicle and the one ahead.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Curves ahead.
questions.answerB: Divided highway starts.
questions.answerC: Divided highway ends.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns that the divided highway ends ahead. Prepare to change lanes or shift lane position.

questions.question: When approaching an intersection with a flashing red light, you must:
questions.answerA: Come to a complete stop, yield to oncoming traffic and pedestrians, then proceed.
questions.answerB: Reduce your speed and proceed with caution.
questions.answerC: Come to a complete stop and remain stopped as long as the light is red.
questions.explanation: A flashing red traffic light means the same thing as a stop sign. When arriving at an intersection with a flashing red light, you must come to a full stop and proceed when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: If you are stopped by a police officer, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull over to the right side of the road.
questions.answerB: Stop your vehicle as far away from traffic as possible.
questions.answerC: Turn off your engine, radio, and any other device that may interfere with hearing the officer.
questions.explanation: If you are stopped by a police officer, pull over to the right side of the road and stop your vehicle as far from traffic as possible. Turn off the engine, the radio, and any other devices that may interfere with your communication with the officer.

questions.question: Signaling your intentions before turning, changing lanes, or driving away from a curb:
questions.answerA: Is necessary only if other traffic is present.
questions.answerB: Is a good driving habit and is required by law.
questions.answerC: Is necessary only during the maneuver, not before.
questions.answerD: Is not necessary if the maneuver is done slowly.
questions.explanation: When changing lanes or turning, signal your intentions well in advance. The law requires that you signal for at least 100 feet before you move your vehicle to the right or left. Before pulling away from a curb, always signal to inform passing drivers of your intentions.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: The highway ahead curves only to the right.
questions.answerB: The highway ahead turns sharply to the right.
questions.answerC: The highway ahead curves to the right and then to the left.
questions.answerD: The highway ahead curves to the left and then to the right.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are used to warn drivers about upcoming hazardous conditions and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers that the road ahead curves to the right and then to the left.

questions.question: When merging onto the freeway, you should be driving:
questions.answerA: At or near the speed of the freeway traffic.
questions.answerB: At the legal speed limit.
questions.answerC: More slowly than the freeway traffic.
questions.explanation: You should enter a freeway at or near the speed of traffic, unless the speed of traffic exceeds the legal speed limit.

questions.question: If you approach a traffic light with a red signal and a police officer directs you to go through the intersection without stopping, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop until the light turns green.
questions.answerB: Go through the intersection without stopping.
questions.answerC: Come to a complete stop before proceeding.
questions.explanation: Instructions given by police officers directing traffic always override posted traffic signals and signs. Follow the officer's instructions.

questions.question: The maximum speed limit when driving in a rural area is ____, unless a higher limit is allowed by federal law.
questions.answerA: 40 mph
questions.answerB: 55 mph
questions.answerC: 60 mph
questions.explanation: In rural areas, the maximum speed limit is 55 miles per hour, unless a higher limit is allowed by federal law. In urban districts or residential areas, the maximum speed limit is 30 miles per hour.

questions.question: An orange and red triangular sign on a vehicle always means:
questions.answerA: The vehicle has the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: Slow-moving vehicle.
questions.answerC: Shoulder work ahead.
questions.explanation: Slow-moving vehicles, such as farm tractors, road maintenance vehicles, and animal-drawn carts, display an orange and red triangle on the back.

questions.question: To avoid being in a truck or bus driver’s blind spot, you should:
questions.answerA: Never pass them.
questions.answerB: Avoid driving alongside them and avoid tailgating.
questions.answerC: Flash your lights at them.
questions.explanation: Because a large vehicle, such as a truck or bus, has large blind spots to its sides and rear, avoid driving alongside such a vehicle and do not tailgate one.

questions.question: What do speed limit signs indicate?
questions.answerA: Potential driving speeds for the area
questions.answerB: The maximum or minimum speed that is legally allowed to be driven
questions.answerC: The speed drivers should drive in heavy traffic
questions.answerD: The speed drivers should drive under poor conditions
questions.explanation: Speed limit signs indicate the maximum or minimum safe speed that is allowed to be driven on a roadway. The maximum limits are for ideal conditions and you must reduce your speed when conditions require it.

questions.question: Double solid yellow line markings down the center of a road indicate that passing is:
questions.answerA: Allowed from both directions.
questions.answerB: Allowed only from your direction of travel.
questions.answerC: Not allowed from either direction.
questions.explanation: A double yellow centerline means that it is prohibited for traffic from either direction to cross the centerline to pass.

questions.question: Who must wear seat belts in a moving vehicle?
questions.answerA: Only passengers on the driver's side of the car
questions.answerB: All passengers and not the driver
questions.answerC: All of the vehicle's occupants, including the driver
questions.explanation: The use of safety belts is required by law. Everyone in a moving vehicle must properly use their seat belt.

questions.question: This sign indicates that the road ahead:
questions.answerA: Turns sharply right, then left.
questions.answerB: Curves right, then left.
questions.answerC: Curves right.
questions.explanation: This sign warns of a reverse curve in which the road curves to the right, then to the left.

questions.question: After you have passed a vehicle moving in the same direction, it is safe to move back into the right lane:
questions.answerA: After about three seconds.
questions.answerB: When you can no longer see the passed vehicle over your right shoulder.
questions.answerC: When you can see the entire front of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror.
questions.explanation: When passing, you should not return to your original lane until you can see both headlights of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror. Always check your blind spots before moving back into your original lane.

questions.question: When a stop line is present at a stop sign, drivers must stop:
questions.answerA: At the line.
questions.answerB: On top of the line.
questions.answerC: Only if pedestrians are in the crosswalk.
questions.explanation: At an intersection with a stop line, you must stop before reaching the stop line or crosswalk. Proceed when the way is clear.

questions.question: Broken yellow lines are used on streets and highways to:
questions.answerA: Indicate no passing zones.
questions.answerB: Separate lanes of traffic moving in the same direction.
questions.answerC: Separate lanes of traffic moving in opposite directions.
questions.explanation: Yellow lines separate traffic moving in opposite directions. Dashed lines on the pavement indicate that passing is permitted when safe.

questions.question: If you see this sign above your lane, you:
questions.answerA: May not exit the freeway.
questions.answerB: May either continue through the interchange or exit the freeway from your current lane.
questions.answerC: May stay in your lane and continue through the interchange.
questions.answerD: Must exit the freeway, if you stay in your current lane.
questions.explanation: If a yellow panel with the message "Exit only" is on a highway sign, the lane below the sign will not continue through the interchange. Instead, the lane will go off of the roadway to form a ramp. If you are in a lane directly under an "Exit only" sign, you may change lanes to move through the interchange or you must exit the highway.

questions.question: You can help keep the driver behind you a safe distance away from your vehicle by:
questions.answerA: Driving 10 mph faster than the car behind you.
questions.answerB: Driving 10 mph slower than the car behind you.
questions.answerC: Maintaining a steady speed.
questions.explanation: It is not always easy to maintain a safe distance behind your vehicle. However, you can help keep the driver behind you a safe distance away from your vehicle by maintaining a steady speed and signaling turns, lane changes, and deceleration in advance.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: No left turn can be made here.
questions.answerB: A left turn can be made only after stopping.
questions.answerC: All traffic must turn right at the next intersection.
questions.explanation: Signs with a red circle and diagonal line over a black symbol indicate that the action represented by the symbol is prohibited. In this case, the sign indicates that left turns are prohibited.

questions.question: A solid yellow arrow on a traffic signal means:
questions.answerA: You should speed up so you can make the turn before the light changes.
questions.answerB: You do not need to signal to turn from the indicated lane.
questions.answerC: You should prepare to stop and yield the right-of-way to oncoming traffic.
questions.explanation: A solid yellow arrow means that the protection of a green arrow is ending. If you are turning in the direction of the arrow, you should prepare to stop and yield the right-of-way to oncoming traffic before turning.

questions.question: If a child is riding a bicycle near your vehicle:
questions.answerA: Beep your horn.
questions.answerB: Expect the child to be in total control of the bicycle.
questions.answerC: Expect the unexpected.
questions.explanation: Children on bicycles are sometimes unpredictable. Young bicyclists are especially likely to make surprising changes in direction. Remember that children and bicycles are both small in stature and may become difficult to see.

questions.question: Which of the following should you do after an accident?
questions.answerA: Protect the area, notify authorities, and care for the injured.
questions.answerB: Report the accident the following week.
questions.answerC: Go to the nearest convenience store and call your insurance company.
questions.explanation: If you are involved in an accident, you must stop your vehicle and move it from the roadway to the shoulder, provide aid to anyone who has been injured, protect the accident scene as much as possible, notify law enforcement as soon as possible, exchange information with other drivers involved, and submit any required forms to the DMV and your insurance company.

questions.question: Look over your shoulder to check your blind spot when:
questions.answerA: Pulling toward or away from a curb.
questions.answerB: Turning left or right.
questions.answerC: Changing lanes.
questions.explanation: Look over your shoulder to check your blind spot every time you want to change your vehicle's position. If you are turning, changing lanes, or pulling toward or away from a curb, you should check your blind spots.

questions.question: If your car starts to skid, turn your steering wheel:
questions.answerA: To keep the front wheels straight.
questions.answerB: In the direction you want the vehicle to go.
questions.answerC: In the opposite direction of the skid.
questions.answerD: In any direction. It doesn't matter.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle goes into a skid, you should turn the steering wheel in the direction you want the vehicle to go. As soon as the vehicle begins to straighten out, turn the steering wheel back the other way.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about railroad crossings is true?
questions.answerA: It is against the law to go around lowered gates at a crossing.
questions.answerB: You must stop at a railroad crossing when directed to do so by a flagger.
questions.answerC: Not all railroad crossings are equipped with flashing red signals and gates.
questions.explanation: You must stop at a railroad crossing when directed to do so by a flagger, stop sign, or warning devices, such as gates or flashing lights. Not all railroad crossings are equipped with such devices. It is against the law to drive around lowered railroad crossing gates.

questions.question: It is unlawful for a car to try to share a lane with a motorcycle.
questions.answerA: TRUE
questions.answerB: FALSE
questions.explanation: Motorcycle operators have the right to use a complete traffic lane. Two motorcyclists may share a lane, but a car should never try to share a lane with a motorcycle.

questions.question: When a school bus is stopped ahead on your side of the road with its red lights flashing, you must:
questions.answerA: Slow to a speed no faster than 10 mph.
questions.answerB: Stop until the lights stop flashing.
questions.answerC: Change lanes and pass cautiously.
questions.explanation: The flashing overhead lights and stop arm on a school bus will be activated when the bus is stopped to load or unload students. If approaching a bus using these signals, you may not proceed until the red lights have stopped flashing and the stop arm has been retracted. Never pass a school bus that is dropping off or picking up students.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: No right turn.
questions.answerB: You must turn right.
questions.answerC: Watch for traffic on your right.
questions.answerD: Don’t park on the right side of the street.
questions.explanation: A sign with a red circle and slash over a symbol indicates that the action represented by the symbol (in this example, a right turn) is not allowed.

questions.question: When approaching railroad tracks, you should:
questions.answerA: Look, listen, slow down, and be prepared to stop.
questions.answerB: Speed up to cross the tracks before the gate is lowered.
questions.answerC: Try to drive around a lowered gate.
questions.answerD: Not pay attention to how many tracks there are to cross.
questions.explanation: When approaching railroad tracks, you should look, listen, slow down, and be prepared to stop for trains or other vehicles that may be using the rails.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Cars in right lane must slow down.
questions.answerB: No left turn.
questions.answerC: Merge.
questions.answerD: Pass only in the right lane.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates a merge ahead. It warns that two lanes of traffic moving in the same direction are about to become one.

questions.question: When changing lanes, you should never:
questions.answerA: Cross the centerline in an intersection.
questions.answerB: Check your blind spots by looking over your left or right shoulder.
questions.answerC: Check for other drivers moving into the same lane.
questions.explanation: Before changing lanes, check for drivers trying to pass you who may be trying to enter the same lane as you. Look over your shoulder to check your blind spot. You should never attempt to pass or otherwise change lanes in an intersection.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about driving speed is true?
questions.answerA: As your speed increases, the chance of a fatality increases.
questions.answerB: As your speed increases, so should your following distance.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: As driving speeds increase, the chance of a fatality in the case of a collision increases. If you are going faster than 80 miles per hour, you have almost no chance of living through a crash. The speed you drive affects your stopping distance, so you should increase your following distance as you increase your speed.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Stop.
questions.answerB: Merge.
questions.answerC: Upcoming change in direction.
questions.explanation: An eight-sided red sign means "stop."

questions.question: When you see this sign, it means:
questions.answerA: There is an object on the roadway.
questions.answerB: Traffic is coming from the right.
questions.answerC: The road is curving sharply to the left.
questions.answerD: There is a merge point ahead.
questions.explanation: Chevron signs like this indicate that the road curves sharply in the direction indicated by the chevron (in this case, to the left). There may be several chevron signs placed throughout a curve.

questions.question: This sign is used to warn drivers that:
questions.answerA: The right lane is ending and traffic should merge left.
questions.answerB: The road curves ahead.
questions.answerC: There are upcoming intersections.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. They alert you to conditions that are immediately ahead. This sign warns drivers that the number of lanes is reduced ahead and that traffic should merge left.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Winding road ahead.
questions.answerB: Do not enter.
questions.answerC: Pedestrian crossing.
questions.explanation: This sign warns of a winding road ahead.

questions.question: The correct way to use a freeway exit ramp is to:
questions.answerA: Slow down before entering the exit ramp.
questions.answerB: Slow down once moving onto the exit ramp.
questions.answerC: Keep your speed constant once in the exit ramp.
questions.answerD: Pass slower traffic in the exit ramp.
questions.explanation: When using a freeway exit ramp, do not slow down until you move onto the exit ramp.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Reserved parking for persons with disabilities.
questions.answerB: Slow-moving vehicle.
questions.answerC: No U-turn.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates parking spaces that are reserved for vehicles displaying Persons with Disabilities license plates, Disabled Veteran license plates, and/or disabled parking placards.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Merge right.
questions.answerB: Divided highway begins.
questions.answerC: Lane ends.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the right lane ends ahead. A merging maneuver will be required for drivers in that lane.

questions.question: The best way to avoid a dangerous situation while driving is to:
questions.answerA: Know what is happening around your vehicle.
questions.answerB: Turn off the radio.
questions.answerC: Always keep your eyes focused ahead of your car.
questions.explanation: Always be aware of what is happening around your vehicle. Constantly observing your surroundings to the front, sides, and rear of your vehicle will help you see problems that may require you to change speed or roadway position.

questions.question: If a transit vehicle is signaling to re-enter the main roadway following a stop, you must:
questions.answerA: Honk to let them know you’re there.
questions.answerB: Move to the left lane.
questions.answerC: Yield.
questions.explanation: You must yield to any transit vehicle that is signaling to pull back onto the main roadway after it has stopped to load or unload passengers. Change lanes, slow down, or stop to allow the bus safe re-entry into traffic.

questions.question: If you are being followed too closely on a two-lane road:
questions.answerA: Reduce your speed slowly to encourage the tailgater to drive around you.
questions.answerB: Speed up to increase the distance between you and the other car.
questions.answerC: Apply your brakes to slow down, then resume your original speed.
questions.explanation: If you are being followed too closely by another driver, merge into a different lane. If there is no lane available for merging, wait until the road ahead is clear and slowly reduce your speed. This will encourage the tailgater to drive around you.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Heavy traffic ahead.
questions.answerB: Do not enter.
questions.answerC: Railroad crossing.
questions.explanation: This sign means that it is not safe for drivers to enter the indicated road or driveway from their current direction. If you come across one of these signs, you should immediately turn around and drive a different way.

questions.question: If you are driving near a large commercial vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Follow the large vehicle closely to reduce wind drag on your vehicle.
questions.answerB: Avoid driving beside it for long stretches of time.
questions.answerC: Drive on its right side when on curves and hills.
questions.explanation: Because large commercial vehicles have large blind spots on each side, you should avoid driving beside them for long periods of time.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true?
questions.answerA: A sudden change in weather calls for a change in driving.
questions.answerB: You should slow down when driving in rain and fog.
questions.answerC: Be particularly aware of vehicles coming up behind you in inclement weather.
questions.explanation: If the weather changes suddenly, you will need to adjust your driving to adapt. Always slow down when driving in rainy or foggy conditions. Be especially aware of vehicles behind you that may be going too fast for conditions.

questions.question: You are driving on a road with two or more lanes traveling in the same direction. You should:
questions.answerA: Drive in any lane.
questions.answerB: Drive in the left lane, except to pass.
questions.answerC: Drive in the right lane, except to pass.
questions.explanation: On a multilane highway, slower traffic should travel in the right lane. Use the left lane to pass slower-moving traffic.

questions.question: You may drive around or under a gate that is being lowered or raised at a railroad crossing:
questions.answerA: As long as an approaching train is not too close.
questions.answerB: If your vehicle can do so without damaging the gate.
questions.answerC: If you first look carefully in both directions.
questions.explanation: Flashing red lights, lowered crossing gates, and/or bells at a railroad crossing mean that you must come to a complete stop. You must not go across the tracks until the lights and bells have stopped and the crossing gates are completely up. Do not drive around or under a gate that is moving up or down.

questions.question: If you have to back up a vehicle on a two-lane road, you should:
questions.answerA: Be sure the way is clear before backing.
questions.answerB: Turn your head back before and while backing.
questions.answerC: Stop, using the proper hand signal to communicate stopping if you see another vehicle approaching from the rear.
questions.explanation: Always turn your head to check behind your vehicle before and while backing up. Be sure the way is clear of other traffic before moving.

questions.question: If someone is driving aggressively behind you, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to get out of the aggressive driver’s way.
questions.answerB: Stare at the driver as he or she is passing you.
questions.answerC: Speed up as he or she is passing you.
questions.explanation: If you encounter an aggressive driver, you should make every attempt to get out of their way. You should avoid making eye contact with a hostile driver. Challenging a hostile driver by speeding up may only make them angrier, thereby increasing their danger.

questions.question: Which statement about speed is true?
questions.answerA: Driving too slowly on certain highways can be dangerous.
questions.answerB: Speeding can kill.
questions.answerC: Speeding is not dangerous if you are a skilled driver.
questions.answerD: Both "Driving too slowly on certain highways can be dangerous" and "Speeding can kill."
questions.explanation: As speed increases, the chance of a fatality increases. If you are moving faster than 80 miles per hour, you have almost no chance of living through a crash. Driving more slowly than other traffic can also be dangerous because other motorists may become impatient and make dangerous moves to pass you.

questions.question: When driving near heavy trucks, other drivers and highway users must make allowances for:
questions.answerA: The increased stopping distance required by large vehicles.
questions.answerB: The decreased stopping distance required by large vehicles.
questions.answerC: The decreased noise of larger vehicles.
questions.answerD: The increased speed of larger vehicles.
questions.explanation: When driving near heavy trucks, other drivers and highway users must make allowances for the increased stopping distance required by the large vehicles. Drivers of smaller vehicles should remain in locations where they can be seen by the driver of the large vehicle and where their view of traffic is not blocked by the vehicle.

questions.question: When in a travel lane on the roadway:
questions.answerA: You may stop to drop off passengers.
questions.answerB: You may stop to look up an address.
questions.answerC: You may make a U-turn or back up if you get on the wrong entrance ramp of the freeway.
questions.answerD: Don’t stop for any reason. Keep moving until you can safely pull off the road.
questions.explanation: You should not stop in a travel lane for any reason. Instead, keep moving until you can safely pull off of the road. If you miss your turn or exit, do not back up. Go to the next turn or exit or where you can safely turn around.

questions.question: A motorist making a left turn at an intersection must yield the right-of-way to a bicyclist entering the intersection from the opposite direction.
questions.answerA: True
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: When turning left at an intersection, you must yield to oncoming bicycles in the same manner that you would yield to oncoming motor vehicles. Keep your wheels straight while waiting to turn and proceed when the way is clear of traffic and pedestrians.

questions.question: Pentagonal signs indicate:
questions.answerA: No passing zones.
questions.answerB: School zones.
questions.answerC: Speed limits.
questions.explanation: Pentagonal signs indicate that you are in a school zone. Be extra alert to children and pedestrians when driving near a school.

questions.question: Which statement is true?
questions.answerA: You only have to stop for a stopped school bus if you see children crossing the street.
questions.answerB: You must stop for a stopped school bus on any two-lane highway.
questions.answerC: You must stop for a school bus when the bus is in a passenger loading zone completely off the roadway.
questions.explanation: You must always stop on a two-lane road for a school bus that has its red or amber signal lights flashing as it is stopped to unload passengers. On a road with four or more lanes, you do not need to stop if the stopped bus is on the opposite side of the road. You do not need to stop if the bus is in a passenger loading zone that is completely off the main road.

questions.question: If you have trouble seeing other vehicles because of dust or smoke blowing across the roadway, you should drive more slowly and turn on your:
questions.answerA: Emergency flashers.
questions.answerB: Parking lights.
questions.answerC: Headlights.
questions.explanation: You must turn on your headlights any time conditions prevent you from seeing other vehicles. Other drivers may have trouble seeing you, too.

questions.question: When you see this sign, you should:
questions.answerA: Watch for traffic merging from the right.
questions.answerB: Merge right.
questions.answerC: Turn left.
questions.explanation: Warning signs alert drivers to upcoming hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers about potential traffic merging into their lane from the right.

questions.question: Drivers are not required to stop upon meeting a stopped school bus when traveling in the opposite direction on a four-lane highway.
questions.answerA: True
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: You do not need to stop upon meeting a stopped school bus when you are traveling in the opposite direction on a roadway with at least four lanes. You should always exercise caution when driving near children.

questions.question: On a four-lane highway, slower traffic should drive in the:
questions.answerA: Center lane.
questions.answerB: Right lane.
questions.answerC: Left lane.
questions.explanation: On a four-lane highway, slower traffic should travel in the right lane. Use the left lanes to pass slower-moving traffic.

questions.question: If you come to a railroad crossing with lowered gates and flashing warning lights, you should:
questions.answerA: Drive around the crossing gates if you can't see a train.
questions.answerB: Come to a complete stop well behind the gates, wait for the tracks to clear, and proceed once the gates are lifted.
questions.answerC: Slow down and drive around the gates.
questions.explanation: You must stop at a railroad crossing where signs, warning devices, or flaggers warn you of the presence of a train. It is illegal to drive around lowered gates.

questions.question: A driver that operates a vehicle on South Carolina roadways has already agreed to submit to a chemical test when requested by a law enforcement officer.
questions.answerA: True
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: South Carolina has an implied consent law. This means that by driving in the state, you give your consent to take a chemical test for intoxication, if called upon to do so.

questions.question: When approaching a four-way stop, drivers must yield the right-of-way to all motorists who arrived before them.
questions.answerA: TRUE
questions.answerB: FALSE
questions.explanation: At a four-way stop, you must yield the right-of-way to drivers who arrived before you. Wait your turn to enter the intersection.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about blind spots is true?
questions.answerA: Blind spots are eliminated if you have one outside mirror.
questions.answerB: Large trucks have bigger blind spots than most passenger vehicles.
questions.answerC: Blind spots can be checked by looking in your rearview mirror.
questions.explanation: Even if a vehicle is properly equipped with rearview and outside mirrors, it still has blind spots that cannot be seen in the mirrors. Large trucks have much larger blind spots than most passenger vehicles.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Do not enter.
questions.answerB: No parking.
questions.answerC: No U-turn.
questions.explanation: This sign prohibits drivers from making a U-turn. You cannot turn around to go in the opposite direction at an intersection where this sign is posted.

questions.question: At dawn or dusk and in rain or snow, it can be hard to see and be seen. A good way to let other drivers know you are there is to turn:
questions.answerA: Up the instrumental panel lights.
questions.answerB: On your parking lights.
questions.answerC: On your headlights.
questions.explanation: You must use your headlights at any time when conditions prevent you from seeing other vehicles and when it may be difficult for other drivers to see you. Always use your low beam headlights if weather conditions require you to use your windshield wipers.

questions.question: When you see an emergency vehicle with flashing lights, you must:
questions.answerA: Slow down and keep moving in your lane.
questions.answerB: Keep driving in your lane.
questions.answerC: Pull to the right curb and stop.
questions.explanation: When you see an emergency vehicle using its lights or hear it using its siren, you must immediately pull over to the curb or side of the road and stop.

questions.question: Drivers who refuse to submit to a chemical test upon request by a law enforcement official will lose their license for:
questions.answerA: One month.
questions.answerB: Three months.
questions.answerC: Six months.
questions.explanation: South Carolina has an implied consent law. By driving in the state, you automatically give your consent to be tested for levels of any dangerous controlled substance. If you refuse to be tested, your license will be suspended for six months. This is in addition to any suspension that you may receive if you are convicted of driving under the influence.

questions.question: A driver entering interstate traffic from an entrance or acceleration ramp:
questions.answerA: Should yield to drivers already on the interstate.
questions.answerB: Has the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: May force their way into traffic.
questions.answerD: Can assume that other drivers will change lanes to make room.
questions.explanation: If you are on an entrance or acceleration ramp and are entering interstate traffic, you should yield to drivers already on the interstate highway. Merge safely into traffic when you are able to do so.

questions.question: When double solid yellow lines mark the center of the road and separate lanes of traffic, passing is:
questions.answerA: Permitted from the left.
questions.answerB: Permitted from the right.
questions.answerC: Not allowed from either direction.
questions.explanation: A double yellow line means that traffic moving in both directions is prohibited from crossing the centerline to pass.

questions.question: Railroad crossings should always be considered:
questions.answerA: Safe to cross, as it is unlikely that a train will be coming.
questions.answerB: Dangerous.
questions.answerC: Safe locations to park a car.
questions.answerD: A place where it is required to stop
questions.explanation: Railroad crossings are always dangerous. Drivers should always look and listen for trains approaching from either direction on all railroad tracks. Always follow the directions indicated by signs, signals, and flaggers. Never proceed past a railroad crossing until you are certain it is safe to do so.

questions.question: If a motorist sees pedestrians in an upcoming crosswalk, they should:
questions.answerA: Continue ahead because motorists always have the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: Wait for the pedestrians to cross.
questions.answerC: Pull to the right and move behind the pedestrians.
questions.explanation: At a crosswalk, you should yield to any pedestrian. Continue driving when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: ____ greatly increase stopping distances and severity of crashes.
questions.answerA: High speeds
questions.answerB: Slow speeds
questions.answerC: Night drives
questions.explanation: High speeds greatly increase stopping distances and severity of crashes. The faster you drive, the greater the impact or striking power of your vehicle, should you be involved in a collision.

questions.question: On a freeway, you realize you missed your turn or exit. You should:
questions.answerA: Make the turn quickly from your lane of travel.
questions.answerB: Stop and back up.
questions.answerC: Continue driving until you reach the next turn, exit, or other location where you can safely turn around.
questions.answerD: Signal other drivers to stop so you can turn.
questions.explanation: If you miss your turn or exit, do not back up, but go on to the next turn or exit where you can safely turn around. It is illegal to back up on a shoulder or a freeway.

questions.question: On the freeway, you see a "Merging traffic“ sign. You should:
questions.answerA: Honk at incoming traffic.
questions.answerB: Always remain at your present speed.
questions.answerC: Speed up to avoid congesting traffic.
questions.answerD: Move to another lane, if safe, to let traffic enter.
questions.explanation: When on a roadway with two or more lanes, you should make room for entering vehicles. If there is no one driving next to you, move over one lane.

questions.question: If you can see that the roadway up ahead is covered by heavy smoke, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn on your four-way flashers and continue.
questions.answerB: Reduce your speed, move as far to the right as possible, and stop off the roadway.
questions.answerC: Turn on your high beam headlights and continue.
questions.explanation: If you notice that the road ahead is covered by heavy smoke, reduce your speed immediately, drive as far as possible to the right, and stop off the roadway. Only then should you determine if it is safe for you to continue. Remember that certain kinds of smoke can irritate your eyes and lungs or even kill you.

questions.question: A steady yellow traffic signal light is a warning that the light is about to change to red. If you are already within the intersection when a green light changes to yellow, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop.
questions.answerB: Continue moving and clear the intersection safely.
questions.answerC: Increase your speed so as not to cause an accident.
questions.explanation: If you are already within an intersection when the traffic light turns yellow, you should clear the intersection as quickly as possible.

questions.question: When driving at night, if oncoming headlights are blinding you, you should:
questions.answerA: Look toward the right edge of the road.
questions.answerB: Switch your lights to their high beam setting.
questions.answerC: Flash your lights.
questions.explanation: To avoid being blinded by the headlights of oncoming vehicles when driving at night, look toward the right edge of the road until the vehicle passes.

questions.question: Which of the following is against the law and is punishable by imprisonment and/or fines?
questions.answerA: Driving barefooted
questions.answerB: Steering with one hand
questions.answerC: Speeding
questions.explanation: The legal maximum speed limit is the absolute limit to how fast you may drive. Participating in or assisting a race on a public highway can be punished by a fine and/or imprisonment.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
questions.answerA: Use your left foot to brake.
questions.answerB: Use your right foot for both braking and accelerating your vehicle.
questions.answerC: You should always brake abruptly to ensure stopping.
questions.explanation: Use your right foot for both braking and accelerating. You should apply the brakes gently with increasing pressure so that your vehicle stops gradually and smoothly.

questions.question: Where is parking prohibited?
questions.answerA: Within 45 feet of a fire hydrant
questions.answerB: On a sidewalk
questions.answerC: Within 100 feet of a driveway
questions.explanation: There are a number of locations where parking is prohibited. These locations include on a sidewalk, within 15 feet of a fire hydrant, and in front of a driveway (or near enough to a driveway to interfere with others' abilities to use it).

questions.question: To see objects in their blind spot when changing lanes, drivers should check:
questions.answerA: Only the left outside mirror.
questions.answerB: Over their left or right shoulder.
questions.answerC: Only the inside rearview mirror.
