questions.explanation: Your vehicle's blind spots are the areas that you cannot see in your mirrors. Look over the appropriate shoulder to check your blind spot when changing lanes.

questions.question: To see vehicles in your blind spots, you should check:
questions.answerA: The inside rearview mirror.
questions.answerB: The outside rearview mirror.
questions.answerC: Over your shoulders.
questions.explanation: By definition, blind spots are areas that cannot be seen using your mirrors. To check your blind spots, you should look over your shoulders.

questions.question: To help others see you when daylight begins to fade, you should use your:
questions.answerA: Parking lights.
questions.answerB: Low beam headlights.
questions.answerC: Emergency flashers.
questions.explanation: As daylight begins to fade, turn on your low beams to help others see you. Only use your high beam headlights in an open area where no other drivers are present.

questions.question: When steering a vehicle:
questions.answerA: Both hands should be placed on the outside of the steering wheel on opposite sides.
questions.answerB: Use a firm but gentle grip on the steering wheel, using your fingers and not your palms.
questions.answerC: All of the above.
questions.explanation: Your hands should be placed on opposite sides the steering wheel with your thumbs aiming up. Grip the wheel gently but firmly, using your fingers rather than your palms. Turn the steering wheel by gripping the outside of the wheel, not the inside.

questions.question: A motorist making a left turn at an intersection should yield the right-of-way to a bicyclist entering the intersection from the opposite direction.
questions.answerA: True
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: Always yield to pedestrians and oncoming traffic when making a left turn. You may complete the turn when the way is clear.

questions.question: Traffic signals sometimes display arrows to control turns from specific lanes. A solid yellow arrow:
questions.answerA: Is never used as a traffic signal.
questions.answerB: Has the same meaning as a circular yellow traffic light.
questions.answerC: Means that drivers may turn in the direction indicated by the arrow.
questions.answerD: Tells drivers that a green arrow is about to be shown.
questions.explanation: A solid yellow arrow has the same meaning as a yellow traffic light. When approaching a solid yellow arrow, you must reduce your speed and prepare for a red light.

questions.question: When driving in work zones, you should:
questions.answerA: Activate your four-way flashers.
questions.answerB: Stay alert, slow down, obey directions given by signs and flaggers, and be prepared to respond quickly to any hazards.
questions.answerC: Increase your speed so as not to impede traffic.
questions.explanation: When entering a work zone, you should slow down and closely watch the traffic around you. Obey directions given to drivers by signs and flaggers Be ready to respond quickly to any changes in traffic.

questions.question: Use your headlights on rainy, snowy, or foggy days:
questions.answerA: To keep your engine warm.
questions.answerB: So others can see your vehicle.
questions.answerC: To warn others of bad weather conditions.
questions.explanation: On rainy, snowy, or foggy days, it may be difficult for other drivers to see your vehicle. Under these conditions, headlights make your vehicle easier to see. If the weather requires you to turn on your windshield wipers, you must also turn on your low beam headlights.

questions.question: A driver who is taking a non-prescription drug should:
questions.answerA: Read the labels on the drug before driving.
questions.answerB: Drink alcohol instead.
questions.answerC: Continue to drive regardless of any warning labels.
questions.explanation: Many over-the-counter medications can affect your ability to drive safely. If you take medication, even a remedy for colds or allergies that is not prescribed, check the label for warnings about its effects. If you are unsure, ask your doctor or pharmacist about driving while on the medication.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Divided highway ends.
questions.answerB: One-way traffic ahead.
questions.answerC: Two-way traffic ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that you must keep to the right of the upcoming divider.

questions.question: If you’re going to turn left onto a one-way street, you should complete the turn into:
questions.answerA: The right lane.
questions.answerB: The lane closest to your previous lane.
questions.answerC: Either lane.
questions.explanation: You should always turn from the lane that is closest to the direction you want to go. Turn into the lane closest to your previous lane.

questions.question: The faster the speed of your vehicle, the longer it takes to stop when you must react to other drivers' unexpected movements.
questions.answerA: TRUE
questions.answerB: FALSE
questions.explanation: The faster you are driving, the longer it will take for you to stop to react to other drivers' unexpected moves.

questions.question: If you park facing uphill where there is no curb, set the parking brake and:
questions.answerA: Turn your wheels toward the edge of the road.
questions.answerB: Turn your wheels away from the edge of the road.
questions.answerC: Keep your wheels facing straight.
questions.explanation: When parking uphill on a road that does not have a curb, your front wheels should be turned to the right (toward the edge of the road). This will ensure that the vehicle will roll off of the road if the brakes fail.

questions.question: When changing lanes, you can check your blind spot by:
questions.answerA: Using the inside rearview mirror.
questions.answerB: Turning your head and looking over your shoulder.
questions.answerC: Using your side mirror.
questions.explanation: Even if your vehicle is properly equipped with mirrors, there are blind spots that cannot be seen by using the mirrors. Before changing lanes, look over your shoulder to check these areas.

questions.question: When approaching a school bus stopped with its stop arm extended, drivers should:
questions.answerA: Come to a complete stop and wait to proceed.
questions.answerB: Honk their horn before passing the bus on its left.
questions.answerC: Continue driving when they think most kids are probably done exiting the bus.
questions.answerD: Pass the bus before its door opens.
questions.explanation: When approaching a stopped school bus that is using its stop signal, a driver is required to come to a complete stop. They should not proceed until the stop arm is withdrawn.

questions.question: Talking or texting on a cell phone while driving will not significantly increase your chances being involved in a crash.
questions.answerA: TRUE
questions.answerB: FALSE
questions.explanation: Using a phone while driving is a distraction that increases your risk of being involved in a crash.

questions.question: You may avoid the risks of alcohol-related crashes by:
questions.answerA: Deciding before you start drinking that you are not going to drive.
questions.answerB: Simply saying, "No thanks, I'm driving," if someone offers you a drink.
questions.answerC: Calling a taxi.
questions.explanation: The only way to avoid the risks of drinking and driving is to decide before you start drinking that you are not going to drive. Because alcohol affects your judgement, it will be harder for you to make safe decisions after you have started drinking.

questions.question: Drivers are always required to stop for a stopped school bus when driving on a two-lane road.
questions.answerA: TRUE
questions.answerB: FALSE
questions.explanation: Drivers are always required to stop for a stopped school bus when driving on a two-lane road, regardless of their direction of travel. You should exercise caution when driving near children.

questions.question: When you need to change lanes, it is important to:
questions.answerA: Signal your intentions ahead of the lane change.
questions.answerB: Check your blind spot.
questions.answerC: Make sure the lane is clear before entering.
questions.explanation: Always signal for an appropriate amount of time before making a lane change or exiting a freeway. Before you make any move to the right or left, quickly turn your head and look over your shoulder to see if your blind spot is clear.

questions.question: When driving in traffic, it is safest to:
questions.answerA: Fluctuate your speed to keep alert.
questions.answerB: Drive faster than the flow of traffic.
questions.answerC: Drive slower than the flow of traffic.
questions.answerD: Drive with the flow of traffic.
questions.explanation: Crashes often happen when some drivers go faster or slower than other vehicles on the road. Always try to drive with the flow of traffic, within the posted speed limit.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: All traffic must turn right.
questions.answerB: No right turn.
questions.answerC: All traffic must go straight ahead.
questions.answerD: A road joins from the right.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is an intersection ahead. A road joins from the right.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true?
questions.answerA: Signal at least 100 feet before changing lanes to pass and ensure there is no oncoming traffic.
questions.answerB: Use your mirrors and look over your left shoulder to check your blind spot when passing to the left.
questions.answerC: When passing, wait until you can see both headlights of the passed car in your rearview mirror before returning to your original lane.
questions.explanation: When passing, you must always signal at least 100 feet in advance of your lane change. Always check behind you in your mirrors and look over your shoulder to check your blind spot. Wait until you can see both headlights of the passed car in your rearview mirror before returning to your original lane.

questions.question: When may you proceed through an intersection that has a stop sign but no stop line or crosswalk?
questions.answerA: After slowing down to verify that there is no cross traffic
questions.answerB: After coming to a complete stop and verifying that it is safe to proceed
questions.answerC: After you have stopped at least 20 feet prior to the intersection
questions.answerD: After slowing down to a speed of 10 mph
questions.explanation: Stop before the stop line or crosswalk at any intersection that is controlled by a stop sign. If there is a stop sign but no stop line or crosswalk, stop before entering the intersection and proceed when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: You approach an emergency vehicle that is stopped with its lights flashing. You must:
questions.answerA: Slow down. If possible, change lanes so you will not drive next to the stopped emergency vehicle.
questions.answerB: Drive to the right side of the road and stop.
questions.answerC: Stay in your lane and continue to drive at the same speed.
questions.answerD: Accelerate to quickly pass the stopped vehicle.
questions.explanation: If you approach an emergency vehicle, tow truck, or roadside assistance vehicle that is stopped with its lights flashing, you must change lanes to allow the vehicle extra space. If there is only one lane moving in your direction, or if changing lanes would be unsafe, you must slow down to a speed below the posted speed limit and give the stationary vehicle as much room as possible. Always slow down and be prepared to stop when you approach an emergency scene.

questions.question: A flashing yellow light at an intersection means that you should:
questions.answerA: Slow down and proceed with care.
questions.answerB: Continue normally through the intersection.
questions.answerC: Stop and proceed when a green light appears.
questions.answerD: Stop and proceed when the way is clear.
questions.explanation: A flashing yellow light at an intersection means "caution." If you approach such a light, slow down, look, and proceed with care.

questions.question: When riding in a vehicle, small children:
questions.answerA: May be safely held by a strong adult.
questions.answerB: Will be safe if they are standing on the floor in the back of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Will not be hurt in an accident because they are small.
questions.answerD: Must never be allowed to ride while standing in the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Special child seats are available for children who are too small to wear regular safety belts. No person is strong enough to safely hold onto a child of any size during an accident or sudden stop. Never allow a child to ride in a vehicle unless they are properly fastened into a seat.

questions.question: Drivers must be careful when passing large vehicles and should avoid driving beside large vehicles for long periods of time.
questions.answerA: TRUE
questions.answerB: FALSE
questions.explanation: Because large vehicles have large blind spots on both sides, you should avoid driving beside a large vehicle for a long period of time. It is safest for you to either drop back or move forward when you find yourself directly next to a large vehicle.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: No right turn.
questions.answerB: You must turn right.
questions.answerC: Watch for traffic on your right.
questions.explanation: This sign prohibits right turns. You cannot make a right turn at an intersection where this sign is posted.

questions.question: The presence of double solid yellow lines means you may pass another vehicle from either direction.
questions.answerA: TRUE
questions.answerB: FALSE
questions.explanation: A double solid yellow line means that it is prohibited for vehicles traveling in either direction to cross the centerline to pass.

questions.question: Traffic signals sometimes display arrows to control turns from specific lanes. A solid red arrow:
questions.answerA: Is never used as a traffic signal.
questions.answerB: Has the same meaning as a circular red traffic light.
questions.answerC: Means that drivers may turn in the direction indicated by the arrow.
questions.answerD: Means that the traffic the arrow is pointing toward must stop.
questions.explanation: A solid red arrow in a traffic signal means the same thing as a circular red traffic light. When an arrow is red, traffic in the indicated lane must stop and may not turn in the direction that the arrow is pointing.

questions.question: When driving in fog, you should:
questions.answerA: Slow down and use your low beam headlights.
questions.answerB: Slow down and use your high beam headlights.
questions.answerC: Turn your lights on and off to warn other drivers.
questions.explanation: When driving in fog, you should slow down and use your low beam headlights. If the fog is so bad that you cannot see, pull off the road and wait for the fog to clear.

questions.question: A broken yellow line down the center of a road indicates that:
questions.answerA: A construction zone is ahead.
questions.answerB: Passing is not permitted from either direction.
questions.answerC: Passing is permitted from either direction.
questions.explanation: When broken yellow lines separate the lanes of traffic on a two-lane roadway, any driver may pass when there is no oncoming traffic.

questions.question: When you see this yellow sign, you should:
questions.answerA: Always stop at the crosswalk.
questions.answerB: Stop at the crosswalk until a crossing guards signals for you to go.
questions.answerC: Be prepared to stop if children are in the crosswalk.
questions.explanation: A five-sided sign indicates that you are near a school. Be aware and stop if children are in the crosswalk.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Four-lane traffic ahead.
questions.answerB: Divided highway ahead.
questions.answerC: Two-way traffic ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. They alert you to conditions that are immediately ahead. This sign warns that you are leaving a separated one-way highway and will soon be driving on a two-way highway.

questions.question: You want to park uphill on a two-way road and there is no curb. Which direction do you turn your front wheels?
questions.answerA: Straight ahead
questions.answerB: Right, toward the side of the road
questions.answerC: Left, toward the center of the road
questions.explanation: When parking either uphill or downhill on a road that has no curb, you should turn your wheels so that the vehicle will roll away from the center of the road if the brakes fail.

questions.question: You should always travel:
questions.answerA: At the speed of vehicles surrounding you.
questions.answerB: At the speed limit.
questions.answerC: At a speed appropriate for road and weather conditions.
questions.explanation: The speed at which you should drive your vehicle depends on road conditions, the weather, and the legal speed limit. You may never drive above the legal speed limit. Decrease your speed when anything makes conditions less than ideal.

questions.question: A large truck is ahead of you and is turning right onto a street with two lanes in each direction. The truck:
questions.answerA: May complete its turn in either of the two lanes.
questions.answerB: May have to swing wide to complete the right turn.
questions.answerC: Must stay in the right lane at all times while turning.
questions.explanation: When a vehicle makes a turn, the rear wheels follow a shorter path than the front wheels. The longer the vehicle, the bigger the difference between the paths of the front and rear wheels. Therefore, long trucks often have to swing wide to complete a right turn.

questions.question: When changing lanes:
questions.answerA: Check your side mirror and look over your shoulder to make sure the lane is clear.
questions.answerB: Check the inside rearview mirror.
questions.answerC: Slow down.
questions.explanation: Before changing lanes, you should check your side mirrors and look over your shoulder to make sure it is safe to proceed.

questions.question: When you see a flashing yellow light at an intersection, you should:
questions.answerA: Yield to all traffic before crossing the intersection.
questions.answerB: Stop, then enter the intersection when it is safe to do so.
questions.answerC: Slow down and cross the intersection carefully.
questions.explanation: A flashing yellow light at an intersection indicates that drivers should slow to a safe and reasonable speed and proceed with caution.

questions.question: From top to bottom, the following is the proper order for traffic lights:
questions.answerA: Red, yellow, green.
questions.answerB: Red, green, yellow.
questions.answerC: Green, red, yellow.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. They alert you to conditions that are immediately ahead. This sign warns drivers about the presence of traffic signals at an intersection ahead.

questions.question: When taking medication before driving, the most important thing for you to do is to:
questions.answerA: Get behind the wheel before the medicine can take effect.
questions.answerB: Make several rest stops on your trip.
questions.answerC: Understand the effects of the medication and adjust your driving accordingly.
questions.answerD: Ask another person to ride with you.
questions.explanation: Many medications can produce side effects that may impair your driving skills. If you are taking any medications, be aware of their side effects and do not drive if they interfere with your ability to drive.

questions.question: If there are two railroad tracks next to each other:
questions.answerA: It is always safe to proceed after one train passes.
questions.answerB: You must always stop before crossing the tracks.
questions.answerC: When one train passes, look for another train on the other track before proceeding.
questions.answerD: Honk your horn as you cross the tracks.
questions.explanation: If there are two railroad tracks next to each other, watch for a second approaching train after one train passes. Do not begin to cross the tracks until you’re sure no train is approaching from either direction on either track.

questions.question: When you park uphill on a street with a curb:
questions.answerA: Keep the front wheel straight and set the parking brake.
questions.answerB: Turn the front wheels away from the curb.
questions.answerC: Turn the front wheels toward the curb.
questions.answerD: Turn the back wheels into the curb.
questions.explanation: When parking on an incline where there is a curb, you should turn your wheels sharply to the left, away from the curb. This way, if your brakes fail, your vehicle will not roll into traffic.

questions.question: Alcohol is:
questions.answerA: A stimulant.
questions.answerB: An antihistamine.
questions.answerC: A depressant.
questions.explanation: Alcohol is a depressant that dulls your judgment and makes your reflexes unreliable.

questions.question: A person riding a bicycle must obey the same traffic laws as a driver of a motor vehicle.
questions.answerA: True
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: Bicyclists have the same rights and responsibilities as automobile drivers when using streets and highways. They are part of the normal traffic flow and are entitled to share the road with other drivers.

questions.question: Always signal when:
questions.answerA: Changing lanes.
questions.answerB: Pulling into or out of a parking space.
questions.answerC: Pulling into traffic from a parking area or alley.
questions.explanation: Your turn signals should always be used when you make any movement to the left or right. You should use your signal when pulling into traffic from a curbside parking space, moving into a new lane, or passing another vehicle.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Narrow bridge ahead.
questions.answerB: Lane ends or roadway narrows ahead.
questions.answerC: Industrial area.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually diamond-shaped with black markings on a yellow background. They alert drivers to upcoming hazards. This sign warns drivers that the right lane is ending or that the road is narrowing ahead.

questions.question: This sign is a:
questions.answerA: Yield sign.
questions.answerB: School crossing sign.
questions.answerC: Stop sign.
questions.explanation: A downward-facing triangular sign is always a yield sign. Drivers must be prepared to slow down or stop when approaching a yield sign.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Your current roadway ends ahead.
questions.answerB: You must bear either right or left.
questions.answerC: A four-way intersection is ahead.
questions.answerD: A road joins from the right.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is a Y intersection ahead. You must bear either to the right or to the left.

questions.question: On a two-lane street, your vehicle is being followed by a fire engine that is not using its emergency signals. You should:
questions.answerA: Continue to drive in a normal manner.
questions.answerB: Stop as quickly as you can.
questions.answerC: Speed up to get out of its way.
questions.answerD: Slow down, move as far to the right as possible, and stop.
questions.explanation: If you are being followed by an emergency vehicle that is not using its siren or flashing lights, you do not need to clear a path. Continue driving in a normal manner.

questions.question: A person who drives much slower than the speed limit:
questions.answerA: Is a very safe driver.
questions.answerB: Always has the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Should not let following cars pass.
questions.answerD: May create a dangerous driving environment.
questions.explanation: Driving more slowly than the flow of traffic can be hazardous. If you are on a two-lane, two-way road and driving so slowly that traffic is backing up behind you, you are required to pull off the road and let the other vehicles pass. Only drive significantly under the speed limit when conditions require it.

questions.question: Roads are slippery after it first starts to rain. When the road is slippery, you should:
questions.answerA: Avoid making turns and stops while driving at high speeds.
questions.answerB: Test your tires' traction while going uphill.
questions.answerC: Decrease the distance you look ahead of your vehicle.
questions.explanation: A wet, slippery road does not allow your tires the traction they need, so it is necessary to drive more slowly on a wet road than you would on a dry road. To reduce the risk of skidding, you should avoid fast turns or stops.

questions.question: To help avoid skidding on slippery surfaces, you should:
questions.answerA: Shift to a lower gear after starting down a steep hill.
questions.answerB: Speed up to enter curves and slow down to exit them.
questions.answerC: Slow down before entering curves and intersections.
questions.explanation: Slow down before you enter a curve because you do not know what may be ahead. Braking on a curve may cause you to skid.

questions.question: You should never park a vehicle:
questions.answerA: Within 50 feet of a railroad crossing.
questions.answerB: Within 20 feet of a crosswalk.
questions.answerC: Within 30 feet of any flashing signal located on the side of a roadway.
questions.explanation: Locations where it is prohibited to park include within 50 feet of a railroad crossing; within 20 feet of a crosswalk at an intersection; and within 30 feet of a signal light, stop sign, or flashing beacon on the side of the roadway.

questions.question: Headlights must be used:
questions.answerA: After 6 p.m. and before 7 a.m.
questions.answerB: After 7 p.m. and before 8 a.m.
questions.answerC: After 8 p.m. and before 7 a.m. during daylight savings time.
questions.explanation: You must have your headlights turned on when driving from a half hour after sunset until a half hour before sunrise. Turn on your headlights when driving in lowered-visibility situations.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Steep grade ahead.
questions.answerB: The road ahead winds with a series of turns or curves.
questions.answerC: Slippery when wet.
questions.explanation: Warning signs provide notice to road users of a situation that might not be readily apparent and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers to be careful when driving under wet conditions as the pavement will become slippery and more difficult to navigate safely.

questions.question: Which statement about making a right turn is true?
questions.answerA: You should swing wide to the left when making a right turn so you won't run over the curb.
questions.answerB: You may make a right turn at a red traffic light, unless a sign prohibits the turn.
questions.answerC: When making a right turn onto a four-lane roadway, finish the turn in the far left lane.
questions.explanation: After yielding to traffic and pedestrians, you may turn right when stopped at a steady red traffic signal, unless posted signs prohibit it. When making a right turn, you should stay close to the right edge of the roadway and turn into the lane nearest to your previous lane.

questions.question: As you approach the top of a hill, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up slightly.
questions.answerB: Prepare to stop, if needed.
questions.answerC: Maintain a steady speed.
questions.explanation: You may not know what is on the other side of a hill or just around a curve, even if you have driven the road many times. If a vehicle is stalled just out of sight on the roadway, you must be able to stop. Whenever you come to a hill or curve, adjust your speed so you can stop if necessary.

questions.question: At many intersections, a right turn may be made while the traffic light is red. Before turning right on red:
questions.answerA: Slow down and proceed without stopping, if the way is clear.
questions.answerB: Come to a complete stop, look both ways, and yield the right-of-way to pedestrians and other traffic.
questions.answerC: Increase your speed because you have the right-of-way.
questions.explanation: Unless otherwise posted, traffic stopped at a red signal may turn right. You must come to a complete stop before the crosswalk and yield to all pedestrians and cross traffic before beginning your turn.

questions.question: When driving at night, you should:
questions.answerA: Always use your high beams.
questions.answerB: Look directly at the headlights of an oncoming vehicle.
questions.answerC: Increase your following distance.
questions.explanation: Driving at night is more hazardous than daytime driving because the lowered visibility makes it difficult to judge speed, distances, and other potential hazards. Increase your following distance to help prevent a potential collision if the vehicle in front of you should stop abruptly. Use your headlights when driving at night, following the rules for proper usage of high beams and low beams.

questions.question: You should allow an extra cushion of space:
questions.answerA: When following a station wagon.
questions.answerB: When following a driver who cannot see the rear of their vehicle.
questions.answerC: When following a small passenger car.
questions.explanation: Drivers of trucks, buses, vans, or any vehicles pulling campers or trailers may not be able to see you if you are driving directly behind them. Increase your following distance when driving behind one of these vehicles. Additionally, large vehicles can block your view of the road, so increase your following distance to look around the sides of the vehicle and see the road ahead.

questions.question: On a green arrow, you must:
questions.answerA: Yield to any vehicle, bicycle, or pedestrian in the intersection.
questions.answerB: Yield to pedestrians only in the intersection.
questions.answerC: Wait four seconds before proceeding.
questions.explanation: A green arrow means "go." You must turn in the direction the arrow is pointing after you yield to any vehicles, bicycles, or pedestrians who are still in the intersection.

questions.question: Drivers may not pass a school bus when its red lights are flashing.
questions.answerA: True
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: When approaching a school bus that is using its flashing red lights, you must stop before you reach the bus and remain stopped until the flashing lights are turned off. On a two-way multilane roadway with a median or shared center lane, vehicles on the opposite side of the road from the school bus do not have to stop.

questions.question: Which of the following blocks the smooth flow of traffic?
questions.answerA: Slowing down to look at collision scene.
questions.answerB: Avoiding unnecessary lane changes.
questions.answerC: Using public transportation instead of your vehicle.
questions.explanation: Rubbernecking (the practice of slowing down to look at collisions or other out-of-the-ordinary things) contributes to traffic congestion and should be avoided.

questions.question: When turning left at an intersection:
questions.answerA: You should always yield to oncoming traffic and pedestrians.
questions.answerB: Oncoming traffic and pedestrians should yield to you.
questions.answerC: You should never yield to oncoming traffic and pedestrians.
questions.explanation: Drivers making left turns must yield to oncoming traffic that is traveling straight. Drivers must always yield to pedestrians.

questions.question: Hydroplaning occurs when tires ride on a thin film of water instead of on the road. To prevent hydroplaning in wet weather, you should:
questions.answerA: Put on your cruise control to maintain a constant speed.
questions.answerB: Slow down.
questions.answerC: Move to the shoulder of the road as soon as it starts to rain.
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning is caused by driving too fast on a wet road. Slow down when driving on wet pavement to prevent hydroplaning.

questions.question: When driving in fog, rain, or snow, use:
questions.answerA: Low beams.
questions.answerB: High beams.
questions.answerC: Fog lights only.
questions.explanation: Low beam headlights should be used in fog, rain, and snow. The light from high beams will reflect back to the driver under these weather conditions, causing a glare that will make it difficult to see ahead.

questions.question: When may you legally drive around or under a railroad crossing gate?
questions.answerA: Never.
questions.answerB: When you can see clearly in both directions.
questions.answerC: When the warning lights are not flashing.
questions.explanation: Do not go around or under any lowered gate at a railroad crossing. Once the gate is raised, do not proceed across the tracks until you can see clearly in both directions and are sure there are no trains coming.

questions.question: When preparing to make a left turn from a two-way street, you should drive:
questions.answerA: Near the right-hand side of the road.
questions.answerB: Near the centerline.
questions.answerC: On the left of the centerline.
questions.explanation: When you are turning left from a two-way street, begin in the lane closest to the centerline and start your turn just before the front of your car reaches the center of the intersection. Do not cut the corner. Steering hand-over-hand, turn into the first available legal lane.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true?
questions.answerA: Driving too slowly is not an unsafe practice.
questions.answerB: Driving too slowly on certain highways can be dangerous.
questions.answerC: The speed at which you drive a vehicle does not affect safety.
questions.explanation: Driving too slowly can be dangerous because it may cause drivers behind you to become frustrated and make dangerous moves to pass you. It is safest to drive with the flow of traffic, within the legal speed limit.

questions.question: When stopped at a red traffic light with a green arrow, you may proceed in the direction of the arrow if you:
questions.answerA: First come to a complete stop.
questions.answerB: Wait until the light changes.
questions.answerC: Are in the proper lane and the intersection is clear.
questions.explanation: You may proceed in the direction that a green arrow signal is pointing if you are in the proper lane, regardless of any other signals that are displayed. Before turning, you must yield the right-of-way to pedestrians and vehicles already within the intersection.

questions.question: Work zones on highways have become increasingly safe for workers and drivers.
questions.answerA: True
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: Work zones on highways have become increasingly dangerous for both workers and drivers.

questions.question: In rainy weather, you should be most careful when turning or stopping:
questions.answerA: After it has been raining all day.
questions.answerB: One half hour after it stops raining.
questions.answerC: During the first half hour of rain.
questions.explanation: You should be extra careful when turning and stopping during the first half hour of rain. At this point, the oil from cars has not yet washed off the pavement and could be forming a slippery mixture with the rain.

questions.question: If an emergency vehicle with flashing lights is traveling in the area where you are driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up to avoid the emergency vehicle.
questions.answerB: Stop your vehicle immediately and prevent them from passing.
questions.answerC: Make every effort to give the emergency vehicle a clear path of travel.
questions.answerD: Signal to the emergency vehicle when it is clear for them to pass you.
questions.explanation: If an emergency vehicle with flashing lights is traveling in the area where you are driving, you must make every effort to give them a clear path of travel. If it is safe to do so, pull your vehicle to the side of the road to give the emergency vehicle an open pathway.

questions.question: You are required to stop your vehicle:
questions.answerA: At any intersection where a police officer orders you to stop.
questions.answerB: Where there is a red traffic light.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: You must come to a complete stop at a steady or flashing red traffic light. You must always obey instructions given by officers directing traffic, regardless of any posted signs or traffic signals.

questions.question: Motorists should maintain a safe operating distance when driving near a cyclist.
questions.answerA: TRUE
questions.answerB: FALSE
questions.explanation: Drivers must be especially careful when driving near a cyclist and should maintain a safe operating distance between their vehicle and the cyclist.

questions.question: When passing, you should move back into the right lane when:
questions.answerA: You are one vehicle length ahead of the passed vehicle.
questions.answerB: You can see both headlights of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror.
questions.answerC: You are 50 feet ahead of the passed vehicle.
questions.explanation: Do not pass unless you have enough space to return to the driving lane. Before you return to the driving lane, be sure you have enough room between yourself and the vehicle you have passed. When you can see both headlights of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror, it is safe to return to the driving lane.

questions.question: A person's ability to drive can be impaired by:
questions.answerA: Alcohol.
questions.answerB: Any medication.
questions.answerC: A lack of sleep.
questions.explanation: The ability to drive safely is dependent on the driver being in good physical condition. Driving can be impaired by alcohol, legal and illegal drugs, and being drowsy.

questions.question: When entering a parked vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Enter only from the passenger side door.
questions.answerB: Signal for oncoming vehicles to stop so you may open the driver side door.
questions.answerC: Look around for any obstacles that may interfere with safe driving.
questions.explanation: Before entering your vehicle, check around it for obstacles. Walk around the vehicle to make sure you see everyone and everything present.

questions.question: Which statement about backing on a roadway is true?
questions.answerA: The driver should first give a signal to warn approaching traffic from the rear that they intend to stop.
questions.answerB: Drivers should look straight ahead while backing.
questions.answerC: Traffic checks are not necessary when backing.
questions.explanation: You should always look behind you to check for traffic when backing up. Only back up where it is safe and legal to do so.

questions.question: Emergency vehicles:
questions.answerA: Have the right-of-way when using sirens, horns, and/or flashing lights.
questions.answerB: May use a loudspeaker to give instructions.
questions.answerC: May follow each other.
questions.explanation: You must yield the right-of-way to police cars, fire engines, ambulances, or any other emergency vehicles using a siren or air horn and a red or blue flashing light. Follow any instructions given over the emergency vehicles' loudspeakers. Emergency vehicles often follow each other so you should proceed only when you are certain the way is clear.

questions.question: If your wheels drop off the pavement and onto the shoulder of the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Brake hard and turn sharply back onto the pavement.
questions.answerB: Stop your car on the edge of the road.
questions.answerC: Slow down and very carefully turn back onto the pavement.
questions.answerD: Maintain your speed and turn sharply back onto the pavement.
questions.explanation: If your wheels drop off the pavement and onto a low shoulder, you should reduce your speed without braking and very carefully turn back onto the pavement. Be aware of any nearby traffic when re-entering the road.

questions.question: Your license can be suspended if you are under 21 and drive with a blood alcohol level of:
questions.answerA: 0.15 percent or more.
questions.answerB: 0.08 percent or more.
questions.answerC: Any amount.
questions.explanation: There is zero tolerance for alcohol use by drivers under age 21. If you are under 21, the detection of any trace of alcohol in your system will result in stiff penalties, including the suspension of your license for two years.

questions.question: As you are driving on a four-lane highway, you approach a school bus that is stopped on the opposite side of the road with its red lights flashing. You:
questions.answerA: May not pass.
questions.answerB: May pass, but only if a pedestrian indicates that the way is clear.
questions.answerC: May pass because you are not required to stop.
questions.answerD: Must turn on your emergency flashers.
questions.explanation: In the state of South Carolina, when driving on a highway with four or more lanes, you must stop for a school bus that is loading or unloading passengers only if you are approaching the bus from behind.

questions.question: When driving on the highway, consistently looking far ahead of your vehicle:
questions.answerA: Helps you keep up with traffic.
questions.answerB: Reduces the need for last-minute braking or turning.
questions.answerC: Allows you to spot upcoming police officers.
questions.explanation: To avoid the need for last-minute braking or turning, consistently watch the road far ahead of your vehicle. By looking ahead and being ready to stop or change lanes if needed, you can drive more safely, save fuel, and help keep traffic moving at a steady pace.

questions.question: How fast you drive does not affect the distance your vehicle travels after you brake to come to a stop.
questions.answerA: TRUE
questions.answerB: FALSE
questions.explanation: When driving in high-speed traffic, it is extremely important to stay well behind the vehicle in front of you. As your speed increases, the distance it will take for your vehicle to stop also increases.

questions.question: An intersection has no traffic signs or signals. You arrive at the same time as a vehicle to your right. You should:
questions.answerA: Speed up and get through the intersection.
questions.answerB: Slow down and yield to the vehicle on your right.
questions.answerC: Drive into the intersection and make the other vehicle stop.
questions.answerD: Honk your horn and drive through the intersection.
questions.explanation: When two vehicles arrive to an uncontrolled intersection at the same time, the vehicle on the right has the right-of-way. Once the vehicle on the right has safely passed through the intersection, the other driver may proceed.

questions.question: You may park or stop along the shoulder of the freeway:
questions.answerA: As long as you turn on your four-way (emergency) flashers.
questions.answerB: If no part of your vehicle is on the road.
questions.answerC: If you need to look at a map for directions.
questions.answerD: Only if you have an emergency.
questions.explanation: It is prohibited to park on the shoulder of a freeway, except in an emergency.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Sharp right turn.
questions.answerB: A road joins from the right.
questions.answerC: The road ahead turns sharply right, then sharply left.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the road ahead turns sharply to the right and then sharply to the left.

questions.question: The most important thing to remember about speed management and curves is that you must:
questions.answerA: Drive at the posted speed limit as you enter the curve, then slow down at the sharpest part of the curve.
questions.answerB: Slow down before you enter the curve.
questions.answerC: Accelerate gently before you enter the curve.
questions.answerD: Drive at the posted speed limit before, throughout, and after the curve.
questions.explanation: The most important thing to remember about driving in curves is that your vehicle’s inertia may make it difficult to turn. To maintain control, it is essential that you slow down before entering the curve.

questions.question: If you plan to turn at an intersection, you should start to signal 50 to 75 feet before your turn.
questions.answerA: True
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: In South Carolina, the law requires you to signal at least 100 feet before making any kind of turn.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Merge.
questions.answerB: Winding road ahead.
questions.answerC: Reserved parking for persons with disabilities.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that two lanes of traffic going the same direction will soon merge into one lane.

questions.question: As you drive, you're required to stop your vehicle:
questions.answerA: At an intersection with a stop sign.
questions.answerB: Where there is a red light.
questions.answerC: When a traffic officer orders you to stop.
questions.explanation: Situations where motorists are required to stop include approaching intersections with stop signs, approaching intersections where a red light is either flashing or illuminated, or any time when a traffic officer orders your vehicle to stop.

questions.question: To prevent yourself from becoming an aggressive driver:
questions.answerA: Relax and concentrate on driving.
questions.answerB: Drive above the posted speed limit.
questions.answerC: Tailgate the driver in front of you.
questions.explanation: To prevent yourself from becoming an aggressive driver, concentrate on driving and don't take the actions of other drivers personally. Be realistic about your travel time, drive within posted speed limits, and be forgiving of other drivers using the roadway.

questions.question: Which statement about making a left turn is true?
questions.answerA: You should swing wide into the right lane when making a left turn.
questions.answerB: You cannot make a left turn from a two-way roadway at a red traffic light.
questions.answerC: When making a left turn onto a four-lane roadway, finish the turn in the far right lane.
questions.explanation: You may only make a left turn at a red light when turning from a one-way street onto another one-way street. You should complete a left turn into the legal lane nearest to your previous lane.

questions.question: At a railroad crossing, you must:
questions.answerA: Watch for vehicles that must stop at all railroad crossings (school buses, trucks carrying hazardous materials, etc.).
questions.answerB: Watch for multiple trains.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: You must approach all railroad crossings with extreme caution and cross only when you know that no train is coming from either direction. Be aware of vehicles that must stop at all railroad crossings, such as school buses and trucks carrying hazardous materials.

questions.question: If you are driving near a motorcycle, you must:
questions.answerA: Allow the motorcycle to use a complete lane.
questions.answerB: Drive on the shoulder beside the motorcycle.
questions.answerC: Allow the motorcycle to use only half of a lane.
questions.answerD: Pass using the same lane as the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle is a full-size vehicle with the same privileges as any other vehicle on the roadway. You should allow a motorcyclist a full lane width. Although it may seem as though there is enough room in the traffic lane for a larger vehicle and a motorcycle, remember that the motorcycle needs room to maneuver safely.

questions.question: You hit a parked vehicle and can't find the owner. What must you do?
questions.answerA: Call your insurance company when you get home.
questions.answerB: Wait for the owner to return.
questions.answerC: Leave a note with your name and address on the parked vehicle.
questions.explanation: If you hit a parked vehicle or other property, you must leave a note with your name, phone number, and address securely attached to the vehicle or property that you hit.

questions.question: Regulatory signs are:
questions.answerA: Green.
questions.answerB: Yellow.
questions.answerC: White.
questions.explanation: Regulatory signs inform drivers of specific laws that must be obeyed. Displayed laws may be about traffic direction, lane use, turning, speed, parking, or special situations. Regulatory signs are commonly white squares or rectangles with black, red, or green letters or symbols.

questions.question: Guide signs are ____ signs that provide directional and mileage information to drivers.
questions.answerA: Yellow
questions.answerB: Red
questions.answerC: Green
questions.explanation: Guide signs, sometimes known as destination signs, have a green background and provide directional and mileage information to specific destinations. They can be a helpful resource when driving in unfamiliar locations.

questions.question: If there is no crosswalk and you see a pedestrian crossing your lane, you should:
questions.answerA: Make sure the pedestrian can see you before proceeding.
questions.answerB: Cautiously drive around the pedestrian.
questions.answerC: Stop and let the pedestrian finish crossing.
questions.explanation: Drivers must always yield the right-of-way to pedestrians in the roadway, even if there is not a marked crosswalk.

questions.question: When approaching an accident scene, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep your attention on your driving.
questions.answerB: Keep moving.
questions.answerC: Stop if you are involved or if emergency help has not yet arrived.
questions.explanation: Do not stop at an accident scene unless you are involved or emergency help has not yet arrived. Keep your attention on your driving and keep moving, watching for people who might be on or near the road. Never drive to the scene of an accident, fire, or other disaster just to look.

questions.question: Driving more slowly than surrounding traffic is:
questions.answerA: A good idea if the weather is bad.
questions.answerB: Appropriate if you don’t know the speed limit.
questions.answerC: Often a hazard because other drivers may become frustrated and try to pass you.
questions.explanation: Driving more slowly than other traffic can be dangerous. Drivers behind you may become impatient and will be tempted to take dangerous risks to pass you.

questions.question: When you see a sign indicating your chosen exit point, you should:
questions.answerA: Signal and move into the exit lane.
questions.answerB: Reduce your speed to the posted exit speed once you are within the deceleration lane.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: When you see a sign indicating that your exit is approaching, begin preparing for it. Signal and move into the exit lane as soon as you reach it. Once you are in the deceleration lane, reduce your speed gradually and slow to the posted exit speed.

questions.question: A U-turn is not permitted:
questions.answerA: In a parking lot.
questions.answerB: On or near any curve or hill.
questions.answerC: On a straight roadway with a clear view for 500 feet in both directions.
questions.explanation: You must never turn around while on or near any curve or hill. You may not be able to see oncoming traffic or pedestrians and may cause a collision.

questions.question: If you must park your vehicle in an area not usually used for parking:
questions.answerA: Park with your reverse lights on.
questions.answerB: Make sure your vehicle is visible to drivers approaching from any direction.
questions.answerC: Park five feet from the curb.
questions.explanation: Drivers are responsible for making sure their vehicles do not become hazards after they have been parked. Wherever you park, make sure your car is visible to drivers approaching from any direction.

questions.question: You come to an intersection with a flashing red light. You must:
questions.answerA: Slow down and drive carefully through the  intersection.
questions.answerB: Turn either right or left, since the road is blocked ahead.
questions.answerC: Stop at the intersection and wait for a flashing green light.
questions.answerD: Stop at the intersection, then proceed as traffic allows.
questions.explanation: A flashing red light means that you must come to a full stop, and then proceed when the way is clear.

questions.question: If you are about to be hit from the rear, you should not:
questions.answerA: Release your seat belt.
questions.answerB: Brace yourself.
questions.answerC: Press your head against the head restraint.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle is hit from the rear while you are in forward motion, your body will be thrown backward. Brace yourself by pressing against the back of your seat and putting your head against the head restraint to prevent whiplash. Maintain a firm grip on the steering wheel and be ready to apply your brakes to avoid being pushed into another vehicle.

questions.question: The most common mistake that drivers make when backing is failing to look both ways behind them.
questions.answerA: True
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: The most common mistake that drivers make when backing up is failing to look both ways behind them. Mirrors do not give you a full view. To see as much as possible, turn your body and head to the right and look through the rear window.

questions.question: To prepare for anything coming up on the road ahead, you should:
questions.answerA: Continually scan the entire road and all roadsides.
questions.answerB: Stare straight ahead at all times.
questions.answerC: Drive with your left foot resting lightly on the brake pedal.
questions.answerD: Maintain focus toward the middle of the road.
questions.explanation: Your ability to handle dangerous traffic situations depends largely on searching for and identifying problems before meeting them. Looking far ahead of your vehicle does not mean you should simply stare at the center of the road. You need to continually scan the entire road, including the sides of the road.

questions.question: You are approaching a railroad crossing that has no visible gates or flashing lights, but has a standard crossbuck. You should:
questions.answerA: Approach all tracks with extreme caution and cross only when you know that there is no train coming.
questions.answerB: Turn your radio down to hear if there may be an approaching train.
questions.answerC: Only continue once cleared to do so by a flagger, if applicable.
questions.explanation: You must approach all railroad crossings with extreme caution and cross only when you know that no train is coming from either direction. If there is a flagger at a crossing, you must obey all of their instructions.

questions.question: To improve visibility lowered by rain or fog, drivers should use their:
questions.answerA: Low beam headlights.
questions.answerB: High beam headlights.
questions.answerC: Parking lights.
questions.explanation: Low beam headlights should be used when driving in rainy or foggy weather. Even if they do little to help you see, low beams will make it easier for others to see you.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Sharp turn ahead, slow down.
questions.answerB: Work crew ahead.
questions.answerC: Side road.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers that there is an upcoming sharp turn and that they should lower their speed accordingly.

questions.question: You are approaching an intersection with a steady yellow traffic light. If you have not already entered the intersection, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up to beat the red light.
questions.answerB: Reduce you speed and proceed carefully through the intersection.
questions.answerC: Come to a safe stop.
questions.explanation: When a steady yellow light appears on a traffic signal, you should prepare to stop. If you are already within the intersection, you should clear the intersection as quickly as possible.

questions.question: Before starting a parked vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Check the fuel gauge, adjust the volume on the radio, and shift gears.
questions.answerB: Adjust the side mirror and make sure your heater works.
questions.answerC: Adjust the seat, adjust the mirrors, and fasten your safety belt.
questions.explanation: Walk all the way around your vehicle to check for obstacles before getting in. Before starting the engine, fasten your safety belt and make sure that your seat and mirrors are in safe positions.

questions.question: What message will be found on this yellow pennant-shaped sign?
questions.answerA: Right turns only.
questions.answerB: Right turns permitted.
questions.answerC: No passing zone.
questions.explanation: Pennant-shaped yellow signs like this are used to indicate a no passing zone.

questions.question: The best way to deal with tailgaters is to:
questions.answerA: Speed up to increase the distance between you and the tailgater.
questions.answerB: Slam on your brakes to get the other driver to back off.
questions.answerC: Change lanes or gradually slow down to encourage them to pass.
questions.explanation: Check the traffic behind you several times a minute to know if another driver is tailgating, approaching too fast, or trying to pass. If another car is following you too closely, slow down and let it pass. Most rear-end collisions are caused by vehicles following too closely.

questions.question: When using roundabouts or traffic circles, you should:
questions.answerA: Slow down as you approach the circle.
questions.answerB: Yield to any traffic, pedestrians, or bicyclists already in the circle.
questions.answerC: Enter to the right, but steer left in a counterclockwise direction.
questions.explanation: You should slow down as you approach a roundabout and yield to any vehicles, bicycles, or pedestrians already in the circle. Enter the circle to your right, but steer to your left so that you move around the circle in a counterclockwise direction.

questions.question: The driver's left arm and hand are extended downward. This hand signal means that the driver plans to:
questions.answerA: Turn left.
questions.answerB: Turn right.
questions.answerC: Stop.
questions.explanation: If a driver's left arm and hand are extended downward, they are indicating that they intend to stop. Adjust your driving accordingly if following a driver who is using this hand signal.

questions.question: To prevent hydroplaning, you should:
questions.answerA: Ensure that your tires have good tread depth.
questions.answerB: Ensure that your tires are properly inflated.
questions.answerC: Reduce your speed when driving in the rain.
questions.explanation: To prevent hydroplaning, you should ensure that the tires on your vehicle have good tread depth and are inflated to the proper pressure. Reduce the speed of your vehicle when driving in the rain. Hydroplaning occurs most frequently at higher speeds.

questions.question: Having a driver license is a:
questions.answerA: Right, not a privilege.
questions.answerB: Privilege, not a right.
questions.answerC: Requirement.
questions.explanation: Holding a driver license is not a right. It is a privilege that must be earned and maintained.

questions.question: When making a right turn on a green light, you must:
questions.answerA: Maintain your normal driving speed.
questions.answerB: Stop and look for nearby police cars.
questions.answerC: Yield to pedestrians.
questions.explanation: Unless a posted sign prohibits it, you may turn right or left at a steady green light. When turning, you must yield to other vehicles and pedestrians within the intersection.

questions.question: When driving in fog, you should use your high beam headlights.
questions.answerA: TRUE
questions.answerB: FALSE
questions.explanation: You should use your low beam headlights when driving in fog. High beam headlights may cause the light to reflect off of the fog and into your eyes.

questions.question: When you see other drivers around you acting or reacting in anger:
questions.answerA: Don’t make eye contact.
questions.answerB: Don't react with hand gestures.
questions.answerC: Distance yourself from the situation.
questions.explanation: When other drivers are behaving angrily, you should take action to physically and mentally distance yourself from the situation. Avoid making eye contact with them, or making body movements or gestures that could provoke them. Slow down, move over, or do whatever you safely can to put yourself out of danger.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: The road ahead curves right. Slow down to the safe speed indicated.
questions.answerB: Divided highway begins. Slow down to the safe speed indicated.
questions.answerC: Merge. Slow down to the safe speed indicated.
questions.answerD: Winding road ahead. Slow down to the safe speed indicated.
questions.explanation: These signs indicate that the road curves to the right ahead and that drivers should slow down to the safe speed indicated (in this case, 35 mph).

questions.question: Double solid yellow lines painted down the middle of the road mean:
questions.answerA: Railroad crossing ahead.
questions.answerB: Pedestrian crossing ahead.
questions.answerC: Passing is not permitted from either direction.
questions.answerD: Passing is permitted from either direction.
questions.explanation: Double solid yellow lines in the center of the road mean that passing is not allowed from either direction. You may not cross the lines unless you are making a left turn or passing pedestrians, bicyclists, and riders of scooters or skateboards when the opposite lane is clear and you can pass safely.

questions.question: Because driving involves some risk, it is wise to continually improve your driving and observation skills.
questions.answerA: True
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: Driving can become unsafe if drivers believe they have nothing to improve. For your safety and the safety of others, always strive to improve your driving and observation skills.

questions.question: Which of the following driving skills is/are affected by the use of alcohol and/or drugs?
questions.answerA: Alertness.
questions.answerB: Coordination.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: Alcohol and other drugs can negatively effect a number of skills needed for safe driving, including a driver's reaction time, coordination, alertness, and ability to concentrate.

questions.question: When being passed by another vehicle:
questions.answerA: Brake hard.
questions.answerB: Maintain a constant speed.
questions.answerC: Speed up.
questions.explanation: When being passed, you must yield to the passing vehicle and not increase your speed. Allow the vehicle to safely merge back into your lane.

questions.question: This sign means that:
questions.answerA: A community service group is picking up trash along the highway ahead.
questions.answerB: Workers are on or very close to the road in the work zone ahead.
questions.answerC: Children are at play ahead.
questions.answerD: There is a pedestrian crosswalk ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that workers may be on or very close to the roadway ahead, so you should take special care when traveling through the area.

questions.question: You are making a left turn from a two-way street onto a one-way street. When you have completed the turn, your car should be:
questions.answerA: In the right lane of the street.
questions.answerB: In the center of the street.
questions.answerC: In the left lane of the street.
questions.answerD: In the lane with the least traffic.
questions.explanation: If you are turning left from a two-way street onto a one-way street, you should complete the turn into the lane closest to the lane you have just left.

questions.question: This sign is used to warn drivers:
questions.answerA: That the right lane ends and traffic should merge left.
questions.answerB: That the road curves ahead.
questions.answerC: About upcoming intersections.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the right lane on a multilane roadway ends ahead. Traffic in the right lane must merge left.

questions.question: What kinds of drugs can affect your driving ability?
questions.answerA: Allergy medicine
questions.answerB: Marijuana
questions.answerC: Cold remedies
questions.explanation: Many kinds of drugs can impair your ability to drive. This includes illegal drugs and legal prescription or over-the-counter medications. It can be a criminal offense to drive while impaired by any drug.

questions.question: Coming to a complete stop at an intersection, yielding to cross traffic/pedestrians, and then proceeding through the intersection when the way is clear corresponds with:
questions.answerA: A solid red light.
questions.answerB: A flashing yellow light.
questions.answerC: A solid green light.
questions.explanation: A flashing red traffic light means the same thing as a stop sign. You must come to a complete stop, yield to cross traffic and pedestrians, and then proceed when the way is clear.

questions.question: Which statement about right-of-way laws is true?
questions.answerA: If two vehicles begin to enter an intersection at the same time, the vehicle on the left has the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: When turning left at an intersection, you may turn before oncoming traffic passes.
questions.answerC: You may make a right turn in front of a crossing pedestrian.
questions.answerD: You should never demand the right-of-way.
questions.explanation: You should never demand the right-of-way. Laws do not specify who has the right-of-way, only who does not. At a four-way stop, if multiple drivers arrive at once, the driver on the left should yield the right-of-way to the driver on the right. Drivers should yield to oncoming traffic and pedestrians when turning right or left.

questions.question: When you are facing a green light and there are pedestrians in the intersection:
questions.answerA: You must yield the right-of-way to pedestrians.
questions.answerB: You have the right-of-way over pedestrians.
questions.answerC: Pedestrians must wait for you to cross.
questions.explanation: When facing a green light, you must yield to pedestrians and vehicles already in the intersection. Drivers must yield to pedestrians when turning on a steady green signal.

questions.question: When passing another car, you have enough space to return to the driving lane:
questions.answerA: If the other driver signals for you to re-enter the lane.
questions.answerB: If you look over your shoulder and see the passed car behind you.
questions.answerC: If you can see both of the passed vehicle's headlights in your rearview mirror.
questions.explanation: Before you return to the driving lane when completing a pass, be sure there is a safe gap between your vehicle and the passed vehicle. When you can see both headlights of the vehicle in your rearview mirror, it is safe to return to the driving lane.

questions.question: Only ____ can lower blood alcohol concentration (BAC) and reduce alcohol's effects on a body.
questions.answerA: Drinking caffeine
questions.answerB: Eating foods high in fat
questions.answerC: Time
questions.explanation: The only way to sober up after drinking alcohol is to allow time for your body to eliminate the alcohol in your system. Nothing you can do, including eating and drinking, can accelerate this process.

questions.question: Highway pavement will be particularly treacherous and most slippery:
questions.answerA: If it has been raining several hours.
questions.answerB: If it has just begun to rain.
questions.answerC: If it has been raining for one to two hours.
questions.explanation: Pavement is particularly treacherous when it first begins to rain. Accumulations of dirt and oil mix with the rainwater, creating a greasy film on the roadway.

questions.question: You are driving too slowly if you:
questions.answerA: Are driving at speeds slower than 40 mph on any highway.
questions.answerB: Do not pass other cars often.
questions.answerC: Block other vehicles moving at normal, safe speeds.
questions.explanation: You must never drive so slowly that you interfere with other cars or trucks that are moving at a normal speed.

questions.question: Compared to driving during the day, driving at night is:
questions.answerA: Less dangerous.
questions.answerB: No more or less dangerous.
questions.answerC: More dangerous.
questions.explanation: Driving at night is more dangerous than driving during the day for several reasons. It is harder to see in the dark, you may be temporarily blinded by the glare from other vehicles' lights, and there are likely to be more drivers on the road who are tired or under the influence.

questions.question: When a car with bright headlights drives toward you at night, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop until the other driver passes.
questions.answerB: Look below their headlights.
questions.answerC: Glance toward the right edge of your lane.
questions.explanation: To avoid being blinded when driving at night, do not look directly at the headlights of oncoming cars. Instead, look toward the right edge of the road until the oncoming driver has passed.

questions.question: When your wheels run off the pavement, you should:
questions.answerA: Hit the breaks hard.
questions.answerB: Grip the steering wheel firmly, begin to slow down, then move slowly back onto the road surface.
questions.answerC: Hit the brakes firmly and jerk the steering wheel hard to pull the vehicle onto the road surface as quickly as possible.
questions.explanation: If one or more of your wheels run off of the pavement, grip the steering wheel firmly and slow down by taking your foot off the accelerator. Do not attempt to cut back sharply onto the pavement. Instead, look to see that the road is clear, then move slowly back onto the highway.

questions.question: When driving through a neighborhood, the speed limit is usually 30 mph.
questions.answerA: True
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: The maximum speed limit in an urban or residential area is usually 30 miles per hour.

questions.question: To safely pass a bicycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Honk at the bicyclist to let them know you're trying to pass.
questions.answerB: Drive in the bicycle lane until you get a chance to pass.
questions.answerC: Slow down and give them as much space as possible.
questions.answerD: Rush ahead to pull in front of the bicyclist.
questions.explanation: When passing a bicyclist, slow down and give them as much space as you can. Bicyclists have much less protection than drivers of motor vehicles and they should not be crowded. Passing a bicycle too quickly can shift the bicyclist off-course.

questions.question: When you drive through an area where children are playing, you should expect them:
questions.answerA: To know when it is safe to cross the street.
questions.answerB: To stop at the curb before crossing the street.
questions.answerC: To run out in front of you without looking.
questions.answerD: Not to cross the street unless they are with an adult.
questions.explanation: You should always reduce your speed and use extra caution when children are in the vicinity. They may fail to understand the danger and may run out in front of you without looking.

questions.question: Just like alcohol and other drugs, drowsiness can:
questions.answerA: Help you to be a better driver.
questions.answerB: Make you feel better.
questions.answerC: Impair your judgment.
questions.explanation: Not getting enough sleep is a cause of poor driving behavior. Just like drugs and alcohol, sleepiness slows reaction time, decreases awareness, and impairs judgment.

questions.question: While driving at night, you may use your parking lights instead of headlights.
questions.answerA: True
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: It is unlawful to drive at night using only your parking lights. You must use your headlights when driving in lowered visibility.

questions.question: What is a potential effect of taking a prescription drug while drinking alcohol?
questions.answerA: There will likely be no effect.
questions.answerB: It will make you more alert.
questions.answerC: It can make you unfit to drive.
questions.explanation: Legal medications, both prescription and over-the-counter, can impair your ability to drive. They can be particularly dangerous when used in combination with alcohol.

questions.question: Which statement is true?
questions.answerA: The speed at which you are traveling affects almost everything else that can happen to you in a car.
questions.answerB: Heavy traffic situations do not affect speed.
questions.answerC: It is always permissible to drive the posted speed limit.
questions.explanation: The speed at which you are traveling affects almost everything else that can happen to you in a car. You must always comply with posted speed limits. Heavy traffic conditions and poor weather conditions require a slower speed.

questions.question: A red traffic signal light means that you must:
questions.answerA: Stop at the stop line.
questions.answerB: Stop before entering any crosswalk.
questions.answerC: Stop before entering the intersection.
questions.explanation: A red traffic light means that you must stop before entering the intersection. You must at any stop line and before entering any crosswalk.

questions.question: Distracted drivers are at a greater risk of a crash when they are using which of the following?
questions.answerA: CD player
questions.answerB: Radio
questions.answerC: Cell phone
questions.explanation: Using a cell phone (including a hands-free phone) or any kind of audio device (including a radio or CD player) can be a dangerous distraction and contributes to the risk of a crash.

questions.question: If a truck or bus is making a right turn where you also need to make a right turn, you should:
questions.answerA: Quickly turn before the truck or bus is able to.
questions.answerB: Wait until the truck or bus turns before you turn.
questions.answerC: Squeeze between the truck or bus and the curb.
questions.explanation: If you try to insert your vehicle between a turning truck or bus and a curb, you may suffer a serious crash. To avoid a collision, do not turn until the truck or bus has completed its turn.

questions.question: When you see this sign, you:
questions.answerA: Are approaching a railroad crossing and should prepare to stop.
questions.answerB: Will always stop at the upcoming railroad crossing.
questions.answerC: Should stop and wait for a signal before crossing the railroad tracks.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that you are approaching a railroad crossing. You must look, listen, slow down, and prepare to stop. Wait for any trains to pass before you proceed.

questions.question: Is it legal cross a double solid yellow centerline to pass?
questions.answerA: Yes.
questions.answerB: No.
questions.answerC: If there is no oncoming traffic.
questions.answerD: If the vehicle ahead of you is driving under the speed limit.
questions.explanation: Two solid yellow lines down the center of a two-way road mean that neither lane of traffic may cross the lines, unless they are turning off of the roadway. A driver can cross double yellow lines when turning into or out of a driveway or entrance to a business. No passing is allowed over a solid yellow line.

questions.question: Taking drugs along with alcohol:
questions.answerA: Increases the risk of causing a crash.
questions.answerB: Is no more dangerous than consuming alcohol by itself.
questions.answerC: Lessens the effect of alcohol on your ability to drive.
questions.answerD: Has no effect on your general driving ability.
questions.explanation: Drugs (including illegal, prescription, and over-the-counter medications) can affect your brain function and impair your ability to drive safely. Combining alcohol with other drugs will increase the risk of a crash.

questions.question: As you approach an intersection with a flashing yellow light:
questions.answerA: Stop before crossing the intersection.
questions.answerB: Slow down and proceed with caution.
questions.answerC: Wait for a green light before proceeding.
questions.explanation: A flashing yellow light means that you should slow down, check for cross traffic, and proceed with caution.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: One-way traffic.
questions.answerB: Two-way left turn.
questions.answerC: Two-way traffic.
questions.explanation: Regulation signs regulate traffic speed and movement, displaying rules which drivers must obey. This sign tells drivers the direction in which they must drive when turning onto a one-way street.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Road widens ahead.
questions.answerB: Lane reduction. The right lane ends soon and traffic should merge left.
questions.answerC: Highway entrance ramp ahead.
questions.explanation: A warning sign is usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns that the number of lanes ahead is reduced and that traffic will need to merge to the left.

questions.question: When entering an interstate highway, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop, check for cars, and enter when safe.
questions.answerB: Check for cars and reduce your speed to 25 mph before entering the traffic lane.
questions.answerC: Check for cars, increase your speed to match the flow of traffic, and merge when the way is clear.
questions.explanation: Rather than stopping (as you would when entering other roads), you must use the merging or acceleration lane to speed up and smoothly merge with fast-moving traffic already on the interstate.

questions.question: In a vehicle equipped with airbags, the safest place for children age 12 and under to ride is in:
questions.answerA: The front seat.
questions.answerB: The back seat.
questions.answerC: The bed of a pick-up truck.
questions.explanation: While airbags provide supplemental protection for adults in the event of a crash, they pose a severe safety risk for children. Anyone age 12 or under should sit in the back seat of a vehicle with airbags.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about steering a vehicle is true?
questions.answerA: Both hands should be placed on the outside of the steering wheel.
questions.answerB: Never steer with just one hand, unless you are backing or operating a vehicle control (wiper, flashers, lights, etc.) that requires a temporary reach from the steering wheel.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: You should steer with one hand only when backing up or operating a vehicle control. Your hands should be placed on the outside of the steering wheel on opposite sides with your thumbs facing up.

questions.question: A distraction when driving is:
questions.answerA: Anything that causes evasive action while driving.
questions.answerB: Anything that takes your attention away from driving.
questions.answerC: Anything that causes you to pay more attention to driving.
questions.explanation: A distraction when driving is anything that takes your attention away from driving. Driver distractions may occur anytime and anywhere. Distracted driving can cause collisions, resulting in property damage, injury, and death.

questions.question: On slippery roads, you should:
questions.answerA: Slow down.
questions.answerB: Drive more quickly.
questions.answerC: Drive the speed limit, with caution.
questions.answerD: Not drive more quickly than 20 mph.
