questions.explanation: You should slow down at the first sign of rain, snow, or sleet, all of which can create slippery road conditions. When conditions on the road are less than ideal, safety may require that you drive more slowly than the posted speed limit.

questions.question: You are involved in a minor collision at an intersection. There are no injuries and there is very little vehicle damage. You should:
questions.answerA: Leave your vehicle in the traffic lane until law enforcement arrives.
questions.answerB: Move your vehicle out of the traffic lane, if possible.
questions.answerC: Not move your vehicle for any reason.
questions.explanation: After a collision, if no one has been injured or killed and you can safely do so, you should move your vehicle out of the traffic lane.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Pedestrian crossing.
questions.answerB: School crossing.
questions.answerC: Jogging trail.
questions.explanation: Warning signs provide notice to road users of a situation that might not be readily apparent and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign tells drivers to be alert to crossing pedestrians.

questions.question: This road sign indicates:
questions.answerA: The maximum safe speed for a residential area.
questions.answerB: The maximum safe speed for an expressway exit.
questions.answerC: The maximum safe speed for an expressway entrance.
questions.answerD: The maximum safe speed for a work zone.
questions.explanation: This advisory speed sign indicates the maximum safe speed for a highway exit (in this example, 30 mph).

questions.question: When stopped for a traffic violation or at an equipment check, the driver must produce:
questions.answerA: Proof of insurance.
questions.answerB: Their license.
questions.answerC: Proof of registration.
questions.explanation: When stopped for a traffic violation or at an equipment check, the driver is responsible for producing their license, proof of registration, and proof of insurance. Drivers are required to have all three of these documents in a vehicle when it is being driven.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Curves ahead.
questions.answerB: Divided highway starts.
questions.answerC: Divided highway ends.
questions.explanation: This sign warns drivers that the divided highway ends ahead.

questions.question: Slowing down just to look at collisions or anything else out-of-the-ordinary:
questions.answerA: Causes traffic congestion.
questions.answerB: Prevents rear-end collisions.
questions.answerC: Improves traffic flow by preventing collisions.
questions.explanation: Avoid "rubbernecking," or slowing down to look at collisions or anything else out-of-the-ordinary. This helps to relieve traffic congestion.

questions.question: If you need to drive in foggy weather:
questions.answerA: Turn on your low beam headlights.
questions.answerB: Turn on your hazard lights.
questions.answerC: It is okay to drive at the maximum speed limit.
questions.answerD: Do not drive at a speed above 10 miles per hour.
questions.explanation: You are required to use your headlights during the day when visibility is reduced to 500 feet or less. When you first turn on your headlights, be sure they are adjusted to the low beam setting. Using high beams in fog or rain will cause the light to reflect back into your eyes, lowering visibility even more.

questions.question: You must stop at a railroad crossing when:
questions.answerA: Directed to do so by a flagger.
questions.answerB: It is controlled by a stop sign.
questions.answerC: Flashing red signals and gates are present and operating.
questions.explanation: You must stop at a railroad crossing when directed to do so by a flagger or stop sign. Stop when flashing red signals and gates are present and operating.

questions.question: A telltale sign of a drunk driver is:
questions.answerA: They are weaving between lanes.
questions.answerB: They are driving more slowly than the normal traffic flow.
questions.answerC: They are making quick and sudden stops.
questions.explanation: Telltale signs of drunk driving include speeding, weaving, driving more slowly than the normal traffic flow, making jerking motions, and making quick and sudden stops.

questions.question: When driving past a vehicle that has just stopped in a parked position on the side of the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume that the driver will open the car door as you approach.
questions.answerB: Speed up.
questions.answerC: Slam on your brakes.
questions.answerD: Assume that the driver will wait for you to pass before opening the door.
questions.explanation: When passing a vehicle that has just parked parallel to the road, you should assume the driver will open the door as you approach. Use extra caution when driving near parked vehicles.

questions.question: When should drivers yield the right-of-way to pedestrians in a crosswalk?
questions.answerA: Only if the pedestrians first wave to the driver.
questions.answerB: Only if the pedestrians are not texting while walking.
questions.answerC: At all times.
questions.explanation: Bring your vehicle to a complete stop at a crosswalk to yield the right-of-way to any vehicle or pedestrian already in the intersection. You may carefully proceed if your lane is completely clear.

questions.question: If you miss your exit on the freeway, you should not:
questions.answerA: Continue on the freeway and find an alternate route to your destination.
questions.answerB: Proceed to the next exit, leave the freeway, and return to your proper exit.
questions.answerC: Back up on the road or shoulder.
questions.explanation: If you miss your turn or exit, do not back up in the travel lane or on the shoulder. Continue to drive to the next exit or crossroad. Drivers do not expect a vehicle to be backing toward them on the roadway and doing so will likely cause a collision.

questions.question: When driving under low-visibility conditions due to fog, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn on your high beam headlights.
questions.answerB: Slow down and use your low beam headlights.
questions.answerC: Increase your speed so you do not cause an accident.
questions.explanation: When driving in fog, you should slow down and use your low beam lights. If the fog is so dense that you cannot see, pull off the road and wait for the fog to clear.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true?
questions.answerA: Trucks have larger blind spots than passenger vehicles.
questions.answerB: Always avoid driving beside a large truck for long periods of time.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: Trucks have large blind spots that start behind the cab and extend for the length of the truck. Because the truck driver will not be able to see you, you should avoid driving beside or behind a large vehicle for long periods of time.

questions.question: When you are parallel parking, it is usually best to:
questions.answerA: Give a right signal on the approach, drive past the space and stop, then back into the space.
questions.answerB: Park your vehicle within 18 inches of the curb or edge of the road.
questions.answerC: Center your vehicle inside the space to give surrounding cars room to maneuver.
questions.explanation: When parallel parking, turn on your right signal and stop, pulling even with the car in front of where you want to park, then back into the space. Park within 18 inches of the curb or edge of the road. Be sure to center your car in the space to allow surrounding vehicles room to maneuver.

questions.question: Before you change lanes, you should check your mirrors and:
questions.answerA: Never look over your right shoulder.
questions.answerB: Always slow down in your traffic lane.
questions.answerC: Glance over your shoulder.
questions.explanation: Before changing lanes, it is very important to check behind you. You should look over your shoulder to ensure that you are not getting in the way of vehicles in the lane you want to enter. Before changing lanes, you should also ensure that no drivers are attempting to drive into the same spot from a different lane.

questions.question: A steady red arrow displayed on a traffic light means:
questions.answerA: Drivers cannot turn in the indicated direction.
questions.answerB: Drivers may turn in the indicated direction after coming to a complete stop.
questions.answerC: Drivers may turn in the indicated direction.
questions.explanation: If a traffic signal is displaying a steady red arrow, traffic in the indicated lane may not proceed in the direction shown by the arrow. Drivers must come to a full stop and wait for a green signal to proceed.

questions.question: This sign shows one type of:
questions.answerA: Intersection.
questions.answerB: Road curve.
questions.answerC: Right turn.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. They alert you to conditions that are immediately ahead. This sign warns drivers that another road crosses the highway ahead.

questions.question: Before switching on the ignition, you should:
questions.answerA: Be sure only backseat passengers have buckled their seat belts.
questions.answerB: Be sure only adult passengers have buckled their seat belts.
questions.answerC: Be sure only child passengers have buckled their seat belts.
questions.answerD: Be sure all of the vehicle's occupants have buckled their seat belts.
questions.explanation: Develop a routine for entering and leaving your car. Before switching on the ignition, buckle your safety belt and see that all passengers do likewise.

questions.question: You are crossing an intersection and an emergency vehicle is approaching while using its siren and flashing lights. You should:
questions.answerA: Stop immediately in the intersection until it passes.
questions.answerB: Pull to the right of the intersection and stop.
questions.answerC: Continue through the intersection, pull to the right, and stop.
questions.explanation: If you are in an intersection when you see an emergency vehicle approaching while using its flashing lights and/or siren, continue through the intersection and then drive to the right and stop. You must yield the right-of-way to any police vehicle, fire engine, ambulance, or other emergency vehicle using a siren or flashing lights.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Upcoming downgrade or hill.
questions.answerB: Road construction area.
questions.answerC: Upcoming narrowing of roadway.
questions.explanation: This sign warns of a dangerous downgrade or hill ahead. The hill may be very long or steep, or it may have sharp curves.

questions.question: When you are backing up, it is usually best to:
questions.answerA: Steer with one hand while looking into the rearview mirror.
questions.answerB: Open the driver side door and look back.
questions.answerC: Steer with both hands while looking into the side view mirror.
questions.answerD: Steer with one hand while looking over your shoulder through the rear window.
questions.explanation: Turn your head to look behind you before and while backing up. Steer with one hand when backing up or when operating vehicle controls. You should keep both hands on the wheel at any other time.

questions.question: Lanes of traffic moving in the same direction are divided by ____ lines.
questions.answerA: Yellow
questions.answerB: White
questions.answerC: Red
questions.explanation: Solid white lines are used to separate lanes traveling in the same direction (as well as to mark the right edge of the road). Broken white lines separate lanes traveling in the same direction and may be crossed to pass. Yellow lines separate lanes of traffic moving in opposite directions.

questions.question: Which is not a factor in determining the distance that it takes to stop your vehicle?
questions.answerA: Steering ability
questions.answerB: Braking distance
questions.answerC: Reaction distance
questions.explanation: The distance required to stop your vehicle depends on perception time, reaction distance, and braking distance. This changes with speed and road conditions.

questions.question: If you want to make a three-point turnabout and there is traffic approaching, you should:
questions.answerA: Begin the turnabout right away.
questions.answerB: Flash your headlights and begin the turnabout.
questions.answerC: Yield to oncoming traffic coming from all directions before performing the maneuver.
questions.explanation: When you make a three-point turn, all approaching traffic has the right-of-way. Only perform a turnabout when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: As you are driving on a two-lane highway, you approach a school bus that is stopped with its red lights flashing. You:
questions.answerA: May pass if the way is clear.
questions.answerB: May pass if a pedestrian indicates that the way is clear.
questions.answerC: May not pass until the school bus driver turns off the flashing lights and continues driving.
questions.answerD: Must turn on your emergency flashers.
questions.explanation: Drivers are required to stop for a stopped school bus when driving on a two-lane road, regardless of which direction they are traveling.

questions.question: Sudden wind gusts on highways:
questions.answerA: Generally affect only the movement of large vehicles.
questions.answerB: Only cause visibility problems.
questions.answerC: Can cause problems for all vehicles.
questions.explanation: While it can create special problems for large vehicles, strong wind can cause problems for all drivers. Wind can lower visibility by blowing dirt and dust into the roadway, but it can sometimes also physically move a vehicle.

questions.question: Extra space in front of a large truck is needed for:
questions.answerA: Other drivers to merge onto the freeway.
questions.answerB: The truck driver to stop the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Other drivers when they want to slow down.
questions.explanation: Because they are larger, trucks take longer to stop than cars traveling at the same speed. Other drivers should not pull in front of a truck and then slow down or stop.

questions.question: If a vehicle is equipped with airbags:
questions.answerA: Seat belts should still be worn.
questions.answerB: Seat belts do not need to be worn.
questions.answerC: Seat belts should be worn behind the back.
questions.explanation: Airbags are important safety devices that provide protection in crashes. For best protection, a vehicle's lap and shoulder belts should be used in combination with airbags.

questions.question: Allowing a space cushion between your vehicle and its surroundings is important because it:
questions.answerA: Prevents distractions from other vehicles.
questions.answerB: Allows you time to react to unexpected situations.
questions.answerC: Keeps traffic flowing at a safe pace.
questions.explanation: The only way to be sure you will have enough time to react to mistakes made by other drivers is to leave plenty of space between you and the vehicles around you.

questions.question: To change lanes you should:
questions.answerA: Check your mirrors and signal, then change lanes.
questions.answerB: Signal, check your mirrors, check your blind spot in the direction you plan to move, then change lanes.
questions.answerC: Signal, check your mirrors, and change lanes.
questions.explanation: Before changing lanes, you should activate your turn signal in the appropriate direction and check your rearview and side mirrors. Look over your shoulder in the direction you plan to move in order to check your blind spot and check the far lane to be sure no one else is trying to enter the same lane as you. Change lanes when you are sure it is safe to do so.

questions.question: You are entering a crowded freeway. What should you do to merge into traffic?
questions.answerA: Use your side and rearview mirrors and check your blind spots.
questions.answerB: Use the acceleration lane to adjust your speed to match the speed of freeway traffic.
questions.answerC: Yield to traffic already on the freeway.
questions.explanation: Use the entrance ramp to accelerate to the speed of freeway traffic and yield to traffic already using the freeway. Before entering traffic, use your mirrors and check your blind spots to verify that you have room to safely merge.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true?
questions.answerA: You should maintain at least a three- to four-second following distance under normal conditions.
questions.answerB: As speed increases, following distance should decrease.
questions.answerC: Following distances are only important on snow and ice.
questions.explanation: When following another vehicle on any street under normal driving conditions, maintain a three or four second gap between your vehicle and the vehicle in front of you. If any unusual conditions exist, such as rainy weather or increased traffic, increase your following distance.

questions.question: As a pedestrian, you should:
questions.answerA: Always insist on the right-of-way over a vehicle when using a crosswalk.
questions.answerB: Never enter a street or crosswalk when vehicles are approaching.
questions.answerC: Enter a crosswalk at any time because it is the vehicle driver’s responsibility to stop.
questions.answerD: Use crosswalks only if they are convenient.
questions.explanation: Pedestrians should not enter a street or crosswalk when vehicles are approaching. Though pedestrians have the right-of-way in crosswalks, a vehicle approaching from a close distance may not have the time to stop before entering the crosswalk.

questions.question: Which statement about tires is true?
questions.answerA: Tires must have good tread and be free of damage.
questions.answerB: Tires with low air pressure provide a smoother ride.
questions.answerC: Over-inflated tires do not skid on wet pavement.
questions.explanation: The tires on your vehicle must have good tread and be free of damage. Inspect the condition of your tires regularly.

questions.question: When you approach a railroad crossing without flashing warning signals or crossing gates, you should:
questions.answerA: Cross the tracks immediately and as quickly as possible.
questions.answerB: Always stop before crossing the tracks.
questions.answerC: Prepare to yield to any train at the crossing.
questions.answerD: Speed up to beat any oncoming train.
questions.explanation: Always be prepared to yield to any oncoming trains before crossing railroad tracks, particularly if there are no lights or gates controlling the crossing. Never start to cross the tracks until there is room for your entire vehicle on the other side of the tracks. Due to the risk of a vehicle stalling, it is not wise to shift gears when crossing railroad tracks.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: T intersection.
questions.answerB: Lane shifting.
questions.answerC: Side road.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers that they are approaching a T intersection and should prepare to turn either right or left.

questions.question: It is important to be alert to motorcycles because:
questions.answerA: They are more difficult to see than cars.
questions.answerB: They rarely use their headlights.
questions.answerC: Motorcyclists are less skilled drivers than other motorists.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles are smaller and harder to see than cars. Because of their size, they are easily hidden in a car’s blind spot. It may be difficult to judge your distance to a motorcycle and difficult to tell how fast a motorcycle is moving, so always be alert and extra cautious when near a motorcyclist.

questions.question: SCDMV must be notified within ____ days of any name or address changes.
questions.explanation: SCDMV must be informed about any change to your name or address within 10 days of the change.

questions.question: You are driving on the freeway behind a large truck. You should drive:
questions.answerA: Closer behind the truck than you would if following a passenger vehicle.
questions.answerB: Farther behind the truck than you would if following a passenger vehicle.
questions.answerC: To the right side of the truck and wait to pass.
questions.explanation: It is necessary to follow farther behind a large truck than you would if following a passenger vehicle because trucks have larger blind spots.

questions.question: When driving in fog, you should use your high beam headlights.
questions.answerA: True
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: You should use your low beam headlights when driving in fog. High beams will reflect back at the driver and lower visibility.

questions.question: Which of the following are used on some highways to direct drivers into the proper lanes for turning?
questions.answerA: Flashing red lights
questions.answerB: Flashing yellow lights
questions.answerC: White lines on the side of the road
questions.answerD: White arrows in the middle of the lanes
questions.explanation: Arrows may be used to indicate which lanes should be used for specific purposes, such as driving straight or making a turn.

questions.question: If you find that the roadway ahead of you is flooded, you should:
questions.answerA: Slam on the brakes.
questions.answerB: Not drive through the flooded area. Turn around and find another route.
questions.answerC: Drive only in the center of the roadway.
questions.explanation: Never attempt to drive on a flooded road. Even if the water looks shallow, it may hide many kinds of hazards. If you encounter a flooded area, turn around and seek another route to your destination.

questions.question: You are driving on a narrow road when you meet an oncoming vehicle. You must:
questions.answerA: Pull completely off the road and stop.
questions.answerB: Allow the oncoming vehicle at least one-half of the main-traveled portion of the road.
questions.answerC: Demand the other vehicle pull over to make room.
questions.answerD: Turn on your high beam headlights to make sure the other vehicle sees you.
questions.explanation: On narrow roads, you must allow vehicles traveling in the opposite direction at least one-half of the main-traveled portion of the road. Both vehicles must have adequate space in order for the drivers to safely pass one another.

questions.question: If you see a cyclist in your lane ahead and wish to pass, you should:
questions.answerA: Treat the cyclist as any other driver you would pass.
questions.answerB: Lightly tap your horn to warn the cyclist.
questions.answerC: Wait until traffic is clear in the opposite lane and then change lanes to pass the cyclist.
questions.explanation: Bicycles on a roadway are considered to be vehicles and should be treated as such. A loud blast of your horn could startle a cyclist and cause an accident, so your horn should be used lightly only to get a cyclist's attention. Before passing a cyclist in a narrow traffic lane, wait until the traffic is clear in the opposite lane and then change lanes to pass the cyclist; do not attempt to squeeze past them.

questions.question: You should signal continuously while turning because it:
questions.answerA: Is illegal to turn off your signal before completing a turn.
questions.answerB: Lets other drivers know what your intentions are.
questions.answerC: Is always unsafe to turn off a signal before completing a turn.
questions.explanation: You should always signal when turning, changing lanes, slowing down, or stopping so that other drivers, motorcyclists, bicyclists, and pedestrians will know your intentions.

questions.question: A solid white line down the center of a two-lane road indicates:
questions.answerA: Lanes are moving in opposite directions and drivers are not permitted to pass.
questions.answerB: Lanes are moving in opposite directions and drivers are permitted to pass when it is safe to do so.
questions.answerC: Lanes are moving in the same direction and drivers are not permitted to pass.
questions.answerD: Lanes are moving in the same direction and drivers are permitted to pass when it is safe to do so.
questions.explanation: White lines are used to separate traffic moving in the same direction. Solid lines indicate that drivers are not permitted to pass.

questions.question: When taking any medicine, you should:
questions.answerA: Consult your doctor about the effects before driving.
questions.answerB: Have someone follow you home.
questions.answerC: Keep your window open and drive more slowly.
questions.explanation: Legal medications, both prescription and over-the-counter, can potentially impair your ability to drive. Always consult with your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions about how a particular drug or drug combination will affect your ability to drive. You should particularly make a point of talking with your doctor if they give you a prescription for a tranquilizer or sedative.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: No right turns.
questions.answerB: Right turns are permitted.
questions.answerC: Stop before turning right.
questions.explanation: A regulatory sign displaying a red circle with a red slash through the middle indicates that a specific action is prohibited. Right turns are not permitted where this sign is posted.

questions.question: "No zones" are areas around trucks where cars:
questions.answerA: Disappear into blind spots.
questions.answerB: Have sufficient space for traveling behind and passing trucks.
questions.answerC: Can try to squeeze around the truck when the truck makes a wide turn.
questions.explanation: Large trucks and buses have large blind spots to the sides, the rear, and the front. These areas are referred to as "No zones." Drivers of smaller vehicles should avoid lingering in these areas because they will be invisible to the truck driver and may also restrict the truck driver's ability to stop or maneuver safely.

questions.question: Before turning, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your signal.
questions.answerB: Turn the wheel.
questions.answerC: Increase your speed.
questions.explanation: To complete a turn safely, you should activate your turn signal three to four seconds before your turn.

questions.question: The correct way to execute a three-point turnabout is to:
questions.answerA: Signal, check your mirrors, then perform the turnabout.
questions.answerB: Signal, then perform the turnabout.
questions.answerC: Signal, check your mirrors, look over your left shoulder, and perform the turnabout when the way is completely clear.
questions.explanation: To make a three-point turn, stop close to the right edge of the road, look over your left shoulder to check for traffic behind you, signal a left turn, then execute the turning maneuver.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Watch for bicycles.
questions.answerB: Bicycles not allowed.
questions.answerC: Bicycle repair shop ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign provides advance warning that bicycles may be present.

questions.question: You should not make sudden stops in front of large trucks and buses because:
questions.answerA: Small vehicle drivers cannot adequately see large trucks and buses in their rearview mirrors.
questions.answerB: Large trucks and buses, due to their size and weight, require longer distances to stop than smaller passenger vehicles.
questions.answerC: Large trucks and buses travel at a higher speeds than small vehicles.
questions.explanation: Large vehicles require longer distances to stop and accelerate than smaller vehicles do. Making a sudden stop in front of a large vehicle is dangerous because the other driver may not be able to stop in time to avoid a collision.

questions.question: What is the purpose of rumble strips?
questions.answerA: They alert drivers to potential tire problems.
questions.answerB: They test a vehicle's shock absorbers.
questions.answerC: Through vibration and sound, they alert inattentive drivers to the fact that their vehicles have left the travel lane.
questions.explanation: Rumble strips create noise and vibrations to warn drowsy or inattentive drivers that they are straying off of the road or are approaching a stop sign or signal.

questions.question: A double solid yellow line down the center of a two-lane road indicates:
questions.answerA: Lanes are moving in opposite directions and drivers are not permitted to pass.
questions.answerB: Lanes are moving in opposite directions and drivers are permitted to pass when it is safe to do so.
questions.answerC: Lanes are moving in the same direction and drivers are not permitted to pass.
questions.answerD: Lanes are moving in the same direction and drivers are permitted to pass when it is safe to do so.
questions.explanation: Yellow lines are used to separate traffic moving in opposite directions. Solid lines indicate that drivers are not permitted to pass.

questions.question: When the road is marked with a solid yellow line and a broken yellow line, with the broken line next to your lane, you may pass:
questions.answerA: Only in an emergency.
questions.answerB: If you are on an expressway.
questions.answerC: If traffic is clear.
questions.explanation: When there is a solid yellow line and a broken yellow line in the center of the road and the broken line is next to your lane, you may cross the lines to pass if there is no oncoming traffic.

questions.question: If you are involved in an accident, you should:
questions.answerA: Remain near the scene of the accident and move your vehicle to the shoulder of the road, if possible.
questions.answerB: Report the accident to the police within one week.
questions.answerC: Go to the nearest telephone and call for help.
questions.explanation: If you are involved in an accident, you must stop your vehicle and move it from the roadway, provide aid to anyone who is injured, notify law enforcement as soon as possible (no matter who is at fault), exchange information with other drivers involved, and submit required reports to the DMV and to your insurance company.

questions.question: When it starts raining or snowing enough for you to turn on your windshield wipers, you must also:
questions.answerA: Pull over to the side of the road.
questions.answerB: Turn on your headlights.
questions.answerC: Shift into a lower gear.
questions.explanation: You are required to turn on your headlights any time conditions make it necessary for you to use your windshield wipers. Use your low beams, not your high beams, when driving in inclement weather.

questions.question: You are turning onto a two-lane road divided by a broken yellow line. You know immediately that:
questions.answerA: You are on a two-way road.
questions.answerB: You are on a one-way road.
questions.answerC: The road is under repair.
questions.answerD: You must stay to the left of the broken yellow lines.
questions.explanation: Yellow centerlines are used to separate traffic moving in opposite directions. Broken lines may be crossed to pass slower-moving traffic when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Two-way traffic.
questions.answerB: Lane shifting.
questions.answerC: Low clearance.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign tells drivers that they may encounter traffic coming from the opposite direction.

questions.question: At a crosswalk:
questions.answerA: You must yield to pedestrians.
questions.answerB: Pedestrians must yield to you.
questions.answerC: Construction workers must yield to you.
questions.explanation: Pedestrians have the right-of-way at street crossings but must obey traffic control signals. Where a traffic signal is not present, vehicles must stop for pedestrians in a crosswalk, whether it is marked or unmarked.

questions.question: ____ limit your concentration, perception, judgment, and memory.
questions.answerA: Only a blood alcohol level greater than the legal limit can
questions.answerB: Alcohol does not
questions.answerC: Even the smallest amount of alcohol can
questions.answerD: Only a blood alcohol level greater than 0.05 percent can
questions.explanation: Even the smallest amount of alcohol will reduce your concentration, perception, judgment and memory, and your driving skills will suffer. No one can drink and drive safely.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Stop Sign Ahead.
questions.answerB: Side Road.
questions.answerC: Railroad Warning.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that a stop sign is ahead.

questions.question: A driver should:
questions.answerA: Assume all drivers automatically obey the right-of-way rules.
questions.answerB: Assume most drivers obey the right-of-way rules.
questions.answerC: Always be prepared to yield the right-of-way.
questions.explanation: Although the right-of-way rules provide a guide to determine who should yield the right-of-way at an intersection, no one should assume they automatically have the right-of-way. The situation and circumstances at an intersection must always be considered. Drivers should yield their legal right-of-way if it can help prevent a collision.
